Plan name: United Nations Strategic Framework for Afghanistan
Strategic priority: Economic Opportunities and Resilient Livelihoods
Outcome: By the end of 2025, more people in Afghanistan, notably women and vulnerable groups, will benefit from an increasingly inclusive economy, with greater equality of economic opportunities, jobs, more resilient livelihoods, strengthened food value chains, and improved natural resources management.
Output: Output 2.3: Rural communities can better and sustainably manage natural resources, increase agricultural productivity and value addition, manage and reduce disaster risks, and enhance biodiversity, contributing to increased resilience, food security and nutrition, decent work, and sustainable livelihoods for all Afghans.
Sub-Output: 2.3.1 The livelihood of the food-insecure rural households is sustained and improved to protect food security and nutrition.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for International Cooperation, Development Cooperation Instrument; FAO Multi-Donor Funds; Government of Luxembourg; Islamic Development Bank; Special Trust Fund for Afghanistan; United States Agency for International Development; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: Local and international NGOs
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
Geography: Northern Region; North Eastern Region; KABUL; NIMROZ; SAMANGAN; Central Highland Region; LOGAR; PARWAN; KANDAHAR; NOORISTAN; NANGARHAR; LAGHMAN; BALKH; KHOST; BAMYAN; TAKHAR; PAKTIKA; UROZGAN; ZABUL; HELMAND; Afghanistan; GHAZNI; DAYKUNDI; Western Region; PANJSHER; Southern Region; GHOR; BAGHLAN; FARAH; KAPISA; BADAKHSHAN; Capital Region (Central); South Eastern Region; HERAT; SAR-E-PUL; KUNARHA; FARYAB; PAKTYA; KUNDUZ; BADGHIS; Maidan Wardak; JAWZJAN; Eastern Region

Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: During the reporting period (July to December 2023), FAO through its Implementing Partners (IPs) and under its non-HRP initiatives, directly supported 225,463 people (32,209 HHs), noting that some of these people benefitted more than one form of assistance, across the nation.  Additionally, during the above-mentioned period, FAO through its Implementing Partners (IPs) established 530 Common Interest Groups (CIGs) and Farmer Field Schools (FFS) for wheat, livestock, soybean, mushroom, and beekeeping in the country.
2024 Narrative: During the reporting period (January - June 2024), FAO, in collaboration with its Implementing Partners (IPs) directly supported 148 330 people (noting that some of these people benefitted from more than one type of assistance package) across the country.Furthermore, FAO facilitated the establishment and organization of 533 Common Interest Groups, Farmer Field Schools, Livestock Farmer Field Schools, and Women and Youth Producers Groups. The groups comprised 10 514 smallholder farmers and livestock owners, with a notable inclusion of 2 225 female participants. These initiatives were strategically focused on various agricultural sectors including crop cultivation, livestock management, home gardening, soybean cultivation, mushroom cultivation, orchard management, ferula (hing) production, poultry farming, micro-greenhouses, beekeeping, fig cultivation, and the implementation of cash-for-work activities. To ensure the successful implementation of these initiatives, pertinent training sessions were conducted to equip individuals and groups with the necessary knowledge and skills to effectively utilize the resources provided.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 10 - Social Protection
Outcome: Outcome 10.1 - By 2022, improved and effective social protection systems will be available for all, particularly for the most vulnerable and marginalized populations
Output: Output 10.1.3 - Fostering innovative solutions to strengthen existing schemes, such as the BISP and Pakistan Bait-ul-Mal, while working with employers‚Äô and workers‚Äô organisations including advocacy around universal health care, insurance schemes, birth registration, CNICs and cash transfers ‚Äì both conditional and unconditional.
Sub-Output: 10.1.3.1 - Social protection system at the federal and provincial levels provides the populations most in need, especially women, adolescent girls and children, with improved and sustained access to safe, nutritious and sufficient food by 2022 (SDG 2.1)
Description: WFP Internal Activity: Augment Government of Pakistan social protection mechanisms like the Benazir Income Support Programme, PSPA etc. to support food and nutrition insecure urban and rural poor people.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Benazir Income Support Programme; Government of Balochistan; Government of KP; Government of Punjab; Government of Sindh
SDG Targets: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
To address the issue of malnutrition among PLW and their children (below the age of five years), WFP launched an integrated CMAM-SafetyNet initiative to support Community Based Treatment of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM)-graduated PLWs to maintain their diet and food consumption during the post-recovery period in four union councils of District Umerkot, Sindh. Under the project, WFP provided an unconditional cash grant of PKR 15,000/ each graduated PLW for improving their diet intake with liberty to utilize the cash for initiating or diversifying livelihoods and diversifying income-generation options so that they can earn or save an income to meet their own and their children‚Äôs food needs that remained unmet due to poverty, low levels of income and corresponding limited affordability. 
The support was meant to assist in strengthening the prevention component of the continuum of care and further reduce relapse while improving and adopting appropriate good feeding practices and a healthy diet through income diversifying activities. A total of 2,446 households of pregnant and lactating women (PLW) and children treated under Community Based Treatment of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) were assisted with one-time unconditional cash assistance of PKR 36.6 M to support their diversified food consumption and/or contribute to initiating income diversifying activities under the ‚ÄúCMAM-Safety Net‚Äù initiative.
An end assessment of the project was conducted to assess the overall impact of the project. A total of 92% of the interviewed households reported project benefits in terms of health and nutrition education and through income support for their households. For the utilization of cash, approximately 78% of the interviewed beneficiaries invested in livestock by spending most of the amount on purchasing goats. Some purchased lactating goats, some lamb while one of the beneficiaries purchased buffalo by selling two goats and adding the received amount of PKR 15,000. Approximately 7% of the interviewed beneficiaries purchased sewing machines as a productive asset with an assumption of earning money by stitching clothes. 7% of the interviewed beneficiaries invested money to start a small business or to further extend the current business. One of the beneficiary households used the cash assistance to pay off the installment of the auto-rickshaw that it had purchased as a source of livelihood. 2% of the beneficiaries shared that they had spent the money for their medical needs. One beneficiary had spent the money on her delivery while another had paid the money to bear the expenses of her daughter who has cardiac issues. However, 8% of the beneficiaries shared that the amount received had not changed their income generation but had considerably helped them to meet their food needs.

Plan name: UN Socioeconomic and Peacebuilding Framework for COVID-19 Recovery in the Philippines 2020-2023
Strategic priority: People
Outcome: The most marginalized, vulnerable, and at-risk people and groups benefit from more inclusive and quality services and live in more supportive environments where their nutrition, food security, health and life-long learning are ensured and protected.
Output: Output 1: Social determinants of people's health are holistically addressed and health systems strengthened for enhanced health outcomes
Sub-Output: Enhancing Food Security and Livelihoods
Description:
The project aims to support and sustain peacebuilding and recovery in Bangsamoro on a food supply crisis and food price inflation and the delay of livelihood support under the Peace Process through the following two approaches. The first is short-term assistance in providing immediate food distribution among the worst impacted or more marginalized communities in the BARMM and adjacent areas in Mindanao. The second is mid-term support to improve livelihood in Bangsamoro through enhancing the capacity of Community Cooperative Groups (including women‚Äôs associations) and strengthening food value chains for the agricultural and fishery sectors towards food security. The project will also contribute to addressing the socio-economic impacts of natural and human-induced disasters in the BARMM, particularly in the aftermath of tropical storm Nalgae (Paeng) which severely affected vulnerable communities in the region.

By improving basic food sufficiency and economic stability in post-conflict Bangsamoro, this project could contribute to achieving SDGs 2: Zero hunger because food shortages could be alleviated, and nutrition could be improved; and SDGs 16: Peace, justice and strong institutions because implementation capacity of local authorities and community groups could be improved to build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions and to promote sustainable agriculture and fishery. Hence, peaceful and inclusive communities for sustainable development could be promoted.
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.5 By 2020, maintain the genetic diversity of seeds, cultivated plants and farmed and domesticated animals and their related wild species, including through soundly managed and diversified seed and plant banks at the national, regional and international levels, and ensure access to and fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge, as internationally agreed

Plan name: UN Socioeconomic and Peacebuilding Framework for COVID-19 Recovery in the Philippines 2020-2023
Strategic priority: Prosperity and Planet
Outcome: Urbanization, economic growth, and climate change actions are converging for a resilient, equitable, and sustainable development path for communities.
Output: Output 8: Untapped potential for agriculture-based inclusive growth and sustainable agri-food systems effectively leveraged.
Sub-Output: Rapid assessment on COVID-19 impacts to food supply chains
Description: The report looks at rural livelihood and agricultural market chains as a critical component of the country‚Äôs food security capacity, and the related effects to it of the community restrictions imposed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Likewise, the report assesses the impact of COVID-19 on the access of the most vulnerable population that may result in a high rate of malnutrition. The results are expected to provide an information base to aid in local and national decision-making to alleviate the impact of this pandemic and facilitate the production movement, and distribution of goods essential to food security without compromising public health and safety
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Fund for Agricultural Development
Implementation partners: Philippines Department of Agriculture
SDG Targets: 1.2 By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.c Adopt measures to ensure the proper functioning of food commodity markets and their derivatives and facilitate timely access to market information, including on food reserves, in order to help limit extreme food price volatility.

2024 Narrative: Distributed 7,000 kg of quinoa seed to over 1,000 acres of land in eastern districts (Trashigang, Mongar, and Trashi Yangtse).Conducted awareness campaigns to promote quinoa cultivation and trained 21 extension officers on quinoa cultivation and utilization.Quinoa is being actively promoted as a nutritious option in hospital and school feeding programs to enhance dietary diversity and support healthier meal plans.Organized ToT programs for researchers and extension officers on quinoa breeding, participatory selection, and cultivation.Provided ongoing technical guidance from FAO's National Quinoa expert.Initiated germplasm development, including trials for tricolor quinoa germination.Conducted field trials, including fertilizer trials within maize-based systems, in various locations.Undertaken surveys and documentation of major insect pests in key quinoa-growing areas.Supported the formation of three farmer groups to cultivate Nameko mushrooms under the TANDI project.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2022 - 2026
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: Inclusive and Sustainable Economic Development
Outcome: Outcome 1: By 2026 people, more people in Bangladesh, particularly the most vulnerable and marginalized from all gender and social groups and those from lagging districts benefit from sustainable livelihood and decent work opportunities resulting from responsible, inclusive, sustainable, green and equitable economic development.
Output: 1.1 Strengthened capacities of the government on evidence-based policies and regulatory mechanisms and SDG financing mechanisms for diverse investments in labour intensive, inclusive (youth women and vulnerable groups), and responsible green businesses including infrastructures and public services
Sub-Output: Institutional capacity building to develop actionable policy and mobilize resource for enhanced livelihood and employment opportunities within the agro-food system through policy dialogue, planning and public-private collaboration
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation; European Union; Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Government of Bangladesh; Government of the Netherlands; International Labour Organisation; The Global Environment Facility; The Green Climate Fund; The World Bank; United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Bangladesh Ministry of Agriculture; Bangladesh Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock; Bangladesh Ministry of Food
SDG Targets: 1.2 By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty; 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Peasants & Rural Workers; Women & Girls; Youth
2022 Narrative: A) In order to strengthen linkages between producers‚Äô organizations and relevant partners in the agribusiness value chain, FAO-MMI project established a productive alliance amongst public, private and producer organizations. This alliance has backstopped 55 POs to link with both domestic and export markets, which eventually benefitted over 11000 smallholders farmers. B) FAO supported 5500 liveststock producer groups (PG) and characterized the PG, mobilization, livestcok based commodities of common interest identified and mobilized, Digital Field Data monitoring system deployed.
2023 Narrative: FAO organized several investment forums in the country to support resource mobilization and encourage private sector participation and investment in addressing climate change. Bangladesh Agricultural Investment Forum in August was one of these initiatives, it aimed to encourage the participation of the private sector in enhancing climate-resilient agri-food systems and natural resource management (fishery, livestock, and crops). The Ministry of Agriculture organized the Bangladesh Agricultural Investment Forum (BAIF) 2023 on 27‚Äì28 August 2023, with support from FAO, IFAD, WFP, IFC, The World Bank, GAIN, CGIAR, and the Embassy of Denmark. The Forum brought together the ministries, UN agencies, international NGOs, multilateral development banks, financial institutions, the private sector, government agencies, and other stakeholders for a dialogue on business and finance opportunities for the future of agriculture, strengthening the sector‚Äôs competitiveness, climate change adaptation, policy development, livestock, and fisheries.Three training workshops were organized to introduce FAO‚Äôs rapid assessment and analysis tool for examining agrifood trade disruptions, and macroeconomic and food policy responses, in response to the agrifood systems crisis in Asia and the Pacific. More than 58 participants from 41 agencies (Government, private sector, academia and CSOs) attended the events. The workshops included analysis of global and national food and nutrition issues, key macroeconomic indicators, the impact of commodity price volatility on the macro-economy, early warning mechanisms and safety net programmes and the overall global 5F crisis (food, feed, fertilizer, fuel and finance).
2024 Narrative: The Ministry of Agriculture in Bangladesh, in collaboration with key stakeholders, is implementing several strategic initiatives to enhance agricultural resilience, food security, and rural development. A crucial intervention is Strengthening Skills and Entrepreneurship in Agro-Food Systems for the Host Communities and Rohingya People in Cox‚Äôs Bazar, aimed at building sustainable livelihoods through skill development and agribusiness opportunities. Additionally, the Technical Assistance to the Diversified Resilient Agriculture for Improved Food and Nutrition Security (RAINS-TA) Project is supporting smallholder farmers by promoting climate-smart agricultural practices. The TCPF: Support to Accelerating the Food and Agriculture System Transformation Process is driving policy reforms and innovative approaches, including the piloting of Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) technology, which facilitates precision agriculture and informed land-use planning.

Plan name: UNSDCF 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Inclusive Human Development
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - People living in Indonesia, especially those at risk of being left furthest behind, are empowered to fulfil their human development potential as members of a pluralistic, tolerant, inclusive, and just society, free of gender and all other forms of discrimination
Output: Output 1.1.10 - Governments and stakeholders at national and local level have greater capacity to develop and implement coherent and coordinated migration and asylum policies and measures that protect and benefit migrants, refugees/asylum seekers, and communities
Sub-Output: 1.1.10.7 - Promoting regular and safe labour migration among South East Asian countries, in particular in the fishing and seafood processing industry (Ship to Shore Project)
Agencies: International Labour Organisation; International Organization for Migration
Implementation partners: Confederations of Workers Trade Unions; Indonesia  Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries/KKP; Indonesia Ministry of Manpower; Indonesia National Board for the Placement and Protection of Indonesian Overseas Workers (BP2MI); Indonesia‚Äôs Employer Association
SDG Targets: 8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.,8.8 Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
SDG Goals: 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth; 10 Reduced Inequalities
Geography: Jawa Tengah; Sulawesi Utara; Kota Bitung; Tegal; Indonesia
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
Focal users: Zena Van Bemmel; Swasti Istika; Julia Lusiani
2021 Narrative:
IOM: Contributing to this activity, IOM through the Ship to Shores project aims to promote the regular and safe labour migration in particular in the fishing and seafood processing industry. In 2021, IOM in collaboration with the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries of the Republic of Indonesia the project implemented a Virtual Training on Identification and Handling of Victims of Trafficking in Persons for Frontline Officers in Fisheries Sector in Indonesia. The training also facilitate sharing and discussion sessions with experts from government and non-government representatives to capacitate 32 frontline officers in Manado Area on various prominent topics including Human Rights and Gender Lens in Fisheries Sector, Identification of TIP cases in fisheries sector, Prosecution of TIP cases, National Referral and Coordination Mechanism. 

ILO: ILO facilitated the initial technical review and tripartite discussion on the harmonization of laws and regulations in Indonesia fishing sector including the plan to develop of national level agreement for Joint Inspection onboard of Fishing Vessels. The meeting organized on 6 October 2021, organized by Ship to Shore Rights SEA Programme.
2022 Narrative: ILO: To expand regional cooperation on work in fishing, ILO through S2SR organized the Fair Seas Labour Conference in Bali, Indonesia in 6-7 September 2022. The Conference brought together 85 representatives of government, workers, employers and civil society from 8 ASEAN countries to discuss safe migration and decent work in the fishing and seafood processing sectors and issued a plenary resolution on priorities for regional cooperation. A series of provincial focus group discussions were held to support a multi-disciplinary model of fishing vessel inspection. In addition, 4 operational tools were adopted to strengthen national referral mechanisms for the protection of survivors of trafficking in Thailand, Cambodia, Myanmar and Indonesia, and direct assistance was provided for the repatriation of 23 trafficked fishers in Somalia, Indonesia and Malta.IOM: Through the Ship to Shore project, IOM conducted research on Labor Supply Chain Dynamics focusing on land-based informal migrant workers in SMEs in the seafood industry in Indonesia. This research was part of the effort to strengthen the protection of migrant fishers who migrate both locally within Indonesian territory and abroad. The research has provided recommendations on recruitment, employment contracts, working conditions such as working time, occupational health and safety, wages, living conditions, debt, and access to remedy, which can be followed up by the Government after the study is released to the public.To support the comprehensive recovery intervention towards the victim of trafficking after the repatriation phase, IOM supported the national government, such as BP2MI, the Ministry of Social Affairs, and the Indonesian Migrant Workers Union (SBMI), to enhance the official‚Äôs capacity for reintegration. As an effort to make this initiative more sustainable, IOM rolled out a series of TOT on Reintegration that utilized IOM's Handbook on Reintegration contextualized to the country's situation. The training has provided participants with an understanding that encourages them to commit to supporting the reintegration process at the community level. In addition, the participants agreed to further utilize the contextualized curriculum to increase the capacity of stakeholders involved in reintegration assistance.In addition, IOM conducted labour supply chain mappings for the fishers who migrated to the Republic of Korea. Over 200 prospective workers participated in the survey, followed by an in-depth interview with the Ministry of Manpower, BP2MI, Ministry of Transportation, Ministry of Fishers and Maritime Affairs, and Private Recruitment Agency. The research highlighted several aspects, such as the recruitment process of the fishers, workers' requirements, including skill and qualifications, recruitment fee and cost, PDO, and fishers' migration management. The research result is expected to recommend GOI towards implementing Government Regulation No 22/2022 on the Placement of Migrant Commercial Ship Crews and Migrant Fishing Ship Crews, IOM will continue supporting the practical application of these recommendations through its work under this output.
2023 Narrative: ‚Ä¢ Coordinating Ministry of the Maritime Affairs and Investment issued a Decree No. 29/2023 concerning Coordination and Harmonisation Team for Laws and Regulations Related to the Protection of Workers in the Fisheries Sector Especially Those Working on Board Fishing Vessels on 23 February 2023. With this decree, Indonesia established a team to harmonize laws and regulations in Indonesia fishing sector which consist of representatives of various relevant Government Ministries/Institutions. The ILO facilitate the team in organizing series of technical coordination meeting in order to recommend some technical actions to harmonizing laws and regulations in Indonesia fishing sector.‚Ä¢The Regional Secretary of the Central Java Province issued a new Decree Number 523/012 Year of 2023 Concerning Joint Monitoring Team for Labour Norms on Fisheries Vessels at Fishing Ports within the Jurisdiction of the Central Java Province. Two local government offices in Central Java Province, namely the Local Marine Affairs and Fisheries and Local Manpower and Transmigration Offices of Central Java Province worked together to develop a decree on joint inspection onboard fishing vessels with the support from the ILO.IOMIn 2023, several legal, policy, and regulatory frameworks related to labour migration and employment in the fishing and seafood processing sectors at the national and subnational levels were strengthened signaling an enhanced structural protection for migrant workers. ASEAN Declaration on The Placement and Protection of Migrant Fishers was adopted during the 42nd ASEAN Summit on 10 May 2023, underscores the ASEAN commitment to enhance the wellbeing and protection of the migrant fishers. In addition to that, the National Action Plan on Prevention and Handling the Criminal Act of Trafficking in Persons (2020-2024) was adopted through Presidential Regulation No. 19/2023 in Indonesia. The Decree No. 523/012 on the Joint Monitoring Team for Labour Norms on Fishing Vessels at Fishing Ports was issued, mandating the Marine Affairs and Fisheries Office and the Manpower and Transmigration Office of Central Java Province to collaborate on inspection of fishing vessels. To increase the protection of labour rights and safe and secure working environments for migrant women and men workers in the fishing and seafood processing sectors, IOM conducted several trainings for frontline officers on identification of victims of trafficking in East Java; on standard operating procedures on integrated services for witnesses and/or victims of trafficking for the Anti-Trafficking Task Force in Central Java; on fair recruitment for government regulatory authorities in Indonesia. Total numbers of government personnel trained are 317 people. Total various government and CSO stakeholders trained are 397 people.25 trafficking survivors (all men) who worked in the fishing, seafood processing and other employment sectors were provided with direct support for return and reintegration in communities of origin in Indonesia.Under the Ship to Shore project, two studies were commissioned; namely, In the Shadows of the Ship (research on internal migrant workers employed in Indonesia‚Äôs seafood processing sector: small and medium enterprises, home-based workplaces and on the pier), and Navigating Indonesian Migrant Fishers (a study on the recruitment and placement process of Indonesian migrant fishers in the Republic of Korea).
2024 Narrative: In Indonesia, ILO partners with SBMI (Serikat Buruh Migran Indonesia) to operate the MRC (Migrant Resource Center) in Tegal, which specifically addresses the needs of potential current, and returned migrant fishers and their families. SBMI was founded in 2003 and advocates for the rights of migrant workers. As a part of the partnership, ILO provides capacity building to SBMI‚Äôs National Board as well as staff at Regency and village levels, who are crucial in the provision of outreach and services, and ensuring that migrant fishers receive accurate and authoritative information, and can provide robust support in case of grievances and problems. Since the launch of the MRC in April 2024, SBMI has trained 15 community members to provide paralegal services in 3 villages around Tegal. It has received 75 complaints from migrant fishers, who seek support to address the issues and seek remedies. To date, SBMI has successfully obtained nearly US$ 19,000 in compensation for migrant fishers.ILO through its Ship to Shore Rights SEA Project partnered with the Trade Union Federation of Food, Beverage, Tourism, Restaurant, Hotel and Tobacco (FSB KAMIPARHO) to support workers‚Äô organising in the seafood processing sector. ILO supported KAMIPARHO to empower union members and plant-level leaders in Jakarta and Bitung through training on leadership skills, labour rights and paralegal support. Women workers were intentionally selected for skills training to identify and encourage women leadership. I

Sub-Output: 1.1.1.46 - UNIDO: Strategic cooperation framework between UNIDO and the Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Light Industry of Mongolia 2021-2025
Description:
Director General‚Äôs approval-in-principle to develop a Strategic Cooperation Framework (SCF) for 20212-2025, between  UNIDO and MOFALI came in response to the letter of the Minister of MOFALI, dated 1 July 2021, inviting UNIDO to consider the formulation of the SCF (see Annex 1). The Framework recognizes the cooperation between UNIDO and MoFALI since Mongolia become a UNIDO Member State in 1985, and the fruitful cooperation carried out since then in the fields of sustainable food, agriculture and light industrial development, which has made a positive contribution to Mongolia's sustainable development, particularly with regard to the industrial sector. The Framework recognizes the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development adopted at the United Nations Summit in 2015, the Lima Declaration adopted at the fifteenth session of the UNIDO General Conference in 2013, as well as the Abu Dhabi Declaration adopted at the eighteenth session of the UNIDO General Conference in 2019 that welcomes UNIDO‚Äôs role in accelerating the achievement of SDG 9 along with all other industry-related goals of the 2030 Agenda with a primary objective to promote inclusive and sustainable industrial development (ISID) in its Member States.
The main objective of the Strategic Cooperation Framework (SCF) is to further strengthen the cooperation between MoFALI and UNIDO in the field of inclusive and sustainable industrial development (ISID) to advance the country‚Äôs capabilities in the food, agriculture and light industrial sectors. The SCF will define the broad areas of cooperation, based on UNIDO‚Äôs comparative advantages and Mongolia‚Äôs development priorities. The SCF is also expected to facilitate collaboration towards ISID, while contributing to the achievement of the SDGs and addressing issues of global concern, such as climate change and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, this Strategic Cooperation Framework (20212-2025) establishes priorities on which MoFALI and UNIDO agree to focus, and contributes to the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF), using UNIDO‚Äôs four main enabling functions of technical cooperation analytical and research functions and policy advisory services, normative functions and standards and quality-related activities, as well as convening and partnerships for knowledge transfer, networking and industrial cooperation.
Agencies: United Nations Industrial Development Organization
Implementation partners: Mongolia Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Light Industry
SDG Targets: 9.2 Promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and, by 2030, significantly raise industry's share of employment and gross domestic product, in line with national circumstances, and double its share in least developed countries.

Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Youth; Children ; Indigenous Peoples; Migrants; Minorities; Peasants & Rural Workers; Women & Girls
2023 Narrative: FAO has supported the integration and approval of 5 International Codex Standards on Food Safety at the Mongolian Agency for Standard and Metrology (MASM). They include: 1) General Principles of Food Hygiene CXC 1-1969. Adopted in 1969. Amended in 1999. Revised in 1997, 2003, 2020. Editorial corrections in 2011; 2) Principles and Guidelines for the Conduct of Microbiological Risk Management (MRM) CAC/GL 63-2007; 3) Code of Practice on Good Animal Feeding CAC/RCP 54-2004, Adopted 2004, Amendment 2008; 4) Maximum residue limits (MRLs) and risk management recommendations (RMRs) for residues of veterinary drugs in foods CX/MRL 2-2021; 5) Guidelines for the Design and Implementation of National Regulatory Food Safety Assurance Program Associated with the Use of Veterinary Drugs in Food-Producing Animals CAC/GL 71-2009, Adopted 2009. Revision 2012, 2014. The National Action Plan on Antimicrobial Resistance 2022-2025 has been developed in cooperation with the Medicine and Medical Devices Regulation Agency. The collaborative effort aimed to address AMR comprehensively across human, veterinary, and food sectors, marking the first official tripartite project of its kind. During 2023, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) directed its attention towards enhancing laboratory capacities specifically for AMR surveillance. The initial phase involved a thorough evaluation of the technical skills of lab inspectors across national laboratories spanning human, veterinary, and food domains. These labs actively participated in international proficiency testing to ensure their capabilities aligned with global standards in the critical fight against AMR. Recognizing the paramount importance of public awareness in tackling AMR, efforts extended to engaging the younger generation. Specialized awareness training sessions were conducted for school children, providing them with a simplified understanding of how AMR emerges and offering guidance on safeguarding against it. To amplify this message, collaboration with influential figures among children was fostered, activating a network capable of promoting awareness and encouraging proactive measures against the growing threat of Antimicrobial Resistance. This multifaceted approach underscored the significance of a One Health perspective in addressing AMR, emphasizing the interconnectedness of human, animal, and environmental health in the pursuit of sustainable solutions.
2024 Narrative: A survey was conducted on the implementation of the national standard "Requirements for Food Production and Service in General Education Schools, Dormitories, and Kindergartens" (MNS 7005:2023) across 155 selected schools.‚ÄãA cost analysis for school lunch programs revealed that the price of raw materials provided by the government needs to be increased by 900 MNT to ensure adequate caloric intake.

SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Within this activity, the need for scaled-up fortified rice in Indonesia is framed within the context of micronutrient deficiencies in the country, the prevalence of which vary across gender and age groups. WFP does this in a way that takes into account the prevalence within groups such as female adolescents and pregnant women.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: This activity is designed and implemented in a way that aims to ensure affordable and accessible fortified rice for all, including for marginalized populations and social protection beneficiaries.
2022 Narrative: WFP continued its partnership with the Ministry of National Development Planning to support Government plans for scaling up the availability and affordability of fortified rice. This partnership was strategically coordinated through the 2022-2024 Workplan for Joint Activities on Rice Fortification, endorsed by the Ministry. Under the Workplan, WFP generated evidence to inform policymakers and other stakeholders on how to increase affordability, availability, and quality of fortified rice. This was done through 1) a cost and supply chain analysis conducted with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to identify bottlenecks and cost drivers in fortified rice production, supply chain, and marketing, and 2) a quality assurance and control study to assess domestic capacity for fortified kernel production.In parallel, WFP and the Ministry convened stakeholders across sectors towards the formation of a national technical working group on rice fortification. The technical working group will serve as a platform through which stakeholders can collaboratively inform policies and programmes on rice fortification scale-up. WFP will continue to support this process in 2023.
2023 Narrative: WFP working in partnership with government and non-government entities accelerated progress towards large scale availability of affordable fortified rice, through advocacy, evidence generation, and South-South and Triangular Cooperation (SSTC). This laid the foundation for modelling of fortified rice distribution channels. Progress, with an emphasis on Government ownership, has been possible through the operationalization of the Rice Fortification Technical Working Group jointly established with the government in 2022.In 2023, WFP achieved two significant advocacy objectives. First: the release of the National Food Agency Regulation No. 2/2023 on Rice Quality and Labelling Standards. This regulation expands the grades of rice eligible for fortification, effectively lowering the cost and increasing the affordability and availability of domestically produced fortified rice. Second, WFP through joint efforts with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) established consensus among stakeholders on the criticality of scaled-up rice fortification to prevent micronutrient deficiencies. This was achieved through convening stakeholders for policy engagement and leveraging evidence generated under activities with government and other stakeholders. The consensus subsequently enabled joint advocacy for the prioritization of fortified foods, including fortified rice, in the next National Medium- and Long-Term National Development Plan.The achievements above were further bolstered by the emerging partnership between WFP and the National Food Agency and engagement with a larger, multi-year, multi-agency initiative to establish national standards for fortified rice and rice kernels. WFP and the Agency finalized and began to implement a joint 2023-2024 workplan to support the Agency‚Äôs efforts in developing further guidelines on fortified rice production. At the end of 2023, WFP and the Agency facilitated the first national expert consultation on rice fortification guidelines through the Rice Fortification Technical Working Group. WFP plans to continue policy engagement and technical assistance for these efforts in 2024.
2024 Narrative: In continued support of the government‚Äôs goal of large-scale availability of fortified rice, WFP supported the establishment and operationalization of the Large-Scale Food Fortification (LSFF) Coordination Forum, formalized in a decree by the Minister of National Development Planning. The decree acknowledges the LSFF Coordination Forum‚Äôs contributions in shaping the policy recommendations, evidence, and advocacy needed to achieve effective and sustainable national food fortification. Through the LSFF, WFP, the National Standardization Agency, and other partners developed the Indonesian National Standard for Fortified Rice Kernels. First of its kind in Indonesia, this new national standard regulates the production and labelling of fortified rice, enriching the existing policies and regulations on fortified rice with safety and quality assurance dimensions.

Description:
WFP's emergency response plan for 2023 aims to reach 2.5 million people with in-kind food, cash-based assistance, and nutrition (support to the National School Meals Programme and Thriposha) in areas of most need. 

Multiyear project: start date: 1/6/2022
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Government of Australia; Government of Canada; Government of France; Government of Japan; Government of Russia; Government of the United States of America; Private Donors

Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Children ; Women & Girls; Other; Youth; Persons With Disabilities; Minorities; Older Persons
2023 Narrative: Since 2022, WFP has supported over 3 million people affected by the economic crisis with food (rice, oil and lentils), cash and vouchers, and the provision of rice for the school meals programme and soya and maize for the production of Thriposha. In 2023, WFP has supported over 1.6 million people with cash, e-vouchers and in-kind food assistance in areas most affected by the economic crisis. WFP supported the continuation of Thriposha (fortified blended foods) by procuring soya and maize for production, which supported 700,000 pregnant and breastfeeding women and girls and children under 5. Through the provision of fortified rice to over 7000 schools across the island, 1 million school children were able to enjoy school meals. Additionally, 34,544 food packs were distributed in six rounds to around 5,500 MAM children identified in the Nuwara Eliya and Anuradhapura districts.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, WFP supported the district of Jaffna through it's Food for Assets (FFA) programme. During the activity period, 19 water ponds, and irrigation and drainage canal rehabilitation projects were completed in Jaffna district covering 7 DS divisions. This includes over 18 km of improvements to irrigation canals, and the clearing of over 4 km of water pond bunds directly benefitting 731 acres of agricultural land. The total number of participants was 2,435 households. Participants received cash assistance and 17.92 Mt of cooking oil. 73% of participants were female and 35% of participants were over 60 years of age.

Description: Technical assistance to government in building synergy between Government ministries, agencies, and programmes for school-aged children, promoting the utilization of nutrition education materials, and integrating nutrition education into Government-led initiatives and systems
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Asian Roundtable on Food Innovation for Improved Nutrition; Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade ; Cargill; Government of Indonesia; Japan Association for the World Food Programme; Strategic Resource Allocation Committee; United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office; United Nations World Food Programme; WFP COVID-19 South-South and Triangular Cooperation Opportunity Fund
Implementation partners: Indonesia Coordinating Ministry of Human Development and Cultural Affairs; Indonesia Ministry of Education, Culture, Research, and Technology; Indonesia Ministry of Health; Indonesia Ministry of Home Affairs; Indonesia Ministry of National Development Planning (BAPPENAS); Indonesia Ministry of Religious Affairs/Kemenag
SDG Targets: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Geography: Nusa Tenggara Timur; Dki Jakarta; Indonesia
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: This activity will promote the equal opportunity for primary school boys and girls in accessing the digital and non-digital  nutrition education materials and will increase the equal participation of women and men government's staff in the training  for inclusion of gender-sensitive digital and non-digital nutrition education materials into the primary school's curriculum, as well as   promoting the scale up on the use of digital and non-digital nutrition education materials based on the pilot evidence-based results
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Contribution to human rights is minor to the overall outcomes of the initiative.
2022 Narrative: WFP generated evidence on the importance of cross-sector collaboration for the nutrition of school-aged children. This was done through a study conducted in partnership with the Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization ‚Äì Regional Centre for Food and Nutrition (SEAMEO RECFON). This evidence was utilized to further the newly launched cross-sector National Action Plan for Improving the Welfare of School-Aged Children and Adolescents (RAN PIJAR) through strategic dialogue. This dialogue resulted in consensus among stakeholders on the importance of cross-sector collaboration for the nutrition of school-aged children.Additionally, to strengthen nutrition education, WFP digitalized nutrition education materials in partnership with the Centre for Data, Information and Technology of the Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology. WFP, the Ministry, UNICEF, and private sector partner evolve developed these materials in 2021. The materials aim to deliver messages on nutrition to primary school-aged children and guide parents, caretakers, and teachers in delivering these messages. The Ministry of Education, Culture, Research, and Technology has uploaded the materials on the UKS website, accessible by all. WFP also collaborated with the Ministry to communicate the materials nationally, embedded into the Ministry‚Äôs podcast, webinar, and web-series focused on school-aged children.WFP plans to continue supporting efforts enhancing synergies for improved nutrition among school-aged children in 2023.
2023 Narrative: WFP continued engagement with the Coordinating Ministry for Human Development and Cultural Affairs to improve nutrition for schoolchildren under the National Action Plan for Improving the Welfare of School-Aged Children and Adolescents (RAN PIJAR). WFP facilitation of cross-sector collaboration for RAN PIJAR in 2022 and 2023 resulted in formal appointment into the national RAN PIJAR implementation team by the Coordinating Ministry. WFP joins eight government entities and the World Health Organization in this national team. Through this partnership, WFP will continue to strengthen multi-sector coordination for the expansion of access to quality health and nutrition services through school and family-based approaches.WFP continued policy engagement for potential synergy between the School Health Programme (UKS) and the Ministry of Social Affairs‚Äô Family Hope Programme (PKH) for Integrated Primary School Nutrition (IPSN). This synergy aims to improve health and nutrition behaviours of parents and children while boosting the purchasing power of poor families to afford healthier food choices. At the sub-national level, WFP engaged its multi-sector national partnerships to begin laying the foundation for district-level IPSN model trials. The model will build upon existing government-led school-based nutrition programmes for schoolchildren, adding a critical educational component for parents or caregivers that aims to achieve synergy between school- and family- based nutrition education approaches. Through these engagements, WFP and government partners identified local needs opportunities, and challenges for the trials. WFP, in partnership with national and district governments will continue to refine and jointly implement IPSN model in 2024.Furthermore, WFP and the National Food Agency expanded their partnership in 2023 through the Agency's appointment of WFP into the national drafting team supporting a new Agency-led food and nutrition surveillance intervention targeting 25,000 primary schoolchildren in ten districts. Through technical assistance, including by leveraging its experiences with the 2016-2019 National Nutrition Programme for School Children to facilitate learning, WFP supported the launch of the technical guidelines.
2024 Narrative: WFP and partners provided technical assistance for the planning and early design processes leading up to the launch of the new national free nutritious meals programme, including by drawing from global and regional expertise and lessons learned from supporting school-based nutrition interventions in Indonesia. Through a national supply chain optimization workshop, WFP and the Ministry of National Development Planning jointly facilitated the sharing of good practices from other countries with national authorities on optimizing supply chains and sourcing strategies for school-based nutrition interventions ‚Äì including those in remote, hard to reach, and rural areas. Further aiming to bolster the new programme, WFP and partners advocated for Indonesia to join the global school meals coalition and succeeded in facilitating and affirming the Government‚Äôs pursuit of coalition membership. Being part of the global school meals coalition will help Indonesia to access resources from coalition members, share lessons learned, and adopt best practices.In partnership with subnational governments, WFP facilitated the institutionalization of mechanisms supporting the implementation of an upcoming Integrated Primary School Nutrition (IPSN) model pilot in the districts of Kupang (East Nusa Tenggara province) and Pasuruan (East Java province). The IPSN model approaches nutrition for school-aged children holistically, enriching existing government-led school-based nutrition programmes with family-based nutrition education and linkages with community stakeholders, such as healthcare providers. Stakeholders in Kupang district formalized Memorandums of Understanding linking health and education entities to provide nutrition services to over 1,000 primary schoolchildren in ten primary schools across the district. In Pasuruan district, WFP facilitated the launch of a regent‚Äôs decree formalizing a district-level multi-sector team comprised of nutrition, education, and health sector stakeholders to support the IPSN model pilot.

Description: To support the Ministry of National Development Planning (BAPPENAS) in strengthening inter-institutional coordination at national and sub-national (province and district) level and developing a shared vision and commitment to design, plan, and monitor components of food systems, to improve diets and enhance the delivery on SDG-2 in Indonesia

2021 Narrative: FAO: Under the Rome-based Agencies (RBAs) coordination and led by FAO, the project has contributed to the improvement of food systems transformation in Indonesia, with the longer-term goal of enhancing food security and nutrition. In particular, it has laid the foundations for shifting the national focus towards ‚Äúfood systems,‚Äù as opposed to the existing concept of ‚Äúfood security‚Äù. The BAPPENAS has committed to strengthening the coordination mechanism/ platform for food systems. Three proposed recommendations for the development of the new National Food Agency were shared with the BAPPENAS for further consideration. The BAPPENAS as well took account of the recommendations, which provided strategies for improving the Indonesian food system that is outlined in the RPJMN 2020‚Äì2024 (5-year Medium-term National Development Plan).

Plan name: UNSDCF 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Inclusive Human Development
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - People living in Indonesia, especially those at risk of being left furthest behind, are empowered to fulfil their human development potential as members of a pluralistic, tolerant, inclusive, and just society, free of gender and all other forms of discrimination
Output: Output 1.1.2 - Governments and key stakeholders at national and sub-national levels have strengthened capacity to deliver and increase demand for essential evidence-based nutrition and food security programs to address undernourishment and the double burden of malnutrition across the life course, including the most vulnerable groups
Sub-Output: 1.1.2.17 - Resilient and Sustainable Food System Programme (FMM/GLO/150/MUL)
Description: A key focus of the effort will be to improve the work on the three primary pillars -Food Production; Value Creation and Markets; and Nutrition and Diet- by working with the governments on the 4th pillar on Policy and Governance. Indonesia, along with Tanzania and Uganda, will be positioned as leading ‚Äúinnovation laboratories‚Äù in the context of the global preparatory process for the 2021 Food Systems Summit.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Indonesia  Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries/KKP; Indonesia Ministry of National Development Planning (BAPPENAS)
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative:
FAO: With the support from this project by having 2 national consultants who closely coordinated with BAPPENAS and MOA, BAPPENAS as the convenor of UN Food Systems Summit has organized national and sub-national food systems dialogues (FSSDs) in Indonesia as a process to incorporate the participation of wide range stakeholders on elaborating comprehensive exploration, gathering inputs on problem statements, analysis and identify game-changing solutions on food systems transformation. The stakeholders at national and sub-national level FSSDs have agreed that vision transformation is toward more healthy, equitable, sustainable, and resilient food systems in Indonesia. The strategy of the food systems transformation should recognize the diversity of ecology, socio-economic, and culture of Indonesia as an archipelagic country. Through the dialogues, BAPPENAS has developed a national strategy and pathway document on food systems transformation that has been submitted to UNFSS Secretariat. 
BAPPENAS has initiated a national platform that is developed in line with the national and sub-national dialogues processes. FSSDs in Indonesia have been conducted through a multi-stakeholder collaboration involving representatives of government, private sectors, and civil society organizations, from planning to implementation. Moreover, this platform has also been used to establish Indonesia Delegation on Food Systems Pre-Summit Rome and continued to Food Systems Summit in New York, September 2021. This project is still ongoing on supporting Food Systems transformation in Indonesia.
2022 Narrative: FAO: FAO through Flexible Voluntary Contribution (FVC Project) has committed to support the analytical work and policy paper as one of the priorities to support the pathway, especially on food systems modelling and convene several dialogues with participation form the local government and capacity development activities on agri-food system transformation. The Government of Indonesia, through BAPPENAS as the national convenor, has received a financial assistance (start-up funds) from the Food Systems Coordination Hub. The financing strategies for the transformation of the food systems play a key important role to complement the existing initiatives of the Government BAPPENAS for the implementation of the National Pathways.
2023 Narrative: FAO has been supporting the Government of Indonesia through the FMM/GLO/150/MUL projects that are focusing on the resilient agri-food systems to support Bappenas and Ministry of Agriculture for the agri-food systems transformation and good governance in Indonesia. Through series of preparation meetings for UN Food Systems Summit in 2021, a National pathways of Food System Transformation already reviewed and cleared from national and global levels.  It has been sensitized through national workshop with focus on sustainable food system planning by referring to the curriculum and tools that have been developed under previous TCP INS 3703 project. The Government of Indonesia, through BAPPENAS as the national convenor, has received a financial assistance (start-up funds) from the Food Systems Coordination Hub (FMM/GLO/181/MUL). The financing strategies for the transformation of the food systems has been developed, as a key important document to implement the existing initiatives of the Government BAPPENAS for the implementation of the National Pathways.

Sub-Output: 1.1.2.19 Technical Support on Exploring Bottlenecks and Pay-Offs Along the Value Chain in Reducing Food Loss and Waste in Perishable Commodities (TCP/INS/3807)
Description: The project aims to provide technical assistance to explore the bottlenecks and pay-offs in reducing food loss and waste in specific perishable commodities, such as fruits and vegetables, as well as provide recommendations on the evidence-based policies/ strategies to reduce food loss and waste in a specific commodity. The project outcome: Reduction in Food Loss and Waste, both quantity and quality losses, leading to the improvement of food security and nutrition and making production and consumption systems more sustainable.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Indonesia  Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries/KKP
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,12.3 By 2030, halve per capita global food waste at the retail and consumer levels and reduce food losses along production and supply chains, including post-harvest losses.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 12 Responsible Consumption and Production
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative: FAO: the project has just started in January 2022.
2023 Narrative: A comprehensive food loss analysis for chili, cabbage and shallot supply chains in selected regions of Indonesia was conducted by FAO together with MoA and Center of System - a research institution in the logistics sector. These three commodities, primarily cultivated by smallholder farmers, play a crucial role in stabilizing food prices and controlling regional inflation, apart from providing a direct contribution to food availability and accessibility. This study provides not only an analysis of quality and quantity losses but also practical solutions for their reduction. Series of  recommendations are provided for the Indonesian horticultural sector and considerations are made for the national food system. Special attention is given to the efficiency ofinterventions and their potential establishment. Innovation in technology, private-sector investment and raising public awareness are decisive elements in substantially reducing food loss. The study also contributes to the implementation of the FAO Regional Strategy on Food Loss and Waste Reduction in Asia and the Pacific that focuses on raising awareness, enabling and encouraging improved data collection and analysis, and facilitating the identification and implementation of state and non-state solutions and scale-up opportunities.

Sub-Output: 1.1.2.5 - National and subnational government have strengthened capacity to generate and utilise food security and nutrition evidence to address food insecurity and malnutrition and inform decision making.
Description:
1) Enhance government tools and analysis processes to monitor, capture, and communicate situations and risks on food security and nutrition. 
This includes: Fill the Nutrient Gap analysis, Food Security and Vulnerability Atlas, ad-hoc bulletins, support to Food and Nutrition Surveillance System (SKPG), work on Small Area Estimation.

2) Enhance national and sub-national capacity to utilise evidence to inform programme and policy decision making.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Finland Ministry for Foreign Affairs; Government of Indonesia; Non-core funds; The United Nations COVID-19 Response and Recovery Multi-Partner Trust Fund; United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Alma Ata University - Indonesia; Faculty of Public Health, University of Indonesia (FKM UI); Hasanuddin University - Indonesia; Indonesia  Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries/KKP; Indonesia Ministry of Health; Indonesia Ministry of National Development Planning (BAPPENAS); Indonesia National Food Agency; Indonesia National Statistics Agency/BPS; Institut Pertanian Bogor (IPB); Netherlands Development Organisation; Nutrition International; Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization Regional Center for Food and Nutrition; Statistics Polytechnic - Indonesia; The Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition; The SMERU Research Institute
SDG Targets: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: This activity aims to strengthen the Government‚Äôs capacities to collect and use data to inform food security and nutrition programme targeting and policies. This includes a gender-sensitive data such as the average years of schooling for women > 15 years old.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: This activity aims to strengthen the Government‚Äôs capacities to collect and use data to inform food security and nutrition programme targeting and policies. This includes the enhancement of methodologies that address contexts where data collection is challenging and populations are at risk of being left behind.
2022 Narrative: In 2019, the Government launched a cooperation agreement between seven ministries for multi-sector efforts to address food insecurity and reduce stunting in Indonesia, including through utilizing the Food Security and Vulnerability Atlas (FSVA). In 2022, WFP and the National Food Agency produced recommendations for enhancing provincial and district FSVA utilization through a case study in East Nusa Tenggara (NTT). These recommendations informed a partnership between WFP and the Government in NTT to advocate for a legal framework for FSVA utilization. As a result, the Kupang Regent of NTT issued a decree forming the legal basis for the utilization of the FSVA for food security policies and programmes through a technical working group led by the Regional Development Planning Agency. In parallel, WFP in partnership with the National Food Agency, Statistics Indonesia, and Statistics Polytechnic produced small-area estimation datasets, which will inform the 2022 subnational FSVAs in 34 provinces.
2023 Narrative: WFP continued to strengthen the Food Security and Vulnerability Atlas (FSVA), a joint WFP-Government effort initiated in 2005 which provides critical data and analysis at national and sub-national levels to inform development planning and geographic targeting of food security interventions. In 2023, WFP completed a review of the small area estimation (SAE) methodology the Government uses for sub-national FSVAs, resulting in recommendations to improve the methodology and ultimately enhance analysis and the accuracy of results. This reflects WFP‚Äôs target to strengthen the Government‚Äôs capacities to use SAE where data collection is challenging, and populations are at risk of being left behind. WFP further expanded evidence building on the barriers to the dissemination and utilization of subnational FSVAs through a case study in West Kalimantan province. The study found that in West Kalimantan, the FSVA was utilized by the provincial and district government to inform food security programmes and interventions. However, similar to findings from the 2022 case study in East Nusa Tenggara province, cross-sector utilization remained lacking. Furthermore, the case study identified differing targets and priorities across offices at the sub-national level as the main factor impeding cross-sector utilization of the FSVA. WFP plans to consolidate findings from the case studies to inform efforts in 2024 to enhance FSVA utilization for policymaking, planning, targeting, and resource allocation at the sub-national level.
2024 Narrative: WFP, in partnership with the National Food Agency, refined the methodology of the Food Security and Vulnerability Atlas (FSVA), a key food security planning tool. This refinement bolstered evidence-based government decision making for improved food security policies, programmes, and monitoring. This includes the allocation of two national budgets addressing food security with a combined value of over USD 920 million in 2024: the Ministry of Villages, Development of Disadvantaged Regions‚Äô food security fund and the Food Sector Special Allocation Fund under the Ministry of Agriculture. Through informing policy and programmatic decision-making, the improved FSVA methodology will strengthen the government‚Äôs targeting, reach, and support of populations most vulnerable to food insecurity across Indonesia. At the subnational level, WFP facilitated the launch of a governor decree formalizing FSVA production and utilization in East Nusa Tenggara province. This decree effectively strengthened the FSVA‚Äôs position as a tool to guide and support programs aimed at improving food security in the province. This is a significant achievement for the province, where 19 percent of the sub-districts are food insecure.

SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,3.2 By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.,9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: Overall MERMAID project level: A total of 3,169 beneficiaries were reached (88% of target set at design), of whom 53% women and 51% youth. The grant recipient has addressed implementation issues, by proactively demanding a grant extension and budget reallocation following implementation delays caused by tropical cyclones in March 2023. Regular Project Steering Committees were organized between Grant recipients‚Äô representatives and IFAD‚Äôs Grant Manager, to present progress and discuss challenges. A learning event was jointly attended in September 2023 in Solomon Islands, bringing together the Alliance Bioversity International ‚Äì CIAT as well as the World Vision Vanuatu and Solomon Islands implementation teams. This served to identify key milestones during the program‚Äôs last year of implementation, and identify priority for expert knowledge transfer between the Alliance and World Visions staff on the ground. Physical targets were attained and in some cases exceeded, for instance through the establishment and support to 29 saving groups (161% targets met), or facilitating the participation of 1,282 to market linkage events and exposure visits (237% targets met). In 2023, updated logframe shows 69% women involved in the nutritional behavioural change strategy design, hence including their voice in the decision-making and prioritization process. All targets under Component 2 (Innovations for investing in women) were met or exceeded in 2023. For instance, Agribusiness opportunities were identified (12 compared to 9 set at design); the agribusiness skills training material was developed and the target was exceeded through inclusion of the Basic Numeracy programme to tailor and enhance effectiveness in reaching and empowering women, given the baseline findings and in line with the programme's adaptative management. Targets were also exceeded by 237% with regards to attendees to capacity building sessions, market linkage events, competitions, and exposure visits with 64% women reached. Small grants to women (and youth) are being delivered, and so far 89% of progress has been reached; for instance these include fish cold storage, demonstration farms, poultry, piggeries, coconut processing, duck farming support have been supported through MERMAID, as identified through feasibility assessments and community consultations giving voice to women and youth.

2024 Narrative: To gain interest from young people to work on agriculture as their future career and to foster youth leadership in agrifood system transformation. FAO in close collaboration with Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs, Pramuka and HKTI have developed agriculture education curriculum for Scout and equipped the pilot sites with innovative solution and digital approaches. The first pilot training has been conducted at the Cibubur camping ground site with a total of 38 participants (24 boys, 14 girls). Modelling innovative farming system hub has established which are divided into four (4) different agricultural systems (permaculture, semi-intensive, smart-farming for beginner and smart farming for advance) that include zoning for various agricultural activities such as crop cultivation areas, agroforestry, livestock, fisheries, poultry, composting areas, crop cultivation areas.

2024 Narrative: In 2024, WFP achieved substantial progress in addressing nutrition gaps in Sri Lanka, particularly through the Thriposha program, research, and other capacity development initiatives. For Thriposha, WFP's support in developing a rice-based formula successfully addressed the issue of aflatoxin contamination, which had previously hindered distribution to children under three years of age. This solution was critical in ensuring that Thriposha remained safe and suitable for vulnerable populations, contributing to the program‚Äôs overall success. Additionally, UNSW together with experts from the Wayamba University and University of Peradeniya played a crucial role by supporting the assessment of food safety and operational standards in the Thriposha production process. Further to their research, UNSW provided technical recommendations on the Systems Analysis of Extruder Operations at Thriposha, to improve production quality and efficiency. WFP also worked on improving Suposha‚Äôs market reach through a market study that evaluated domestic and international opportunities for the product, aligning with broader efforts to enhance the complementary food sector.

Dep of Probation and Childcare and UNHCR, set up a protection monitoring system for refugee unaccompanied minors (UAMs).
