2024 Narrative: WFP, together with government stakeholders, launched local fortified rice production. It supported the National Food Promotion Board's capacity and facility improvement to ensure the production of fortified rice targeting schoolchildren in some districts in the country. WFP supported the launch of locally blended fortified rice for school meals in Sri Lanka, demonstrating a direct link between capacity-building efforts and tangible outputs. Through high-level engagements, such as symposia, regional meetings, and strategy development sessions, WFP amplified its influence by sharing expertise and aligning stakeholders on the importance of large-scale fortification. Additionally, partnerships with institutions such as the College of Community Physicians and involvement in global forums extended WFP's impact beyond immediate local settings.

Plan name: UN Socio-Economic Resilience Response Plan
Strategic priority: Social protection and basic social services
Outcome: Households and communities' resilience strengthened and recovery supported through the provision of inclusive social protection measures and basic social services
Output: Essential food and nutrition services delivered in communities most at-risk of food insecurity
Sub-Output: Essential nutrition and food-security interventions continued and expanded.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; United Nations Children's Fund; United Nations Office for Project Services; United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; United Nations Children's Fund; United Nations Office for Project Services; United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and Equitable Human Development and Well-Being
Outcome: Strengthened, Resilient & Equitable Social Service Systems and Enhanced Well-Being
Output: The government and other nutrition system-related stakeholders have strengthened capacities to ensure food system sustainability and to protect and promote diets, services and practices that ensure adequate nutrition for all, particularly the most vulnerable.
Sub-Output: Strengthening household resilience and livelihoods and enhancing food security and nutrition among the most vulnerable households in the context of  2022 economic and food crisis in Sri Lanka (OSRO/SRL/203/NZE)
Description:
To develop 2500 Home Gardens targeting households which have one or more cases of severely malnourished children (-3 SD children between 0-5 years with a less than -3 standard deviation of weight for height.
To provide training to the care givers of these identified 2500 households to improve family dietary habits for better nutrition, including the use of healthy recipes developed using nutritious foods available locally.
To provide locally available nutritious food ingredients (five-grain flour mixture) to supplement diets of these severely malnourished children. The supplemented food will compensate for the household cash shortfall, that would ideally be spent on food and nutritional requirements.

Multiyear project: start date: 9/1/2022
FAO Project Code: OSRO/SRL/203/NZE
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Sri Lanka Ministry of Agriculture; Sri Lanka Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.
Geography: Uva; Monaragala; Nuwara Eliya; Sri Lanka; Central
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Mothers, mother support groups, and caregivers of malnourished children were the primary implementers and beneficiaries of the project, recognizing their central role in household nutrition. In addition to addressing immediate nutritional needs, the project empowered these women by providing them with entrepreneurial opportunities, enabling them to prepare, distribute, and sell the nutritious 5-grain mix introduced through the initiative. This approach not only improved food security but also promoted gender inclusion by equipping women with skills and resources to contribute to their household income and community wellbeing.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The right to access nutritious, safe and affordable food
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: The project was implemented as an emergency response project of FAO. Provided supplementary food for below 5 years old, 2250 malnourished children (SAM - Sevier Acute Malnutrition and MAM - Moderate Acute Malnutrition) in Monaragala and Nuwara Eliya District. Furthermore, mother support groups in each village/area was strengthened by providing equipment (grinders, roast pans) and hands on training on preparation supplementary food using grains. The endline study results marked that in Monaragala 36% children who was in low and moderate IDDS (Individual Dietary Diversity Score) has improved to high IDDS while in Nuwara Eliya 11% who was in low and moderdate IDDS has improved to high IDDS.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and Equitable Human Development and Well-Being
Outcome: Strengthened, Resilient & Equitable Social Service Systems and Enhanced Well-Being
Output: The government and other nutrition system-related stakeholders have strengthened capacities to ensure food system sustainability and to protect and promote diets, services and practices that ensure adequate nutrition for all, particularly the most vulnerable.
Sub-Output: Scale up nutrition-sensitive interventions in social protection and on the food system to facilitate access to healthy diets.
Description:
2023 - 2024: 
1. Develop age-appropriate nutrition sensitive plus component activities focusing on diet and growth monitoring promotion using social and behaviour change communication strategies to be implemented together with the preschool feeding programme and social protection unconditional cash transfers.                                                 
2. Conduct virtual monthly knowledge and experience sharing sessions on nutrition improvement targeting the preschool teacher networks in the provinces.

2025:
1. Develop and implement age-appropriate nutrition-sensitive activities to complement and leverage social protection programmes in order to achieve improved nutritional outcomes
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: Australian National Committee for UNICEF; Government of the United States of America; UN Sri Lanka SDG Multi-Partner Trust Fund; UNICEF Nutrition Thematic Fund; United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Sri Lanka Ministry of Education; Sri Lanka Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Inclusion of women will be considered in this activity and gender-disaggregated data may be collected .However, gender equality perspectives and concerns are not significantly mainstreamed through all activities, so UNCT-GEM 1 applies.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: Given the exceptional vulnerability of young children, UNICEF implemented a short-term nutrition-sensitive cash transfer programme for families with infants and young children in nine districts of Sri Lanka, involving five transfers of cash to more than 114,000 families, combined with a nutrition ‚Äòplus‚Äô component. The nutrition ‚Äòplus‚Äô component involved social behaviour change communication interventions implemented by the government with support from a non-governmental organization. This included targeted home visits, food demonstrations, capacity building on cash management and orientation of combined mechanism officials to enable multisectoral actions that are designed to enhance the impact of cash transfers on maternal and child diets, nutritional knowledge and awareness and uptake of nutrition-relevant public services.
2024 Narrative: In response to Sri Lanka‚Äôs economic crisis, UNICEF implemented a nutrition-sensitive, shock-responsive cash transfer programme reaching over 114,000 households across nine districts with high rates of severe wasting. This programme supported families with children aged 4 to 24 months with a cash transfer of Sri Lankan Rupees 6,750 per month for five months, which aligned with the Government‚Äôs pregnancy voucher programme. To complement this, UNICEF implemented a ‚Äònutrition plus‚Äô component to improve maternal and child diets, nutritional knowledge, and the uptake of nutrition services by enhancing household decision-making regarding diets and care. UNICEF partnered with Sarvodaya, a local civil society organization, and the Ministry of Health‚Äôs Nutrition Division to deliver this component. To further promote nutrition and care practices, UNICEF trained 1,371 community-based volunteers who conducted household visits covering more than 100,000 households that benefitted from the humanitarian cash transfer programme across the nine districts which had the highest prevalence of severe wasting as per Demographic Health Survey 2016 data.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2022 - 2026
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: Inclusive and Sustainable Economic Development
Outcome: Outcome 1: By 2026 people, more people in Bangladesh, particularly the most vulnerable and marginalized from all gender and social groups and those from lagging districts benefit from sustainable livelihood and decent work opportunities resulting from responsible, inclusive, sustainable, green and equitable economic development.
Output: 1.2 Improved opportunity for people of Bangladesh from all gender, ethnicity and socio-economic background seeking employment in country and globally to market driven skills training, productive employment and decent work opportunities including in green sector through employment and labour market policies and regulations
Sub-Output: Equitable access to productive resources, efficient services, and markets for resilient food system
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation; Embassy of the Netherlands; European Union; Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Government of Bangladesh; Government of the Netherlands; International Fund for Agricultural Development; The Global Environment Facility; The Green Climate Fund; The World Bank; UNITED NATIONS JOINT PROGRAMME; United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Bangladesh Ministry of Agriculture; Bangladesh Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Peasants & Rural Workers; Persons With Disabilities; Youth; Women & Girls
2022 Narrative: A) With the support of FAO-MMI, Producer Organizations (POs) established Virtual Call Centres (VCCs) and were able to ensure that their farmer members could continue their day-to-day farming business despite such trying circumstances. In endline survey showed (December 2022), all 55 VCCs were functioning well. Over 10,000 producers have benefitted from the VCCs and 130,611 calls were received for selling products, 56,021 calls for buying inputs, and 36,309 calls for technical advice. Through the VCCs, approximately BDT 82.16 million (approximately USD 766,000) of products were sold and agricultural inputs worth BDT 12.63 million (approximately USD 118,000) were purchased cumulatively. B) - FAO‚Äôs community-based climate-resilient fisheries and aquaculture development in Bangladesh project is piloting climate-resilient fisheries and aquaculture technologies with selected community-based organizations in the South West and North East regions of Bangladesh. In 2022, the project formed 45 CBOs which were supported with aquaculture inputs like fingerlings, fish feeds, etc. This has improved their aquaculture production and contributed to food and livelihood security. This in addition to several trainings that have been provided to the farmers in strengthening sustainable fisheries and aquaculture value chains. The project conducted a total of 43 batch training (for 1290 participants) on Climate-resilient fisheries and aquaculture value chains. 27 government officers were trained in mud crab and 20 government officials were trained in Golda hatchery operations. The project provided flood recovery support to communities following the devastating flood where 3 000 community members received unconditional cash support of BDT 4 500 and 100 fish farmers, 20 in each of the Upazilas, received conditional cash support of BDT 4 500 and inputs support for fish farming-fingerlings, feed, vegetable seed, agricultural equipment, and fishing nets. A working manual on ‚ÄòClimate Resilient Fisheries and Aquaculture was formulated for the training of Government officials and communities on fisheries climate resilience planning and management.C) Renovation of 2 Fresh Markets in DNCC, 10 pilot markets with upgraded waste segregation systems in DSCC in development (2022)
2023 Narrative: FAO developed four videos to use the digital application for sustainable production for farmers, extension agents, and service providers. Bangladesh Agricultural Research Council (BARC) disseminated those videos through their mobile app: Khamari. This crop zoning app is used for smart agriculture, efficient water and fertilizer management, adapting to changing climate for crops and mitigating GHG from agricultural fields
2024 Narrative: Ensuring equitable access to productive resources, efficient services, and markets is critical for building a resilient food system in Bangladesh. The Technical Assistance to the Diversified Resilient Agriculture for Improved Food and Nutrition Security (RAINS-TA) project enhances smallholder farmers‚Äô access to climate-smart technologies, improved seeds, and sustainable farming practices, ensuring that vulnerable groups can actively participate in agricultural value chains. Similarly, the UN Joint-Project SAFE Plus 2 addresses food security and environmental challenges by promoting alternative cooking fuel solutions and sustainable resource management for Rohingya refugees and host communities, reducing dependence on natural forests and improving local livelihoods.

Plan name: UN Socioeconomic and Peacebuilding Framework for COVID-19 Recovery in the Philippines 2020-2023
Strategic priority: People
Outcome: The most marginalized, vulnerable, and at-risk people and groups benefit from more inclusive and quality services and live in more supportive environments where their nutrition, food security, health and life-long learning are ensured and protected.
Output: Output 3: Food and nutrition security enhanced
Sub-Output: Engaging the food and agriculture sectors in sub-Saharan Africa and South and South-east Asia in the global efforts to combat antimicrobial resistance using a One Health approach.
Description: The main outcome from this project is Data generation (AMR specific and sensitive), their analysis, sharing, and utilization for evidence-based decision making within the food and agriculture sector, is increased and improved, and will be achieved through the following outputs: 1)Strengthen laboratory and surveillance capacities and related data management infrastructures of the food and agriculture sector to generate, collect, and share data on AMR, AMC, and antimicrobial residues, and actively contribute to integrated AMR surveillance; 2)Antimicrobial use practices and good practices that reduce AMR transmission along the food chain promoted in food and agriculture; 3) Evidence based AMR economic argument in the food and agriculture sectors developed and documented to support decision making; 4) Antimicrobial policies and governance enhanced to minimize the role of sub-standard and falsified (SF) antimicrobials in food and agriculture and 5) Country owned processes and collaborative initiatives for implementation of multi-sectoral One Health AMR National Action Plans (NAPs) supported
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Philippines Department of Agriculture
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.b Support the research and development of vaccines and medicines for the communicable and non-communicable diseases that primarily affect developing countries, provide access to affordable essential medicines and vaccines, in accordance with the Doha Declaration on the TRIPS Agreement and Public Health, which affirms the right of developing countries to use to the full the provisions in the Agreement on TradeRelated Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights regarding flexibilities to protect public health, and, in particular, provide access to medicines for all.,3.d Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 3 Good Health and Well-being
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective

Conducted awareness campaign in 3 different universities, attended by medicine, veterinary medicine and agriculture students, and students from other related courses.

2021 Narrative:
1. The government food waste reduction measure was achieved with the launch of the National Roadmap on Urban Food Waste Prevention and Reduction for Households, Food services, Retailers, and Wholesalers on 17 August 2021.

2. Two private sector representatives, namely the Dedicated Economic Center and Waters Edge Hotel in Colombo, have measured food waste and implemented, successfully, reduction measures. The report FAO and IWMI, 2021. Case studies on food waste quantification, characterization, and identification of prevention and reduction options in Colombo, Sri Lanka can be consulted.

2023 Narrative: WFP collaborated with national counterparts in five countries (Fiji, Kiribati, Samoa, Tonga and Vanuatu) to collect cross-sectional data through its mobile vulnerability analysis and mapping (mVAM) tool. The mVAM platform provides well-visualized public data for governments, key partners and stakeholders, allowing identification of food security trends for external users. WFP continued with capacity-strengthening support to Government counterparts and strengthened government-led national food security and nutrition monitoring systems by integrating WFP mVAM indicators into national systems.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: PEACE: Ensuring Peace Human Rights, Gender Equality and Participation
Outcome: By 2027, people enjoy and contribute to more accountable, inclusive, resilient and responsive governance systems that promote gender equality, climate security, justice and peace, ensure participation, and protect their human rights.
Output: 4.6.2 Improving knowledge and behaviors related to  gender equality, women economic empowerment, and young people‚Äôs rights to political participation and leadership  within local communities
Sub-Output: FSM 21 [CD.0111] To contribute to the economic development of the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) by focusing on employment creation and the revitalization of local economies, particularly in food, agriculture, and market systems. The project targets enhancing conditions for climate resilience and promoting the sustainable economic inclusion of women.    ‚Äã
Description:
This project aims to contribute to the economic development of the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) by focusing on employment creation and the revitalization of local economies, particularly in food, agriculture, and market systems. The project targets enhancing conditions for climate resilience and promoting the sustainable economic inclusion of women.  The primary outcome (Outcome 1) is to enhance employability and business support for women through the provision of mentoring and financial support to women-owned and women-staffed MSMEs and the enhancement of institutional capacity within the Government of FSM.

‚Äã
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Implementation partners: FSM College of Micronesia; FSM Department of Foreign Affairs; FSM Department of Health and Social Affairs; FSM Department of Resource & Development
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality; 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth; 10 Reduced Inequalities

LNOB groups targeted: Children ; Indigenous Peoples; Migrants; Minorities; Peasants & Rural Workers; Women & Girls; Youth
2023 Narrative: Healthy herd certification program to demonstrate the absence of Brucellosis infection in livestock and residues to antimicrobials in milk has been developed and handed over to General Authority of Veterinary Services. Designed and developed a Plant Gene bank Information System and handed over to IPAS for effective management and seamless information exchange with other gene banks.
2024 Narrative: FAO conducted a survey across 155 selected schools to assess the implementation of the national standard "Requirements for Food Production and Service in General Education Schools, Dormitories, and Kindergartens" (MNS 7005:2023). Based on the findings, FAO provided targeted recommendations to the Ministry of Education to enhance the School Lunch Program. As a direct result, the government increased the school lunch budget, strengthening efforts to improve the quality and accessibility of nutritious meals for students.FAO developed over 100 recipes and techniques to make offal more appealing to young children, enhancing school menus with nutritious and cost-effective options. Through targeted advocacy and engagement, FAO raised awareness among education stakeholders about the nutritional benefits of offal, fostering its integration into school lunch programs. These efforts contribute to sustainable and health-conscious meal planning, ensuring better dietary diversity for students.Promoting Dietary Diversity: To raise public awareness of the benefits of vegetable consumption and stimulate domestic demand for diverse vegetables, FAO translated and printed the Dietary Diversification Handbook in Mongolian. Distributed as a key communication and visibility resource, the handbook provides practical guidance on food production, storage, preparation, and healthy recipes. It specifically supports improved dietary diversity and vegetable consumption among pregnant and breastfeeding women, as well as children aged 6 months to 2 years, contributing to better maternal and child nutrition outcomes.

Plan name: Papua New Guinea United Nations Development Assistance Framework 2018 - 2023
Strategic priority: People
Outcome: Outcome 1.3 - By 2022, people in PNG, especially the most marginalized and vulnerable, increasingly demand and use social and protective services
Output: Output 1.3.2 - PEOPLE OUTPUT B: Availability of equitable access to health, edu, soc. services, protection, food, WASH
Sub-Output: Improving the resilience of food systems and social protection of refugees in Iowara, Western Province, Papua New Guinea
Description: Improve the resilience of food systems and social protection of refugees in Iowara will be implemented at the refugee settlement site known as Iowara in Western Province. The Iowara population comprises of approximately 3,000 refugees and a small host population. Despite the majority of refugees arriving in the 1980s, only a small number have been naturalized. The refugee community has received limited integration support and has been left behind in terms of development due to their refugee status, particularly those who with specific needs/vulnerabilities. The focus will be on improving the resilience of the food systems for the refugee community and the social protection systems for the most vulnerable groups who have been adversely impacted by consecutive crises, including climate hazards, the COVID-19 pandemic and the Ukraine crisis.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Government of Papua New Guinea

While beneficiary targeting at the quarantine centres was determined by the population demographics of returning migrant workers, WFP ensured that gender-disaggregated data was recorded and reported by the cooperating partners. Outcome: By 2022, people in Sri Lanka, especially the vulnerable and marginalised groups of children, youth, women, migrants, elderly and disabled, benefit equitably from dynamic and responsive social protection systems.
Output: Nutrition and Food Security
Sub-Output: Technical assistance to address gaps in food security sensitive forest management in rural communities
Description:
Socioeconomic Advisory Paper
Focus Area 2.2: Maintaining essential food and nutrition services
Recommendation 2.2.3 Reform supply chains for government food programmes ‚Äì e.g. school nutrition - to use locally-sourced foods and feeds, helping to reduce reliance on imported food, stimulate domestic agriculture production and employment, and guard against future food shocks.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Ministry of Forestry
SDG Targets: 2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries
2021 Narrative:
An impact assessment was conducted in two areas, Kahatagasdigiliya, Anuradhapura (dry zone) and Kalawana, Ratnapura (wet zone), to determine the impacts forestry landscape based interventions on food security and livelihoods of the local communities. 
The results presented valuable species and forestry activities that can be promoted to enhance local livelihoods and highlight potential for further forestry development work in both zones. This information also supplemented the development of the road map with evidence-based suggestions for incorporation of food security and nutrition (FSN) into forestry and related initiatives in the broader institutional context of Sri Lanka.
Technical assistance provided for pilot intervention targeting agroforestry through the project. A plant nursery, consisting of a net house, plant house, compost hut and nursery beds, was constructed in Tambuttegama, Anuradhapura with the intention of supporting community livelihoods and promoting related forest nursery activities by the Forest Department. 
Community participants (50) of Kahatagasdigiliya and surrounded areas were trained on home garden improvement and plant nursery management for food and nutritional security and livelihood improvement. A ToT program was conducted for the Forest Department extension officers on home garden and nursery management, tree propagation techniques, with special emphasis on how the extension officers can support the local communities in promoting home gardens, plant nurseries and agroforestry initiatives for food and nutritional security and livelihood improvement.

2021 Narrative:
The project is designed to strengthen and diversify licit livelihoods and counter narcotics by supporting innovative alternative solutions to reduce dependence on opium poppy cultivation in the most affected districts of Kandahar (Arghandab, Dand, Maiwand, Daman, Panjwayee and Zhire districts) and Helmand (Lashkargah, Nad-e-Ali and Nar-e-Siraj) and address food insecurity, livelihoods particularly for the most vulnerable populations.
During the reporting period Jan-June 2022, the project supported 3,631 vulnerable farming families (5,534 women and 5,534 men) that are susceptible to engaging in opium poppy production and trade in the project targeted provinces. The project also supported 31 women headed entrepreneurs with the market linkages. The project provided the target communities improved seeds and fertilizer for cereal, vegetable and saffron production, four-month-old pullets, concentrate feed, drinker, feeder, door and windows for coop construction and backyard poultry farming, hygiene and dairy processing kits, seed and fertilizer for fodder production, tools for stable improvement, medicine and vaccination for animal husbandry and livestock management. The project to address the irrigation needs of the communities has started constructing seven check dams which will provide irrigation water to 240 hectares of land to increase production and productivity of agricultural crops.  
By the end of the project, beneficiaries will have the ability and means to produce enough food for household consumption as well as for sale. This will enable them to stay away from narcotics production and trade.
2022 Narrative: "The project is designed to strengthen and diversify licit livelihoods and counter narcotics by supporting innovative alternative solutions to reduce dependence on opium poppy cultivation in the most affected districts of Kandahar (Arghandab, Dand, Maiwand, Daman, Panjwayee and Zhire districts) and Helmand (Lashkargah, Nad-e-Ali and Nar-e-Siraj) and address food insecurity, livelihoods particularly for the most vulnerable populations.During the reporting period Jan-Dec 2022, the project supported 9068 vulnerable farming households that are susceptible to engaging in opium poppy production and trade in the project targeted provinces. The project also supported 31 women headed entrepreneurs with the market linkages. The project provided the target communities improved seeds and fertilizer for cereal, vegetable and saffron production, four-month-old pullets, concentrate feed, drinker, feeder, door and windows for coop construction for backyard poultry farming, hygiene and dairy processing kits, seed and fertilizer for fodder production, tools for stable improvement, medicine and vaccination for animal husbandry and livestock management. The project to address the irrigation needs of the communities has constructed seven check dams which will provide irrigation water to 240 hectares of land to increase production and productivity of agricultural crops. By the end of the project, beneficiaries will have the ability and means to produce enough food for household consumption as well as for sale. This will enable them to stay away from narcotics production and trade.
2023 Narrative: The project is designed to strengthen and diversify licit livelihoods and counter narcotics by supporting innovative alternative solutions to reduce dependence on opium poppy cultivation in the most affected districts of Kandahar, Helmand, Laghman and Nangarhar and address food insecurity, livelihoods particularly for the most vulnerable populations.During the reporting period Jan-June 2023, the project supported 8,130 vulnerable farming families (56,910 people our of which 50% female) that are susceptible to engaging in opium poppy production and trade in the project targeted provinces. The project also supported 10 women headed entrepreneurs with the market linkages. The project provided the target communities improved seeds and fertilizer for cereal, vegetable and saffron production, four-month-old pullets, concentrate feed, drinker, feeder, door and windows for coop construction and backyard poultry farming, hygiene and dairy processing kits, seed and fertilizer for fodder production, tools for stable improvement, medicine and vaccination for animal husbandry and livestock management.As a result of project inputs and capacity building of the farmers there was a 13% increase in yield of wheat and 8.7% increase in the yield of maize. The backyard poultry women farmers from each farm produced 20 eggs per day 4 of them used for household consumption and surplus sold to the local market at the price of 10 AFN per egg. The project supported veterinary field units to provide health care and extension services for animal husbandry as result the targeted households reported 10% increase in the milk productivity and were linked to the project established milk collection centers to sell the surplus milk.

Plan name: UNSDCF 2023 - 2027
Strategic priority: Basic Social Services
Outcome: Outcome 1: By 2027, the people in Pakistan, especially the most vulnerable and deprived, have increased equitable access to and utilization of quality, sustainable basic social services (BSS).
Output: Output 1.5: Social protection systems and measures are strengthened to provide well-coordinated responses, in an inclusive and shock-responsive manner, to the most deprived and vulnerable populations.
Sub-Output: Facilitating shock responsive livelihoods programmes focusing food security (including through livestock protection and management interventions)
Description:
Facilitating shock-responsive livelihoods programs that focus on food security involves a comprehensive strategy that addresses various aspects of livelihoods and social protection. One key component is livestock protection and management interventions. This involves implementing measures to safeguard the health and well-being of livestock, such as providing vaccinations, improving animal husbandry practices, and establishing early warning systems for disease outbreaks. Additionally, support is given to farmers in managing their livestock effectively, including guidance on breeding, feeding, and ensuring proper shelter.

Another crucial element of the strategy is skills training and entrepreneurship development. This is where ILO will focus on equipping individuals with the necessary skills and knowledge, they can enhance their capacity to earn a sustainable income. Skills training programs can focus on a range of sectors, such as agriculture, handicrafts, or small-scale manufacturing. Additionally, entrepreneurship development initiatives can empower individuals to start their own businesses, providing them with opportunities for income generation and economic resilience.

Furthermore, ILO's strategy will emphasizes the creation of labour-intensive employment opportunities. This involves promoting sectors that have the potential to absorb a large number of workers, such as infrastructure development, construction, or public works projects. By providing employment opportunities, especially during times of shocks or crises, individuals can access income to meet their immediate needs, reducing their vulnerability to food insecurity.

Lastly, the strategy incorporates shock-responsive social protection frameworks. These frameworks aim to provide a safety net for individuals and communities affected by shocks, such as natural disasters or economic downturns. They include mechanisms such as cash transfers, food assistance programs, and social insurance schemes. These social protection measures can help individuals cope with the impacts of shocks, maintain their food security, and mitigate the negative consequences on their livelihoods.

In summary, facilitating shock-responsive livelihoods programs for food security requires a multi-faceted approach. Livestock protection and management interventions ensure the well-being of animals and support farmers in effectively managing their livestock. Skills training and entrepreneurship development equip individuals with the necessary tools to earn a sustainable income. Labor-intensive employment opportunities provide immediate income generation during shocks or crises, while shock-responsive social protection frameworks offer a safety net to mitigate the impacts of shocks on livelihoods. By integrating these strategies, communities can enhance their resilience, ensuring sustainable food security and promoting long-term economic well-being.

LNOB groups targeted: Women & Girls; Persons With Disabilities; Children
2023 Narrative: Working in collaboration with the Department of Samurdhi Development (DSD), WFP provided financial assistance to 2,300 households, representing 9,200 beneficiaries. Each household received electronic vouchers totalling LKR 52,500 spread over three months (monthly voucher value of LKR 17,500) to help them meet their essential needs. In addition, the initiative strengthened the capacity of 25 small retail businesses, through standardizing shops and providing training on retailer business management, digital devices and apps, reimbursement processes, and prefinancing. This voucher program served as a catalyst for transforming the local food system. It not only provided cash support to female-headed micro-retailers but also fostered livelihood opportunities. The project connected different groups involved in rural supply chains, such as Government cooperative societies, farmers, local retailers and social protection beneficiaries. The overarching goal was to enhance food and nutrition outcomes for the most vulnerable populations.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Planet
Outcome: By 2025, environmental sustainability and resilience are mainstreamed as priorities within the national development agenda, across all sectors and levels of society.
Output: Natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems are sustainably managed, adequately protected and conserved for long-term economic and environmental sustainability.
Sub-Output: Integrated landscape management for sustainable food systems, land use and restoration in Sabah, Malaysia
Description: The project is well aligned with the FOLUR impact program approach in working to promote integrated approaches, address negative externalities in production landscapes, and promote deforestation-free supply chains for palm oil at the landscape, jurisdictional, state, national, and transnational (regional) levels. The project components will facilitate the development of integrated landscape management systems in Sabah, with multi-stakeholder collaboration for effective land-use planning and management, building on existing efforts and structures. Conservation and restoration of natural habitats through public-private-community partnerships will leading to enhanced protection of high conservation value (HCV) and high carbon stock (HCS), safeguarding ecosystem services, and providing improved habitat and connectivity for globally significant biodiversity. Promotion of responsible value chains for palm oil and smallholder support will be undertaken through multi-stakeholder engagement at state levels, accelerating the jurisdictional approach in Sabah, and diversifying and improving agricultural practices to improve smallholder livelihoods.
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme
Contributing partners: IDH (the Sustainable Trade Initiative); The Global Environment Facility; United Nations Development Programme; World Wild Fund
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.b Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,12.2 By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.,15.2 By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.,15.3 By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.,15.9 By 2020, integrate ecosystem and biodiversity values into national and local planning, development processes, poverty reduction strategies and accounts.,15.b Mobilize significant resources from all sources and at all levels to finance sustainable forest management and provide adequate incentives to developing countries to advance such management, including for conservation and reforestation.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty; 2 Zero Hunger; 12 Responsible Consumption and Production; 13 Climate Action; 15 Life on Land
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership

2021 Narrative: This outputs respresents the provision of support and assistance to urban refugees in Afghanistan. UNHCR assists a total number of 1,774 individuals with provision of monthly allowance.
2022 Narrative: UNHCR assists a total number of 326 individuals with provision of monthly allowance - all of which are urban refugees.This output includes provision of Core Relief Items (CRIs) to persons of concern to UNHCR. CRI has two components of internationally procured items (Tents, Blankets, plastic sheets, jerry cans, kitchen set‚Ä¶) and locally procurement items (Cooker Gas cylinders, soap, bucket.This output includes provision of Sanitary kits for women as part of UNHCR protection efforts to PoCs. During reporting period a total of 22,169 individuals were assisted from current stock in hand.During the reporting period, a total number of 6,424 individuals returned to AFG under UNHCR's voluntary return programme from neighbourhood countries. The refugee returnees were assisted with the facilitation of return as well as supported by provision of a return cash grant of $250 per individual.
2023 Narrative: Refugee and Asylum Seekers support GBV Cluster support Warehouse Management Border Monitoring GBV Improvement of living environment in the hosting area with Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees in the Southern Afghanistan in sectors of Education, Health, WASH, and    Livelihood.   Livelihood: Construction of health facilities and midwifery training, Construction of water facilities and training on operation and maintenance, construction of education facilities and teachers' trainings, construction of community centers and training on the facility management - in addition to Voluntary Repatriation programme and Persons with Specific Needs.  Shelter and protection need for earthquake affected households in Gardez.   Strengthening and enhancing community-based protection monitoring and providing access to shelter/housing solutions.  To support humanitarian assistance activities in the 2023 Afghanistan Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP).  Provision of business management courses in Kunduz.  Vocational trainings on motorbike repairing, carpentry, and tailoring. Animal husbandry project for men and women heads of households. Construction and rehabilitation of shelter needs in Farah, Jawzjan, and Sar-e-Paul provinces, through major/minor repair and transitional shelter. 2021 Narrative: Cancelled
2022 Narrative: The project focused on addressing a major gap identified in the current local food system, which is lack of quality seed production to support farmers obtain high yields and balance the price escalation of essential commodities.   Introduced pilot scale interventions of quality seed production and technologies such as protected houses, rain shelters, and micro irrigation systems for better crop management to increase the human and infrastructural capacity with improving availability of quality seeds, which are high cost, particularly chili, big onion, red onion and soybean. Farms of the DoA and other individuals through PPPs will be utilized for this purpose. Produced seeds will be certified by seed certification division of the DoA.   Introduced post-harvest management practices and small-scale packing methods to inhibit germination to farmers. Quality produce can always assure a premium price. The present customer ponder quality and safety of the food they consume. Hence, project focused on crop establishment, weed management, insect pest and diseases management to implement as per the DOA recommendations. Furthermore, the small-scale packing systems will introduce to farmers to avoid germination until commodities reach customers.

2022 Narrative: The Joint Food Security Initiative partnered with the FAO, identified 4,225 households affected by the compounded pandemic and economic downturn to receive cash assistance through social protection mechanism, and improve shock resilience of the most vulnerable Sri Lankan population (e.g., pregnant or nourishing mothers, children under 5 and persons with disabilities). Additionally, to complement the various cash assistance programmes, WFP collaborated with the Scaling Up Nutrition People's Forum (SUN PF) to conduct awareness raising sessions on nutrition, gender, domestic cash management and Social Behavior Change Communication (SBCC) with the aim of sensitizing beneficiaries on good gender and nutrition standard practices.

2023 Narrative: A support facility for citizens and private sector was established by the country office to respond to the socio-economic crisis with a primary goal of mobilizing resources towards procuring essential medical supplies and enhancing food security. The support facility successfully garnered support from over a dozen prominent private sector organizations, foundations and three (3) vital development partners. Collaborative efforts with key stakeholders including Ministry of Health, FAO and WHO further solidified the impact. This unified approach resulted in raising over USD 6 million and was utilized to provide critical support to 200,000 individuals in the medical sector and approximately 50,000 beneficiaries on food security. This collaborative engagement has enabled UNDP to act as a dependable, responsive and an innovative partner during critical times.Considering the success of this engagement, the Country Office is actively pursuing towards establishing a new iteration facility, considering significant scope and need towards fortify development efforts despite current country stability.

Description: NAMAC (National Association of Mongolian Agricultural Cooperatives) provides support to establish and strengthen rural cooperatives. Support activities include training courses and advisory services in organizational, business plan and loan application development, technical assistance, agricultural advocacy, and linking members with national and international stakeholders, projects, and programs. 2023 Narrative: For the year 2023, a total of 10 Farmers‚Äô Organizations/Cooperatives (FOs) were supported by the ARISE Program directly benefitting 1,970 members. From the revolving fund level of USD 181,380, NAMAC was able to revolved the funds 3 times resulting to a total disbursement of USD 426,386. The funds were used by the FOs are working capital to aggregate and market the products from the members. NAMAC was able to recover 100% of the funds from the FOs.
2024 Narrative: NAMAC is the national implementing agency (NIA) for the ARISE RECOVERABLE GRANT to be utilized by Farmers‚Äô organization FOs to support their longterm resiliency by financing innovative 4Ps projects. The NIA uses the recoverable grant proceeds solely to (i) provide sub-recoverable grants toFOs, which shall in turn extend subsidized/soft loans to eligible beneficiaries; and (ii) directly issue subsidized/soft loans to farmer cooperatives. In 2024, 10 farmers/herders' cooperatives were supported by the ARISE program, revolving in three agricultural production seasons. Altogether 1,121 farmers and herders benefitted from the recoverable fund, in which 360 are women and 268 are youth.

Gender marker narrative: FAO - The project aims to identify and strengthen socially inclusive institutional models for value chain development to integrate non-bovine smallholders, particularly women. It will provide policy recommendations to the government for mainstreaming non-bovine livestock keepers, especially women involved with small ruminants. The project will also focus on creating an enabling entrepreneurial ecosystem and raising awareness through publicity campaigns on the nutritional and therapeutic benefits of non-bovine milk.

2023 Narrative: WFP: Working with a group of National and International experts on fortified rice, WFP compiled evidence on the impact of fortified rice in the Asian context and studied the safety of consumption of fortified rice in patients of haemoglobinopathies. WFP also supported a financial analysis of the decentralised production of take-home-rations in UP-basis which additional funds were assigned by Government of Uttar Pradesh to sustain provision of nutritious and quality assured take home rations.----UNICEF: The states of Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Telangana, and Uttar Pradesh mobilized almost USD 80 million for nutrition priorities around diets, services, and practices.Building on UNICEF‚Äôs support to adapt global recommendations for managing early growth faltering to the Indian context in 2021-22, 10 out of 12 UNICEF-supported states-initiated programming in 22 districts to demonstrate operational feasibility.Jointly with the social protection section, UNICEF undertook a mapping of the social protection for nutrition (SP4N) schemes in India. Learnings from the Vidisha district in Madhya Pradesh successful integrated algorithmic approach to antenatal nutrition services. It was expanded to Jharkhand, and Telangana and Uttar Pradesh issued a detailed integrated high nutritionally at-risk pregnancy management protocols.Ôªø
2024 Narrative: WFP:Working with National experts across premier medical colleges and nutrition institutes of the country, WFP supported successful advocacy for removal of disclaimer around safety of fortified rice for patients with thalassemia and sickle cell anaemia. The state government of Uttar Pradesh approved an additional budget of USD 31.5 million (INR 262 crores) to ensure the continued provision of a nutritious and quality assured take home ration basis advocacy and inputs from WFP. WFP completed a comprehensive study to map the menus offered across the nation under the PM POSHAN scheme including their assessment through a nutritional lens. The study records the diverse practices in meal planning, preparation, and distribution and, offers well-informed recommendations for enhancing menu diversity and nutritional value.UNICEF:UNICEF is closely working with Public Health Foundation on India (PHFI), ICMR-NIN, Institute of Economic Growth (IEG), Lady Irwin College, International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) to develop a national Nutrition Strategy for NITI Aayog. In 2024, UNICEF built upon the work initiated in 2023 under its new Country Program 2023/27. Differential and innovative programming driven by state various contexts and budgets was successfully attempted by many states. The equity focus was applied in Maharashtra where UNICEF‚Äôs technical support resulted in the government going beyond the ECD agenda to launch a special flagship program, Vatsalya (Nurturing), focusing on the continuum of care from pre-conception to two years of age and targeting tribal, urban and climate-impacted districts. Maharashtra mobilized USD 280,000 for this new initiative from domestic funds while also leveraging USD 3.25 million for the ongoing ECD program. Similarly, UNICEF Chhattisgarh invested in strengthening the capacities of local NGOs working in tribal and Left-Wing Extremist-affected districts to support ground level implementation of nutrition programs, thus using partnerships to expand program coverage in pockets of geographic inequities. A total of USD 110,000 was also leveraged through Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) to support nutrition initiatives across the state. In Odisha, UNICEF worked with DoWCD to facilitate four state-level multisectoral meetings with the aim of strengthening the quality of Growth Monitoring and Promotion. An additional USD 2.9 million was leveraged from domestic funding to support this initiative. In Rajasthan, UNICEF worked with partners to support the design and demonstration of an innovative, low-cost, and replicable capacity-building initiative, the Advanced Training and Learning (ATaL) project in 13 districts.With support from UNICEF, Assam established its first multisectoral state core committee on nutrition resulting in the release of operational guidelines for district nutrition committee meetings.In Bihar, UNICEF supported the development of State Convergent Action Plan as part of which capacities of local governance bodies was built on nutrition. In Uttar Pradesh, UNICEF successfully advocated and leveraged USD 193,000 from MoWCD for training supervisory cadre.

Description: To enhance the socio-economic well-being and food security of rural communities in Sri Lanka through the sustainable development of inland fisheries. This will be achieved by improving fish seed production, increasing fish fingerling stocking, enhancing reservoir fisheries management, and expanding market opportunities. The project aims to build technical capacities, integrate environmentally sustainable practices, and promote gender equality and inclusivity in all aspects of fisheries development. By leveraging innovative technologies and best practices, the objective is to establish a self-sustained, climate-resilient, and community-driven inland fisheries sector that contributes to the national goal of reducing poverty and ensuring nutritional security.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.
Geography: Ratnapura; Sabaragamuwa; Eastern; Matale; Uva; Sri Lanka; Northern; Central; Anuradhapura; Kilinochchi; Monaragala; North Central; Batticaloa; Ampara; Mullaitivu
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance

Gender marker narrative: The results of this initiative cannot be measured / no gender sensitive indicators.
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: The project activities commenced in March 2024.The construction of four mini hatcheries for inland fisheries began in Batticaloa, Monaragala, Mullaitivu, and Anuradhapura. Simultaneously, the renovation of five hatcheries operated by NAQDA in Udawalawa, Ampara, Kilinochchi, and Matale also commenced. These construction and renovation activities are planned to complete in 2025.To enhance fisheries management and productivity, the project has engaged 28 reservoir-based fisheries associations across five districts: Anuradhapura, Ampara, Monaragala, Mullaitivu, and Vavuniya. Through these associations, over 1,375 inland fishers will be engaged as beneficiaries, with the initiative focusing on improving fisheries management practices and strengthening financial management skills to boost productivity and livelihoods.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and Equitable Human Development and Well-Being
Outcome: Sustainable and Inclusive, Green-Led Growth, People-Centred Economic Recovery, Livelihoods and Productivity
Output: The government in partnership with the private sector, trade unions/producers‚Äô organizations, women, youth, and other stakeholders demonstrate strengthened capacity and commitment to implement transformational economic strategies that support sustainable, green and gender-responsive economic recovery, growth and decent work.
Sub-Output: Support to promoting investment in agri-food system transformation in Sri Lanka under the framework of Hand-in-Hand Initiative
Description:
The Hand-in-Hand Initiative (HIH), launched in 2019 by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), is a targeted intervention aimed at supporting the transformation of agri-food systems, food security, and rural development in countries facing significant challenges. It can provide solutions to a lower-middle-income country like Sri Lanka that seeks to mobilize resources available most-efficiently. 
The HIH is designed to address poverty reduction and is intrinsically linked to agri-food investment in several ways: 
‚Ä¢	Territorial approach: By identifying specific geographic and sectoral areas where the impact can be maximized, the initiative helps direct investments to where they are most needed. 
‚Ä¢	Enhancing Productivity: Investments under this initiative aim to modernize agriculture through technology and innovation, thus enhancing productivity and sustainability. 
‚Ä¢	Market Access: Improving infrastructure and logistics to provide farmers better access to markets is a key component, thus increasing their potential revenue and investment returns. 
‚Ä¢	Capacity Building: The initiative invests in training and equipping local communities and governments to manage agricultural projects effectively, ensuring long-term sustainability.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
SDG Targets: 2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries

2024 Narrative: WFP supported Nepal's delegation, led by the Prime Minister, to attend the UN Food Systems Summit+2 in Rome, reaffirming Nepal's commitment to transforming food systems, including the national school feeding program. With WFP's support, the National Planning Commission integrated food systems actions into annual planning and budgets, and four additional provinces established Food Councils under the Right to Food and Food Sovereignty Act. WFP also assisted in operationalizing the Food Systems Steering Committee and Action Track Groups. Pilot localization of food systems actions in seven local governments led to two creating 5-year strategic plans, with the remaining five planning to develop theirs in 2024. Additionally, WFP conducted training on Right to Food and Food Systems Strategic Planning for provincial and local governments, enhancing their understanding of food systems.
