2023 Narrative: WFP: Leveraging different modes of communication, WFP facilitated knowledge, attitudes, and practices enhancement on the importance of fortified rice, take home rations for young children, nutrition among school children and food safety/hygiene among cook cum helpers attached to government schools.-----UNICEF: In 2023, to support NRLM, UNICEF actively contributed to strengthening SBC in FNHW program resulting in 13 states having costed SBC action plans. This led to strengthening implementation of Standard Operating Procedures resulting in increased discussions on nutrition behaviors engaging 88,000 Self-Help Groups (SHGs). UNICEF supported partnerships with community radios, faith-based organizations, and SBC alliances (Assam, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, and Madhya Pradesh) to amplify priority nutrition messages during national nutrition events ‚ÄòPoshan Maah‚Äô, ‚ÄòPoshan Pakhwada‚Äô (nutrition month and fortnight), and national gender campaigns. 67,400 UNICEF trained National Service Scheme (NSS) volunteers facilitated 5,194 community events resulting improved knowledge on healthy diets and IFA compliance for adolescents. To strengthen results around strategic communication, technical support was extended to improve the effectiveness of national campaigns like Poshan Maah and Poshan Pakhwada in 13 states. Community Radio partners in Assam, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Rajasthan reached 5.5 million people in vulnerable communities with knowledge on first 1,000 days, Early Childhood Development (ECD), and healthy diets. Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Telangana, and Chhattisgarh shifted beyond traditional frontline functionaries resulting in involvement of youth networks for intensive promotion of nutrition literacy reaching 5 million people. UNICEF conceptualized and supported two campaigns, enhancing breastfeeding practices and "Raise above 12" launched in Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka reaching 1,484 million people. Towards awareness generation, UNICEF Jharkhand supported outreach through LED vans resulting in 95,000 Community Based Events (CBEs) and development an adolescent mascot ‚Äì ‚ÄòKuni‚Äô in Odisha that informed adolescents on anemia and healthy diets. In Uttar Pradesh, 67,000 panchayat sahayaks were capacitated resulting in engagement of 100,000 households to promote nutrition behaviors using Poshan Tastari, a diverse diet communication tool in local language.-----WHO: Training of Trainers (ToT) programmes for around 100 master trainers (MTs) on Good Hygiene Practices (GHP), Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) and food safety (Sanitary and phytosanitary for selected spices were conducted, subsequently ensuring the delivery of training sessions to approximately 1 700 targeted farmers and 200 other stakeholders in spice value chain.FAO: FAO collaborated with Digital Green Trust, for Digital Extension for Strengthening Spice Value Chain in India. This collaboration marks a significant step towards integrating advanced digital solutions with traditional agricultural practices, aimed at enhancing the productivity, sustainability, and profitability of the spice sector. FAO Collaborated with the ICMR -National Institute of Nutrition, MoHFW to develop a concept note for strengthening nutrition-sensitive agriculture for piloting the ENACT programme in India.-----WHO: Leading the agenda to deliver safer food across population, protect consumer health and ensure fair practices in the food trade through implementation of strong food standards in India, WHO India in collaboration with the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) conducted social media campaign was conducted on YouTube, Instagram and Facebook in collaboration with the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) on World Food Safety Day 2023. The campaign reached 147 million target audience creating 617 million impressions for the different social media creatives.ÔªøA cross-sectional PAN India survey was undertaken across the population in collaboration with FSSAI to understand gaps in knowledge and practices on food safety and related standards given that unsafe practices across the food supply chain makes food safety a critical issue in India. The findings will be used to inform communication efforts to promote food safety.
2024 Narrative: WFP:WFP reached more than 5400 targeted beneficiaries with one-to-one counselling approaches, and 3710 group sessions organized at Anganwadi Centres on appropriate infant and young child feeding practices and the role of THR within the same in Rajasthan. More than 40 million beneficiaries of the different food based safety nets were reached through mass media, street plays and a series of other engaging activities such as cooking demonstrations to dispel various myths and misconceptions on fortified rice in the states of Bihar, Assam and Chhattisgarh.Focusing on school children in adopting and sustaining improved nutrition, health, and hygiene-related practices in school and their daily life. World Food Programme developed different SBCC materials on nutrition, Health, and hygiene to be used through playful methods with school children. In 2024, the SBCC activities were conducted in 2600 schools with approx. 103000 children. During September‚Äô24, Poshan Maah was celebrated in schools through different activities with focus on nutrition, health and hygienic practices. The activities were celebrated in more than 1000 schools covering 64,904 school children, 3,468 teachers, 1,387 school cooks and 2,892 community members. The activities included rallies in village, pledge taking by children, group discussion on health and hygiene, slogan making etc.UNICEF:UNICEF engaged in strengthening peer-to-peer nutrition counselling under the leadership of the Ministry of Rural Development (MoRD) via its National Rural Livelihood Mission (NRLM). Results from four regional meetings, one expert consultation and one national conclave, were used to realign Social and Behavior Change (SBC) in the National Food, Health, Nutrition and WASH (FNHW) strategy and its implementation. A ‚ÄúGender for Nutrition‚Äù guidance focusing on male engagement to change social norms around child feeding was created and shared in 34 states with relevant guidance and materials. To strengthen the integration of FNHW strategy across sectors, a joint advisory group comprising NRLM, Ministry of Women and Child Development (MoWCD), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), and others key stakeholders was set-up. This translated in capacity strengthening of 1,589 state resource persons and 34 national resource persons to support realigned implementation of FNHW nationwide. Over 200 Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) and academic partners of ‚ÄúPoshan Ghar‚Äù were engaged in six national campaigns on nutrition literacy and healthy diets through an Artificial Intelligence-generated family of three mascots. A total of seven newsletters were disseminated featuring success stories on SBC for nutrition as well as four open editorials, two podcasts and nutrition meets in different states. In Chhattisgarh, youth-led initiatives in 16 districts reached 675,000 people with messages on healthy diets and anemia prevention. About 200,000 households in tribal districts were reached through community-based programs (‚ÄúPotth Laika‚Äù and ‚ÄúBaapi Na Uwaat‚Äù). Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan developed and rolled-out state SBC guidelines including CBEs tools and templates for transformative men engagement in alignment with the ‚ÄúPurush Bane Zimmedar‚Äù initiative under POSHAN 2.0. In Assam, 26,355 adolescents (20,514 girls and 5,841 boys) were reached through Adolescent Friendly Centers established in 205 tea gardens. Government in six states supported BIU to conduct behavioral studies in collaboration with UNICEF. Results are being used to develop culturally adapted solutions to nutritional behavior barriers focusing on diet diversity for complementary feeding, maternal nutrition and Iron-Folic Acid supplementation.FAO:FAO contributed to strengthening nutrition education and food safety practices through two key interventions: the piloting of the ENACT course in academic institutions and capacity building in the spices value chain.To promote nutrition education and healthy diets, FAO collaborated with the Indian Council of Medical Research ‚Äì National Institute of Nutrition (ICMR-NIN) and other academic institutions to pilot the Education for Effective Nutrition in Action (ENACT) course in India. The course materials have undergone expert review and are being finalised for rollout. Once implemented, ENACT will help develop a cadre of trained professionals equipped to integrate nutrition education into food systems and community-level interventions, aligning with national goals for healthier diets and nutrition-sensitive agriculture.In parallel, FAO implemented a comprehensive spices value chain project to build knowledge and awareness on food safety and hygienic handling practices. Over 1,700 farmers (including 535 women) and 200 value chain stakeholders‚Äîsuch as FPO representatives, exporters, traders, and government officials‚Äîacross Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, and Rajasthan were trained on Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) and Good Hygienic Practices (GHP). The training was delivered through in-person sessions, group activities, refresher courses, and exposure visits.To scale outreach, FAO developed 60 short training videos in Hindi, Gujarati, and Telugu focused on safe and hygienic spice production (cumin, coriander, fennel, and black pepper). These videos, tailored to local contexts, reached over 6,000 farmers‚Äîincluding 300 women‚Äîand are being integrated into the Ministry of Agriculture‚Äôs VISTAAR mobile application to ensure long-term accessibility. Over 96% of participants found the trainings highly useful.These initiatives not only strengthened knowledge on food safety and healthy diets but also enhanced digital literacy and market linkages, ensuring that smallholders‚Äîparticularly women‚Äîare better equipped to adopt nutrition-sensitive agricultural practices.WHO: WHO supported the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI), MoHFW to revise their national regulation defining compositional and marketing/promotion standards for infant foods to align them with the latest WHO recommendations on nutrient profile and promotion standards with the primary aim to improve the nutritional quality of these foods to promote healthy diet and end inappropriate promotion of food products meant for older infants and young children. The technical support aimed to strengthen regulatory landscape to ensure that no misleading health and nutrition claims are used by manufacturers to market their products as healthy while simultaneously pushing them to reformulate their products to reduce the energy, sugar, fat and sodium content.To support implementation of the WHO global sodium benchmarks in India in combination with policies aiming to reduce discretionary sodium intake, WHO India generated evidence for policy making and published it as a paper titled ‚ÄúEstimated benefits and risks of lowering sodium through potassium-enriched salt substitution in India‚Äù and ‚ÄúEstimated health benefits, costs, and cost-effectiveness of implementing WHO‚Äôs sodium benchmarks for packaged foods in India: a modelling study‚Äù in reputed journals including Lancet Public Health. This will help inform policy makers in the design, planning, and implementation of relevant policies on use of low sodium salt substitutes at population level for prevention/management of hypertension. These publications were widely covered in media and have been a great advocacy tool with the government.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2022 - 2026
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2: Equitable Human Development and Well Being
Outcome: Outcome 2: By 2026, more people, in particular, the most vulnerable and marginalized, have improved access to and utilization of quality, inclusive, gender- and shock-responsive, universal, and resilient social protection, social safety-net and basic social services.
Output: 2.1 Improved availability, utilisation of, and access to quality, gender responsive, equitable services and nutritious safe diets for people across the life cycle, in particular the most vulnerable in both urban and rural areas, including in emergencies
Sub-Output: Support national institutions to strengthen their capacity to design and implement inclusive and nutrition- and gender-sensitive safety net programmes in urban and rural areas (e.g. MCBP, WVB, school feeding program), including appropriate targeting, transfer modalities, nutrition SBCC and linkage to complementary services and improving private sector commitment to enhance availability, access and consumer awareness about safe and nutritious food to meet the nutrition needs of women, children and vulnerable groups including emergency crisis response
Description: Strengthen national institution's  capacity to design and implement inclusive nutrition- and gender-sensitive safety net programmes in urban and rural areas (e.g. MCBP, WVB, school feeding program) to meet the nutrition needs of women, children and vulnerable groups including emergency crisis response, by enhancing availability, access and consumer awareness about safe and nutritious food through appropriate targeting, transfer modalities, nutrition SBCC and linkage to complementary services and improving private sector commitment.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade ; Embassy of Sweden; World Food Programme Multilateral Fund
Implementation partners: Bangladesh Cabinet Division; Bangladesh Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief; Bangladesh Ministry of Health and Family Welfare; Bangladesh Ministry of Industries; Bangladesh Ministry of Primary and Mass Education; Bangladesh Ministry of Women and Children Affairs
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
Geography: Mymensingh; Khulna; Dhaka; Sylhet; Chittagong; Barisal; Rangpur; Bangladesh
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: Organized and technically supported the training on Basic nutrition and nutrition sensitive programing  for 67 GoB officials from 22 ministries at both central and sub national level under the leadership of Cabinet Division where BNNC, NNS and INFS were the lead facilitators. - 422Community workers received training on nutrition in Cox‚Äôs bazar to implement nutrition programs for host community arranged by WFP . -11103 PLWs from host community  received nutrition counseling at the community center in Cox‚Äôs bazar supported.-WFP has supported 34752 children 6-59 months and  PLWs for malnutrition treatment services in cox‚Äôs bazar ( host) community.-WFP  Provided technical support to the food security cluster to revise the food security response package.
2023 Narrative: WFP: 1) District-level sensitization workshop on Nutrition and nutrition-sensitive programming in 7 districts. The workshop covered 436 participants at District, Upazila and Union officials to develop the annual work plan and quality implementation of nutrition related activities. 2)Provided technical and coordination support to the BNNC and Cabinet division to organize a sensitization session on nutrition commitments made by the Honourable Prime Minister at the Nutrition for Growth Summit. The session was conducted in 11 ministries, and high officials, including the secretary of each respective ministry, were made aware of the commitments. In total, there were 440 participants. 3) Maternal and child nutrition training (ToT) for officials from the Mother and Child Benefit Program from the Department of Women Affairs (total 40) to implement nutrition SBCC for safety net beneficiaries.
2024 Narrative: WFP: 1) A nutrition SMART survey has been conducted at Sylhet division (covering all district) to know the current food security and nutrition status and actual geographical difference in this division aim to inform future programming to reach most vulnerable people in this area. A report has been finalized and disseminated. 2) In 2024,WFP embarked on the development of a comprehensive SBCC strategy to support the WFP‚Äôs Country Strategic Plan to positively influence nutrition outcomes for children, women, families and vulnerable communities. 3) A formative research has been conducted to assess households' understanding of healthy eating, hygiene, and nutrition across life stages. The research mapped the "food journey" in Bangladeshi households, from purchase to consumption, identifying key decision-makers and influencers, focusing on gender dynamics and the role of children and adolescents in shaping dietary choices. An important element also involved a semi-ethnographic study aimed at uncovering key cultural codes that can be used to shape food practices, social interactions, and cultural identities around nutrition.

2023 Narrative: FAO collaborated with WFP, UNICEF and IFAD in implementing a Joint Programme under Development Emergency Modality ‚Äì Response to the Global Crisis on Food, Energy, Finance (Assessing and Strengthening Food Security in Bangladesh project). Under this project, FAO and WFP undertook an analysis of the impacts of the 5F crisis (food-feed-fertilizer-fuel-finance), Integrated Food Security Phase Classification, and assessments to develop targeting criteria for public food distribution systems for the urban poor.Local Consultative Group Working Group for Agriculture, Food Security, and Rural Development was established through the collaborative effort of FAO and the Ministry of Agriculture and received assistance in mobilizing a substantial amount of USD 543 million for agricultural transformation strategies.
2024 Narrative: FAO collaborated with WFP, UNICEF, and IFAD to implement a Joint Programme under the Development Emergency Modality ‚Äì Response to the Global Crisis on Food, Energy, and Finance through the Assessing and Strengthening Food Security in Bangladesh project. As part of this initiative, FAO and WFP conducted an in-depth analysis of the 5F crisis (food, feed, fertilizer, fuel, and finance), applied the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC), and carried out assessments to develop targeting criteria for public food distribution systems aimed at supporting the urban poor.

2022 Narrative: ¬∑      At the start of 2022, TADs (FMD, PPR, LSD) outbreaks occurred in different regions of Mongolia. Through joint project with World Bank, FAO provided technical assistance to the government/GAVS to address the situation in a professional way, focusing on improving GAVS capacity on transparency by providing support to develop a Risk-Communication strategy and conducting on-the-job training for communication. ¬∑      FAO provided lead technical support in developing FMD strategy (2021-2024); PPR strategy (2022-2030); Contingency plan and Preparedness plan and all are approved by the government.  ¬∑      To strengthen animal health delivery systems and institutions including policy and legislation, developed a capacity development plan for GAVS personnel and trainings were conducted accordingly. ¬∑      The assessment was done on the perceived gaps and needs in the Animal Health Law (2018) and looked into the alignment of this law and its regulations with international standards. In addition, upon request from GAVS and MoFALI, the review has been carried out on a number of other laws and regulations (veterinary drug law, animal health insurance law, national security law). A g draft including proposed amendments is under preparation. A series of consultation workshops were conducted to set priorities for further amendments and legal advice support. ¬∑      GAVS was assisted in reviewing and implementing recommendations from assessments (WHO-JEE, OIE-PVS, FAO-EMT) to strengthen veterinary services and a high-level TAD strategy. ¬∑      Continued support has been provided to the development and implementation of Mongolia One Health plan including key activities such as organization of the Tripartite National Bridging Workshop (NBW) that resulted in development of the Roadmap on One Health for Mongolia defining 15 objectives in 6 technical areas; a pilot study on testing herds for Brucellosis by sampling 894 herds in two soums and herders and local vets. This herd level approach was recognized well by the government and FAO is requested to provide continued support in this regard and assist one aimag to pursue Brucellosis-free herd certification.

Sub-Output: Enhance the sustainable utilization of fisheries and aquaculture products and its contribution to livelihoods and food security (Component 5) (GCP/GLO/352/NOR BABY05)
Description:
Project will enhance the sustainable utilization of fisheries and aquaculture products and its contribution to livelihoods and food security through the application of multi-dimensional solutions to reduce FLW in fish value chains. FLW is a manifestation of poorly functioning food systems. It is widely recognized that significant levels of FLW occur in the food supply chain from production to consumption. Although underlying many fish loss and waste issues is quality and spoilage, solutions to FLW are wide ranging, complex and interlinked. Informed decision making regarding solutions to FLW in fish value chains is hampered by a lack of robust evidenced based data particularly on the impact of interventions/solutions. Through the activities proposed, the project will contribute to addressing this knowledge need.

FAO Project Code: GCP/GLO/352/NOR BABY05
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Sri Lanka Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Gender marker narrative: The results of this initiative cannot be measured / no gender sensitive indicators.
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: Fisheries value chain stakeholder working group was established with members from 19 organizations covering fisheries sector, health sector, finance institutions, academia, fish exporters, NGOs and fishing community based associations.Food loss and waste (FLW) assessment for fisheries value chain was conducted and identified key points of major FLW. Multiday fisheries FLW assessment was further carried out covering all the 23 fishery harbours in Sri Lanka. Average 42% quality loss was reported in the results and the figure will be marked as the national figure by the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources.
2024 Narrative: The project aimed to tackle critical challenges in the fisheries sector, enhancing sustainability, reducing food loss and waste (FLW), and improving livelihoods through innovative and multidimensional strategies.Key Achievements:AI Maluwa Application for Yellowfin Tuna Grading: Designed, developed, and successfully launched the AI Maluwa application to automate and standardize Yellowfin Tuna (YFT) grading, enhancing efficiency and reducing post-harvest losses. This will be expanded for other varieties based on the testing results.Demonstration of Sustainable Fishing Practices: Installed an energy-efficient cooling system integrated with a bulbous bow on marine multiday boats, serving as a model for sustainable fishing operations.Enhanced Public Awareness:Produced and telecasted nine educational video documentaries on national television (Rupavahini), addressing FLW reduction, fish quality improvement, and energy efficiency.Established a digital screen at the Peliyagoda Central Fish Market to disseminate key messages and information to the public.Capacity Building and Resource Development:Published and distributed 250 marine food fish identification books to the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (DFAR), supporting better resource management.Trained 64 fisheries officers (22% female participation) and 271 fishers/skippers (7% female participation), enhancing their technical knowledge on sustainable practices.Policy Development: Drafted fish handling regulations to institutionalize best practices and ensure compliance with sustainability standards.

A business development plan was produced to scale up the new cooling system technology to other multiday boats. Plan name: UN Socio-Economic Resilience Response Plan
Strategic priority: Economic resilience and recovery
Outcome: Households, communities and MSMEs are better able to withstand the adverse economic impacts of the crisis and recover when conditions allow, through the promotion of gender-responsive employment, private sector and climatic resilience mitigations.
Output: Rural communities and agri-food value chains become more resilient through suport to their prductive assets, provision of inputs and promotion of adaptive agricultural and food processing methods
Sub-Output: Vulnerable rural households received cash and non-cash support to increase food production and income
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; United Nations Capital Development Fund; United Nations Development Programme; United Nations Office for Project Services; United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; United Nations Capital Development Fund; United Nations Development Programme; United Nations Office for Project Services; United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,3.d Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.,15.1 By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.

Gender marker narrative: WFP's capacity-strengthening initiatives under the TPDS empower government officials to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of its implementation and daily operations. This support not only streamlines the distribution of essential commodities but also indirectly benefits women by alleviating household management burdens. By ensuring timely and transparent delivery of food grains, the initiative strengthens food security, empowering women as primary household managers. Moreover, the improvements in TPDS contribute to women's socio-economic empowerment, enabling them to dedicate more time to other productive and decision-making roles within their families and communities
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Peasants & Rural Workers; Youth; Women & Girls; Children
2023 Narrative: WFP: To support enhancement of Government policy, WFP presented evidence from pilots that led to national level policy changes. Based on the success of Supply chain optimisation pilots by WFP, the Government of India introduced a new national policy in 2023 that mandates all the States to undertake TPDS supply chain optimisation as a precondition to claim their transportation costs. Similarly, building upon the SMART warehouse pilot of WFP, the Government of India created a new Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for SMART warehouses and instructed government storage agencies to scale-up SMART warehouse solutions in the warehouses that store food grains for a long period.---FAO: FAO organized a roundtable discussion on ‚ÄòEnhancing livestock keepers‚Äô income through certification for milk and dairy products to increase market access‚Äô in November 2023 in collaboration with the Ministry of Fisheries, Animal Husbandry  Dairying (MoFAHD), Government of India. The discussion was aimed to deliberate on pointers for devising a road map and strategy for the development of standards and protocols for clean and safe milk.The roundtable discussion brought together relevant stakeholders and individuals from the ministry and the dairy industry from across the country. It was attended by senior representatives from the MoFAHD, Department of Animal Husbandry  Veterinary Services, Government of Sikkim, Feed  Fodder Division, MoFAHD, the National Dairy Development Board (NDDB), Gujarat Co-operative Milk Marketing Federation Ltd, Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI), ICAR-Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI), and from milk producer organizations from Kerala, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal, and Rajasthan.
2024 Narrative: WFP:To support enhancement of Government policy, WFP presented evidence from pilots that led to national level policy changes. The Government of India introduced a new national policy in 2023 that mandates all the States to undertake TPDS supply chain optimisation as a precondition to claim their transportation costs, to support the policy WFP completed SCO for All states in 2024, and GOI launched Anna Chakra the tool developed by WFP in collaboration with IIT Delhi, tool uses advanced algorithms and AI to streamline the distribution of food grains, integrating with platforms such as PM Gati Shakti and Railways' Freight Operations Information System. Similarly, building upon the SMART warehouse pilot of WFP, WFP in collaboration with IGMRI launched 1 year study to facilitate evidence-based scale-up of SMART warehouse.FAO:To support evidence-based policy development in the dairy sector, FAO developed a farmer-level Clean Milk Scorecard and finalized assessment tools for evaluating hygienic and production practices. The Scorecard serves as a monitoring and advisory tool to assess farm-level practices, benchmark quality standards, and track improvements over time.To strengthen institutional frameworks, FAO  has initiated collaboration with the National Dairy Development Board (NDDB) to align on regulatory reforms and explore certification systems for clean and safe milk production.FAO also contributed to policy dialogue and multi-stakeholder engagement for enhancing the camel milk value chain in India. On 20 December 2024, FAO India, in partnership with the Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying, organized a national workshop on the sustainable development of camel milk systems. The event brought together over 100 participants‚Äîincluding 57 government, private sector, and academic stakeholders and more than 50 camel rearers‚Äîfrom Rajasthan and Gujarat. Discussions focused on procurement, pricing, product standardization, and policy feasibility to enhance the sector‚Äôs integration into formal food systems. A short video developed by FAO showcasing camel milk‚Äôs therapeutic value and community relevance was also released.Both initiatives strengthen the evidence base for clean milk certification and camel milk integration, enabling policy action that supports food safety, climate adaptation, and improved income for pastoral and smallholder communities.

2023 Narrative: 1)     MACRO level/legislative framework and practical guidelinesa. Adoption of a new organic law on 16th January 2024.b. Roadmap for trade negotiations on organic products between China and Mongolia developed and first steps facilitated.c. MOFALI became official voting member of International Federation of Organic Agricultural Movements (IFOAM).d. The Food Department of MOFALI got equipped with 8 guides to compliance and guides to best practice for selected value chains which shall further enhance overall compliance with general principles of food hygiene standards. 2) MESO level/enabling institutional environmenta. Upgrading six selected certification bodies in line with organic and Halal accreditation scheme requirements.                    i.    Total 2 national CBs accredited by IOAS for organic product certification                    ii.   Total 2 national CBs accredited by GAC for Halal product certification, and 1 with pending corrective actions to be addressed                    iii.  Total 1 national CB accredited by MNAS for generic product certification in line with ISO 17065 b. In full complementarity, the national accreditation system has been strengthened in these scopes, and the Mongolian Accreditation Body (MNAS) got equipped with a pool of qualified assessors and staff which benefitted from intensive human capacity-building, and an update of its documentation system.c. The Central Leather Testing Lab (CLTL) benefitted from intensive upgrading support which comprised the development of a business plan, human capacity building, and a revision of its documentation system and procedures in line with international standard requirements. 3) MICRO level/enterprise supporta. At micro-level 23 meat processing enterprises, tanneries and textiles companies benefitted from intensive upgrading support, which started by in-depth gap analysis against relevant standard/scheme requirements (i.e. Halal, HACPP, ISO 2000, Leather and Working Group tools and scheme, √ñEKOTEX 100) and the development of complementary upgrading roadmaps. b. By being assisted in the implementation of the latter - through coaching, system design advise/implementation, human capacity-building - 11 enterprises achieved the final goal, and their products are eventually certified.                    i. Total 2 tanneries certified by an international LWG auditor against LWG scheme requirements (final audit results already available)                ii. Total 6 meat processing enterprises certified by one of the national CBs, which eventually managed to achieve accreditation by GAC, against Halal standard requirements (final audit results awaited)                   iii. Total 3 textile companies certified against √ñEKOTEX 100 (final test results awaited)c. Total 6 tanneries intensively coached and guided on the implementation of the upgrading roadmaps generated by having applied the Tanneries of the Future Tool which got developed by the LWG.

2023 Narrative: Thanks to new vaccination tactic (risk based control) foot and mouth and peste des petits ruminants are under control and open new opportunities for meat market‚Ä¢ 2023 saw highest meat export to China‚Ä¢ New marketing opening up in Vietnam (frozen meat)Healthy herd certification program to demonstrate absence of Brucellosis infection in herd and residues, and antimicrobials in milk.Camel milk supply chain best practices in South Gobi aimag has been up scaled by private sector partner to new aimags: Bayanhongor and Gobi Altai aimags. The camel milk products export has increased by 3 times. Private sector investment has increased 10 times. Livestock supply chain improvement support has resulted in following results: Nuclear herd of ram and bucks (380) created at the 6 soums. 5 herder cooperatives have supplied 58 tons sustainably sourced and certified cashmere to domestic processing plants. 20 herder households have been supported to earn additional income from sales of 40 000 litres of milk to peri-urban market while qualifying for school milk program. Honey cluster development has been supported in eastern two aimags and supplied high quality 625 kgs of honey to urban markets. A SEMI-INTENSIVE CAMEL DAIRY FARM for 200 camels is being established in Khankhongor, Umnugovi, in partnership with SPG LLC.
2024 Narrative: FAO has supported the Government of Mongolia in amending key legislation on food and agriculture, which was subsequently approved by the Parliament of Mongolia. These amendments aim to strengthen the legal framework for food security, animal health, and crop farming. Notably, on June 5, 2024, the Parliament approved the new Law on Livestock and Animal Veterinary Drugs and Feed Additives and amended the Law on Livestock and Animal Health. On the same day, the Law on Plant Health and Plant Protection was revised, along with amendments to the Crop Law, the Law on Ensuring the Safety of Food Products, and the Law on Food. Earlier, on January 17, 2024, the Law on Food Products had also been revised.FAO supported the establishment of a Livestock Breeding and Technology Unit in Yeruu soum, Selenge aimag, providing specialized livestock breeding improvement services to 600 households. The unit has performed artificial insemination on 1,487 sheep and 107 cattle, contributing to the enhancement of livestock breeds.Models of public-private partnerships have been developed and piloted to improve the coordination of national program implementation and create opportunities for large numbers of young people to work in agricultural value chains. The "Incubator farm" training and incubation program was launched in partnership with SPG LLC to provide herders with the training for adopting modern farming methods.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and Equitable Human Development and Well-Being
Outcome: Sustainable and Inclusive, Green-Led Growth, People-Centred Economic Recovery, Livelihoods and Productivity
Output: The government, private sector and other stakeholders create an enabling and innovative business environment for job-rich economic growth and diversification of sustainable enterprises and key value chains, particularly for MSMEs.
Sub-Output: JP: Mainstreaming standards-based best practices for agri-food sector development (BESPA-FOOD)
Description:
The project aims to (1) modernize the food control system in line with international benchmarks and best practices, (2) upgrade the quality infrastructure (QI) system to provide locally accessible QI services to the agri-food sector, (3) strengthen food safety and quality-related compliance capacity of the private sector, particularly along select value chains (namely coconut, banana, vanilla and cassava), and (4) raise stakeholder awareness and adherence to best practices end-to-end along the agri-food value chain, including that of producers and consumers.
(UNJP/SRL/076/EC)
Multiyear project: Start date: 11/1/2021
FAO Project Code: UNJP/SRL/076/EC
Agencies: United Nations Industrial Development Organization
Implementation partners: Sri Lanka Ministry of Trade
SDG Targets: 9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: (UNIDO)In 2023, NQI institutions, such as the Sri Lanka Accreditation Board (SLAB) and Measurement Units, Standards, and Services Department (MUSSD), underwent capacity building, international peer assessments, and collaboration with the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB) for accreditation readiness. UNIDO recommended adopting or revising 66 standards based on ISO standards for the Food and Agri-industry. The project identified 8 ISO Technical Committees relevant to the Agri-Foodsector and supported the participation of the Sri Lanka Standards Institute (SLSI) in 4 of them. The establishment of a National Quality Council (NQC) was emphasized for embedding good regulatory practices. In the Accreditation Readiness Programme, 28 of 43 Conformity Assessment Bodies (CAB) were deemed eligible. The project provided consultancy guidance and training, with four CABs undergoing procurement for laboratory capabilities. Four priority VCs‚Äîcoconut, banana, vanilla, and cassava‚Äîwere selected for their potential impact on food safety and quality. Stakeholder consultations and workshops were organized, andthe project facilitated the National Food  Beverage Conference 2023. The project supported value chain development through diagnostic assessments, training, and collaborations with relevant authorities, aiming at enhancing productivity, quality, and sustainability in selected value chains, addressing gaps in post-harvest practices. In support of the Food and Agri-sector, UNIDO launched in 2023 the Supplier Qualification Program (SQP), to assist selected enterprises in developing and executing robust technical investment proposals, with the aim of significantly improving food production, and consequently fostering socio-economic growth and sustainable development. In the Food Safety  Quality Culture component, awareness was assessed among agri-food enterprises in Sri Lanka. IEC activities were developed to raise awareness about technicalregulations, standards, and market requirements related to food safety and quality.
2024 Narrative: (UNIDO)NQI institutions like the Sri Lanka Accreditation Board (SLAB), the Measurement Units, Standards, and Services Department (MUSSD), and the Sri Lanka Standards Institution (SLSI) have received technical support to improve services for Conformity Assessment Bodies (CABs) and ensure compliance with food safety and quality standards. Collaboration with the Ministry of Trade is underway to establish a National Quality Council (NQC) for better coordination among NQI institutions.The Accreditation Readiness Programme (ARP) has provided technical assistance, training, and equipment to 49 Conformity Assessment Bodies (CABs) in Sri Lanka's agri-food sector, enhancing their capabilities and ensuring global recognition of their certificates for compliance with quality and safety standards.Within the Supplier Qualification Programme (SQP), a financial feasibility analysis is underway for 76 applicants to assess whether their proposed business venture would generate adequate returns to justify resource investment. UNIDO, in partnership with the Ministry of Industries presented a position paper with recommendations for reforming the national food control system, based on extensive consultations, to guide the development of the National Food Safety Policy and promote a joint public-private action plan.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and Equitable Human Development and Well-Being
Outcome: Sustainable and Inclusive, Green-Led Growth, People-Centred Economic Recovery, Livelihoods and Productivity
Output: The government, private sector and other stakeholders create an enabling and innovative business environment for job-rich economic growth and diversification of sustainable enterprises and key value chains, particularly for MSMEs.
Sub-Output: JP: Mainstreaming standards-based best practices for agri-food sector development (BESPA-FOOD)
Description:
The project aims to (1) modernize the food control system in line with international benchmarks and best practices, (2) upgrade the quality infrastructure (QI) system to provide locally accessible QI services to the agri-food sector, (3) strengthen food safety and quality-related compliance capacity of the private sector, particularly along select value chains (namely coconut, banana, vanilla and cassava), and (4) raise stakeholder awareness and adherence to best practices end-to-end along the agri-food value chain, including that of producers and consumers.

FAO specifically aims to achieve the following results. 
- Food competent authorities operate an effective food control system in line with international best practices for consumer protection.
- Consumers, enterprises, institutions and other stakeholders are more aware, informed and demanding of food safety and quality (driving demand from products and services supported by SO1 and SO2). (combined)
Multiyear project: Start date: 11/1/2021
FAO Project Code: UNJP/SRL/076/EC
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Sri Lanka Ministry of Trade
SDG Targets: 9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Gender marker narrative: The results of this initiative cannot be measured / no gender sensitive indicators.
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: FAOFAO provided technical support to Ministry of Health to develop a Zero draft of the food safety policy. A preliminary document was prepared on the updated food act with a legal report. Conducted a situation analysis report on food safety control systems in Sri Lanka. A baseline study was conducted as formative research on the perception and behavior of consumers on food safety. Social and Behavior Change campaign to advocate and promote food safety practices of consumers and better regulatory enforcement by government authorities.
2024 Narrative: The Food Safety Policy, along with strategic action documents, has been submitted to the Ministry of Health (MoH), alongside the proposed Food Act, a consolidated act, and a position paper. Regulatory review documents, including SOPs, technical analyses of nine regulations, and justification for seven new regulations, have also been submitted. Capacity-building activities under Codex commenced with advocacy workshops in February 2024, followed by a four-day workshop in June 2024, focusing on procedural validation and strategic planning. Another three-day workshop in August 2024 engaged multiple stakeholders on Codex harmonization and transparency. Additionally, five draft normative documents, including a National Codex Manual and a strategy for standards harmonization, were submitted to the MoH. A desk review was also conducted. Furthermore, 800 Public Health Inspectors (PHIs) received training through a series of eight workshops covering nine technical areas. Bi-lateral meetings with key trade and regulatory bodies supported policy implementation.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: People
Outcome: By 2025, poor and vulnerable groups living in Malaysia benefit from more equity-focused and high-quality social services as well as a social protection system that ensures all have an adequate standard of living.
Output: Social services are strengthened to ensure universal access to high-quality, equity focused social services that promote social wellbeing for all.
Sub-Output: Survey of salt levels in street foods to strengthen salt reduction action in Malaysia
Description:
This project will strengthen the implementation of  Malaysia‚Äôs  Salt  Reduction Strategy through generating data about the salt levels in street foods and meals in Malaysia, with a view to: 
(1) providing evidence for accelerating the introduction of mandatory sodium labelling on packaged and street foods, 
(2) informing salt-reduction education messages about what high-salt foods to avoid and what alternatives to consume as part of a strategic behavior change communication plan; and
(3) identifying and engaging food industries producing high-salt foods in reformulation. Analysis of the sodium content will be conducted on street foods which include ready-to-eat foods usually sold by small- to medium-sized vendors in a street, hawker center, or food court. 
This proposal extends ongoing national salt reduction efforts since 2015 and a recent mid-term evaluation of its progress, which elucidated areas for enhancement to ensure the targeted 15% reduction in population salt intake is achieved by 2020.
Agencies: World Health Organization
Implementation partners: Malaysia Ministry of Health; The George Institue for Global Health; Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,3.4 By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from noncommunicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.,12.3 By 2030, halve per capita global food waste at the retail and consumer levels and reduce food losses along production and supply chains, including post-harvest losses.,12.a Support developing countries to strengthen their scientific and technological capacity to move towards more sustainable patterns of consumption and production.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 3 Good Health and Well-being; 12 Responsible Consumption and Production
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Support Functions; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance

2022 Narrative: WFP provided technical assistance to MoPME and DPE for fortified biscuit distribution (total 2,781,800 government primary school children received biscuits) continued until mid-2022 alongside the conclusion of the iteration of the National School Feeding Programme (2010-2022). Also, WFP supported MoPME
2023 Narrative: WFP supported Ministry of Primary and Mass Education (MoPME) and the Directorate of Primary Education (DPE) to complete and publish the feasibility study for the relaunch of the National School Feeding Programme. Feasibility study‚Äôs recommendation for potential menus contributed to the ministry‚Äôs three-year draft development proposal (expected to be approved in 2024 by government) for the programme‚Äôs relaunching. Through policy and advocacy efforts, WFP supported the Ministry of Primary and Mass Education (MoPME) in joining the Global School Meals Coalition at the UN Food Systems Summit stocktaking event in July 2023 ‚Äì a commitment to continue improving the quality of school meals and strengthen the school meal system. WFP also provided school feeding assistance to 61,000 Government Primary schoolchildren in three sub-districts of Cox's Bazar.
2024 Narrative: WFP: WFP continued providing technical support to MoPME and DPE in revision of the Development Project Proposal (DPP) for Government School Feeding Programme. The Government aims to provide school feeding assistance, providing a weekly combined food basket to the schoolchildren in the Government Primary Schools of 150 Sub-districts of 62 districts. The Planning Commission convened three Project Evaluation (PEC) meetings for the project in 2024 and provided numbers of observations and recommendation. Following feedback from the meetings, WFP assisted MoPME and DPE in revising the project proposal. The approval process of the DPP has been delayed due to various reasons such as political turmoil, Government transition, new directives from Interim Govt, and frequent turnover of key officials in MoPME, DPE and Planning Commission. Additionally, WFP conducted a rapid assessment of local food procurement capacity across 14 sub-districts in 13 districts and assisted the Government in designing a tailored supply chain for the programme. The visits findings will be fed into the Operational Guidelines for the upcoming Government Primary School Feeding Programme which is expected to launch in July 2025. WFP supported MoPME and DPE in attending the 24th Global Child Nutrition Programme in Osaka, Japan to learn, exchange experiences, and gain inspiration for building, maintaining, and expanding high quality of school meal programs. WFP continued school feeding programme for 56,000 schoolchildren in the government primary schools in Ukhiya, Kutubdia and Teknaf upazilas of Cox‚Äôs Bazar district.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2022 - 2026
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2: Equitable Human Development and Well Being
Outcome: Outcome 2: By 2026, more people, in particular, the most vulnerable and marginalized, have improved access to and utilization of quality, inclusive, gender- and shock-responsive, universal, and resilient social protection, social safety-net and basic social services.
Output: 2.7 Increased access of targeted beneficiaries to sufficient, quality, nutritious and preferred food through a combination of coordinated actions focused around food security programmes for vulnerable populations, food safety in production and supply lines as well as green and sustainable agriculture production.
Sub-Output: Targeted vulnerable populations benefited from the availability and accessibility of safe and nutritious food through the engagement of private sector producers and processors to have improved food security and healthy diets.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: DSM Corporation; Government of Switzerland; Multilateral Fund for the Implementation of the Montreal Protocol; WFP Private Donors; World Food Programme Multilateral Fund
Implementation partners: Bangladesh Ministry of Food; Bangladesh Ministry of Women and Children Affairs; Private Sector
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Focal users: NOWSHIN JAHAN; Din Ara WAHID; Haimanti Ghosh
2022 Narrative: To strengthen the capacity of the Government (MoFood and MoWCA) and private sector partners to commercialization of fortified rice, WFP i) developed a comprehensive training module on rice fortification, nutrition, quality assurance and monitoring and ii) delivered training sessions and workshops for government stakeholders and private partners. In 2022, government distributions of fortified rice continued through WFP-supported Food Friendly Programme (FFP) and Vulnerable Group Development (VGD) programme and 498,005 women benefitted from fortified rice. WFP designed and implemented a campaign raising awareness of the health benefits of using fortified rice, reaching 265,000 people using interpersonal and media communications. WFP provided technical support to the Bangladesh Standard and Testing Institute (BSTI) to revise its fortified rice kernel testing methods and standards to ensure adequate micronutrient content for end users. WFP provided technical assistance to a total of 178 millers and 8 fortified rice producers who are in government roaster.
2023 Narrative: WFP has provided technical assistance to the MoFood, MoWCA and Fortified Rice producers to scale up the FR distribution in social safety net programmes and commercial markets. i) Revised and published the BSTI standard methodsii) Revised SoP on Fortified Rice distribution and managementIn 2023, Fortified Rice (FR) was distributed among 1,358,825 beneficiaries through the two major safety net programmes called the Vulnerable Women Benefit (VWB) programme and the Food Friendly Programme (FFP). WFP continues the awareness raising activities though interpersonal and SBC campaign and reaced 136,410 people. Though the technical assistence the 190 blendilng millers has continuing the supply of FR to the Government.
2024 Narrative: WFP continuing it's technical support to the MoFood, MoWCA and Fortified Rice producers to scale up the FR distribution in social safety net programmes and commercial markets as well as in the humanitarian sector.i) WFP handed over to the Government and Government is taking the lead to ensure the monitoring and inspection of Fortified rice at the social safety net programme.In 2024, Fortified Rice (FR) was distributed among 1,358,825 beneficiaries through the two major safety net programmes called the Vulnerable Women Benefit (VWB) programme and the Food Friendly Programme (FFP). WFP continues the SBC campaign though interpersonal and social media and reached 3,161,522 people. Though the technical assistance the 200 blending millers has continuing the supply of FR in different programme.

2022 Narrative: A) Dhaka Food System project of FAO established City Working Groups and developed City Food Charters for Dhaka North, Dhaka South, Gazipur and Narayanganj Cities. Through the development of modelling tools (GIS and Economic Models with WUR) and rounds of consultations with over 100 organizations, DFS prepared the final draft of the Dhaka Food Agenda 2041 to integrate food into urban planning. DFS also organized a two study tours for selected government officials to learn from cities in the Netherlands (may22); Bangkok and Melbourne (Sept22). The delegations comprised of officials from the Local Government Division of the Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development, and Cooperatives, the Ministry of Agriculture; the Ministry of Food; and all four city corporations. They were joined by a representative from the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. Lessons learned from the tours will help to shape the Dhaka Food Agenda 2041. B) Improvement of food safety practices to market vendors, including butchers, and management committees in over 80 markets in the Dhaka Division. Training for restaurants, as well as peri-urban farmers (reference - budget in SP1). C)2300 urban farmers and rooftop gardeners trained and supported with inputs in Dhaka(reference- budget in SP1)MUCH project supported harmonizing food standards with CODEX Alimentarius. Around 11,200 food safety regulations were developed by 27 Technical Working Groups comprising over 200 experts, including 36 from India who provided pro bono support to this deliverable. Food safety is a multi-stakeholder responsibility and MUCH provided relevant training to stakeholders on the CODEX process.- MUCH project conducted a pilot assessment of food vouchers and unconditional cash transfers on dietary diversification in Sunamganj and Kurigram districts which has a rationale for informing social protection strategy of the government.
2023 Narrative: FAO provided technical support to BFSA for developing and drafting around 11 200 food safety standards and regulations which now are in the process of notification to the World Trade Organisation (WTO).FAO provided technical support to the Ministry of Food in developing guidelines on rice milling outlining the steps to be followed from the point of entry of paddy into the rice mill, its processing, and packaging to ensure food safety and retain essential nutrition.
2024 Narrative: FAO provided extensive technical support to the Bangladesh Food Safety Authority (BFSA) in the development  These standards are currently undergoing the notification process with the World Trade Organization (WTO), marking a significant step towards enhancing food safety compliance at the global level.Additionally, FAO assisted the Ministry of Food in developing comprehensive guidelines for rice milling. These guidelines outline the critical steps involved in the rice milling process, from the point of entry of paddy into the mill, through its processing, to packaging. The objective is to ensure food safety while preserving essential nutritional values, thus supporting both consumer health and the sustainable

2021 Narrative: WFP conducted a research on food system environments in partnership with the Johns Hopkins University. 2,540 low-income  households in three sectors of urban, rural and estate, in geographic areas of high poverty, were involved in the survey. Communication campaigns targeted to these areas informed residents of the study objectives and allowed them to opt in. The survey is expected to reveal the susceptibility of these three groups to  external stressors and shocks such as the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. The report is expected in 2022.

2023 Narrative: The full project document produced through this PPG initiative aims to support in the mainstreaming of biodiversity and sustainable land management in and around key biodiversity areas along Bataan province to Manila Bay, through harmonized land use plans and frameworks while improving secure and diversified local livelihoods. The Three inter-connected components are focused on (i) strengthening of cross-sectoral capacities to develop and implement harmonized land use plans, investment plans, and resource management frameworks under Component 1; (ii) implementation of biodiversity-friendly interventions, incentive mechanisms for restoration and sustainable use, and sustainable land management (SLM) in a ridge-to-reef approach under Component 2; and (iii) knowledge management and scale-up of project lessons in Component 3.

Output: The government demonstrates improved commitment to gender-responsive and climate-smart environmental protection, natural resource management, and sustainable consumption and production practices.
Sub-Output: Joint Food Security Initiative (Phase I): Addressing immediate and emerging food security challenges faced by communities. (UNJP/SRL/078/UNJ)
Description:
FAO and WFP propose to address food security amidst the current crisis in Sri Lanka by supporting the efficient utilization of essential inputs such as fertilizer, along with cash transfers to sustain farmer livelihoods. The intervention will build the resilience and capacity of farmers to facilitate a successful transition towards Good Agricultural Practices (GAP). Moreover, the Government of Sri Lanka will strengthen their capacity to monitor the food security situation enabling informed policy decisions and targeted strategies. A second component will aim at improving food and nutrition security of school children through a better understanding/attitude toward healthy eating.

FAO Project Code: UNJP/SRL/078/UNJ
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: UN Sri Lanka SDG Multi-Partner Trust Fund
Implementation partners: Scaling Up Nutrition People's Forum; Sri Lanka Department of Agrarian Development; Sri Lanka Department of Census and Statistics; Sri Lanka Department of Samurdhi Development; Sri Lanka Ministry of Agriculture; Sri Lanka Ministry of Education; Sri Lanka Ministry of Finance; Sri Lanka Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Geography: Nuwara Eliya; Central; Kilinochchi; Badulla; Monaragala; Sri Lanka; Matale; Mullaitivu; Jaffna; Vavuniya; Mannar; Kandy; Northern; Uva
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The program empowered beneficiaries with Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) and cash assistance, using a holistic approach that addressed vulnerable groups' needs while promoting gender-sensitive targeting to ensure equal support for women. The Entrepreneurial School Gardening initiative engaged both male and female students, supporting women-led home gardens by providing education and creating market linkages, fostering equal entrepreneurship opportunities for women.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Youth; Children ; Persons With Disabilities; Women & Girls
2023 Narrative: WFP provided cash assistance to 18,860 Samurdhi beneficiaries (including pregnant and breastfeeding women and girls, children under five and people with disabilities and chronic illnesses) to address increasing vulnerabilities, inequalities, poverty and enhance their resilience, and enable them to bounce back from economic shocks. In addition, WFP provided cash assistance to 570 FAO-selected smallholder farmers, which prioritized women-headed households, women entrepreneurs and farmers keen to follow GAP certification. In parallel, WFP partnered with Scaling Up Peoples Forum (SUN PF) and the Health Promotion Bureau and provided trainings to the beneficiaries (DSD and smallholder farmers) to promote awareness of nutrition, gender, cash management and Social Behavior Change Communication (SBCC). FAO launched Good Agriculture Practices Programme (GAP) for horticulture farmers and Entrepreneurial School Gardens (ESG) Programme under the project. Through GAP programme farmers were trained and provided technical expertise to use sustainable and climate resilient modern agriculture practices. FAO further supported farmers with providing modern agriculture equipment and building up market linkages. Under ESG programme 400 schools were supported and sensitized in establishing school garden. Each and every schools were awarded with cash grants.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2022 - 2026
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Sustainable, Healthy and Resilient Environment
Outcome: Outcome 3: By 2026, ecosystems are healthier, and all people, in particular the most vulnerable and marginalized in both rural and urban settings, benefit from and contribute in a gender-responsive manner to a cleaner and more resilient environment, an enriched natural resource base, low carbon development, and are prosperous and more resilient to climate change, shocks and disasters.
Output: 3.1 The most vulnerable people, especially women, and communities in both rural and urban areas are more prepared to adapt and respond to climate change, shocks, and disasters
Sub-Output: Nature-based, DRR, and CCA, measures to support resilience in rural and urban agri-food systems
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Disaster Preparedness ECHO Programme; European Union; FAO Technical Cooperation Programme; Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Government of Bangladesh; Government of the Netherlands; International Organization for Migration; The Global Environment Facility; The Green Climate Fund; United Nations Joint Projects; United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Bangladesh Ministry of Agriculture; Bangladesh Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief; Bangladesh Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change
SDG Targets: 13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,13.b Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.,14.4 By 2020, effectively regulate harvesting and end overfishing, illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and destructive fishing practices and implement science-based management plans, in order to restore fish stocks in the shortest time feasible, at least to levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield as determined by their biological characteristics.,15.1 By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.
SDG Goals: 13 Climate Action; 14 Life Below Water; 15 Life on Land
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Youth; Peasants & Rural Workers; Women & Girls
2022 Narrative: Integrating Nature-based solutions, DRR, and CCA to enhance nature-positive and resilient rural and urban agri-food systems. In Cox's Bazar and CHT FAO have tested and piloted a landslide early warning system, and performed tree plantation, and biological stabilization of hill slopes under several initiatives. Under the Green Cities Initiative project FAO has provided support to the development and implementation of local actions related to urban and peri-urban forestry, urban and peri-urban agriculture, and urban food systems, create action labs and develop capacity for integrating urban food systems, urban forestry, and urban agriculture into urban planning. FAO has also conducted a farm sustainability analysis in several AEZs of Bangladesh and enhanced the Khamari App in support of the DRR and CCA in the agriculture sector.
2023 Narrative: Capacity-building training was organized for better interpretation of the warning, to increase the resilience of the vulnerable communities, and to ensure better management of the disasters. A landslide volunteer network was formed in Cox‚Äôs Bazar with support from the local DRR (Disaster and Relief Management) office and actors in the management of disaster. 40 volunteers were trained in the identification and verification of landslide-vulnerable areas as well as in emergency searches and rescue which will pave the way for future management of such disaster more efficiently.FAO supported the Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of Environment Forestry and Climate Change to strengthen landscape resilience in Bangladesh for improved livelihoods and reduced vulnerability to climate change. As a basis for developing project interventions in the future, a baseline survey was initiated to document the socio-economic and environmental conditions and climate risk in the High Barind Tract, Waterlogging-prone region and Chittagong Hill Tracts.
2024 Narrative: Capacity-building training was organized to improve early warning interpretation, enhance community resilience, and strengthen disaster management. A landslide volunteer network was formed in Cox‚Äôs Bazar, with 40 volunteers trained in identifying vulnerable areas and conducting emergency search and rescue operations. FAO also supported community-based climate-resilient fisheries and aquaculture development in Bangladesh, alongside pesticide risk reduction initiatives.Additionally, FAO partnered with the Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Environment, Forests, and Climate Change to strengthen landscape resilience. A baseline survey was initiated to assess socio-economic, environmental conditions, and climate risks in the High Barind Tract, waterlogging-prone areas, and Chittagong Hill Tracts, forming the foundation for future interventions.
