Plan name: UNSDCF 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3 - Disaster and Climate Resilience
Outcome: Outcome 3.1 - Institutions, communities and people actively apply and implement low carbon development, sustainable natural resources management and disaster resilience approaches that are all gender sensitive.
Output: Output 3.1.1 - Strengthened institutional capacities in government agencies and other key national stakeholders to develop, improve, and implement coordinated policies/strategies/plans for increased resilience to climate change and disasters and reduced greenhouse gas emissions
Sub-Output: 3.1.1.26 - Strengthened capacities of the national and subnational government agencies and key stakeholders to adapt and better manage increased climate variability in the country, by improving the understanding of the impacts of climate change on food security and nutrition.
Description: (a) Improve the utilization of Government's monitoring and early warning information to inform impact-based forecasting and other anticipatory actions and (b) Support the coordination of the Food Security Monitoring Technical Working Group and provide analysis to produce quarterly seasonal bulletins
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade ; German Federal Foreign Office; German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development; Google.org; Government of Indonesia; Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs; The Joint SDG Fund; United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Indoneisa Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries/KKP; Indonesia  Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries/KKP; Indonesia Metereology, Climatology, and Geophysical Agency/BMKG; Indonesia Ministry of Forestry; Indonesia Ministry of National Development Planning (BAPPENAS); Indonesia Ministry of Social Affairs/Kemensos; Indonesia National Institute of Aeronautics and Space; Indonesia National Statistics Agency/BPS
SDG Targets: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 17 Partnerships for the Goals
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: With WFP support, the Governments of Indonesia and Jordan exchanged knowledge on disaster risk reduction, emergency preparedness and response, and early warning systems. This was done through South-South and Triangular Cooperation events, which includes a visit from Jordanian National Centre for Security and Crises Management delegates to Government institutions in Jakarta and East Nusa Tenggara.WFP continued to support the Government-led Seasonal Monitoring Technical Working Group. With WFP support, the technical working group produced three joint Seasonal Impact Monitoring Bulletins assessing and forecasting the impacts of climate events on agriculture and food security. Technical working group members include the Meteorological, Climatological, and Geophysics Agency, the National Food Agency, the National Disaster Management Agency, and Statistics Indonesia. The bulletins, which aim to inform agricultural and food security interventions and preventative actions, were disseminated through government communication channels.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, WFP achieved its targets partnering with Government across multiple sectors to enhance understanding of anticipatory action and assess the feasibility for its implementation in Indonesia through convening stakeholders, providing technical assistance and engaging policy dialogue. This included the finalization of a joint WFP-Government feasibility assessment conducted across five provinces, generating evidence to inform national and sub-national development plans. Through convening multi-sector consultation processes, WFP enabled the deepening of stakeholder engagement, promoted government ownership, and supported the defining of anticipatory action within the Indonesian context by building on existing Government systems. WFP capacity strengthening investments included the facilitation of a South-South Triangular Cooperation knowledge exchange between the Governments of Indonesia and the Philippines. This resulted in learning and knowledge exchange on early warning systems and the institutionalization of anticipatory action into national governance, legal structures, and funding and coordination mechanisms.   WFP in partnership with the Coordinating Ministry for Human Development and Cultural Affairs convened the First National Dialogue on Anticipatory Action ‚Äì a key milestone in the collective effort to institutionalize anticipatory action at the national level. This catalytic platform enabled stakeholder collaboration ‚Äì including those of WFP and partners to strengthen the Government‚Äôs support and recognition of anticipatory action, integration of its principles into early warning systems and funding mechanisms, and critical to minimizing the impact of disasters. This platform will be key to the development of national anticipatory action guidelines and frameworks.
2024 Narrative: WFP in partnership with the National Disaster Management Agency facilitated consensus on the national operational definition of anticipatory action within the Indonesian Government system as ‚ÄúAction in Response to Early Warning‚Äù (Aksi Merespon Peringatan Dini or AMPD). This consensus and the subsequent codification of the operational definition in the National Disaster Management Agency Regulation No. 2/2024 marked a significant achievement in ensuring a synchronized anticipatory action approach at national and subnational levels. WFP partnered with provincial governments to test the integration of anticipatory action into existing government systems, expanding on the pilot models established in 2023 in the provinces of Yogyakarta, West Kalimantan, and East Nusa Tenggara. These provinces cover a population of 15 million people across three major Indonesian islands. The testing of models and the results achieved at the provincial and district levels now provide the foundation for an evidence-based integration of the anticipatory action system at the national level. In Yogyakarta, WFP and the local government finalized the development of a provincial contingency plan and operational guidelines for tropical cyclones, integrating anticipatory action principles for strengthened disaster risk management mechanisms. This included defining early action triggers for national authorities to declare an emergency and initiate response with national resources, even before the impacts of the disaster are felt by the population. Further strengthening anticipatory action in the province, WFP successfully advocated for the legalization of the operational guideline and contingency plan through a Governor‚Äôs Decree.  In West Kalimantan, WFP and partners mainstreamed anticipatory action into the national Climate Field School curriculum and built local sensitization and training of trainer models for wider implementation. The Climate Field School is a national programme that equips over 1,000 farmers and community facilitators annually with the knowledge and skills to manage agricultural resources and adapt their practices to climate variability.  In East Nusa Tenggara, drought conditions persisted and were exacerbated by climate anomalies. In response, WFP and government partners advanced the integration of anticipatory action into the provincial contingency plan for drought. As a result, the local government endorsed the plan and swiftly informed a declaration of emergency based on early warning for the province from June to December 2024, enabling access to on-call funds for early action in anticipation of drought. In parallel, WFP and the East Nusa Tenggara Province Climate Task Force achieved the integration of the findings on food security and climate risks from the 2023 Consolidated Livelihood Exercise for Analysing Resilience (CLEAR+) study into the East Nusa Tenggara 2025-2045 Long-Term Provincial Development Plan. This will inform the formulation of provincial development plans, programmes, and resource allocation towards improved livelihoods and food security among populations most vulnerable to the impact of climate change.

Plan name: UNSDCF 2023 - 2027
Strategic priority: Green, inclusive and sustainable growth
Outcome: Outcome 3 - By 2027, communities and eco-systems in Mongolia are more resilient to climate change with improved capacity for evidence-informed and gender-responsive sustainable natural resource and environmental management and disaster risk reduction
Output: Output 3.1 - Regulatory systems for climate responsive planning and development strengthened to improve adaptive capacity and reduce socio-economic vulnerabilities and risks including disaster displacement risk
Sub-Output: 3.1.13:  Agricultural sector policies and systems in the One Health arena for management of animal, plant, and human health, and food safety in national agri-food systems enhanced, with particular focus on zoonotic diseases and responsible use of antimicrobials in agricultural production.
Description: Agricultural sector policies and systems in the One Health arena for management of animal, plant, and human health, and food safety in national agri-food systems enhanced, with particular focus on zoonotic diseases and responsible use of antimicrobials in agricultural production.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Mongolia Ministry of Food Agriculture and Light Industry
SDG Targets: 13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: First ever international project "One health approach to manage Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) and Antimicrobial use in Mongolia to support National Action Plan on AMR (2022-2025). The objective of the project is to strengthen multispectral governance, surveillance and awareness raising. This is the first ever project on One Health in Mongolia which was initiated and jointly implemented by WHO, FAO and WOAH.Strengthened global collaboration with 3 labs (NCZD, IVM and City vet lab) and supported in the participation of international proficiency testing AMR inactive pilot surveillance: 1) Identified and addressed gaps between sectors for a comprehensive surveillance system, 2) Positioned strategically to monitor National Action Plan (NAP) 2022-2025 activities.
2024 Narrative: FAO trained 16 professionals in food safety risk assessment and translated the FAO food safety risk guide into Mongolian, enhancing local expertise in food safety practices. Additionally, FAO developed the "Food Safety Interdisciplinary Surveillance Plan" and "INFOSAN Operational Procedure," addressing regulatory gaps and strengthening international food safety cooperation.FAO also conducted AMR studies in cattle, ensuring veterinary drug residue and drug quality compliance with Mongolian standards, supporting public health and safety. Furthermore, 23 professionals were trained in AST across six laboratories, and 26 professionals from eight regional labs were trained to advance a unified AST methodology aligned with international standards.FAO resolved E. coli AMR surveillance discrepancies and progressed toward the 2025 "Veterinary Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Strategy." Additionally, a monitoring framework was established for the National AMR Action Plan (2022‚Äì2025), with an evaluation scheduled for 2025.

2023 Narrative: No significant progress to report in 2023, as the project was initiated in Q3.
2024 Narrative: The completion of six lift irrigation systems, 475 roof harvesting systems, 13 micro-irrigation systems and 15 solar irrigation pumps brought more than 55ha of land under irrigation, benefiting more than 1,700 households by ensuring a reliable water supply foragriculture. This improved access to energy and irrigation has not only increased agriculturalproductivity and enterprise development but also directly contributed to income generation. Notably, 15women have been able to triple their income, demonstrating the tangible impact of these interventions onlivelihoods, particularly for marginalized groups and women. Altogether 2,215 people (includingstudents) benefitted from upgrading of 10 school kitchens, installation of 4 solar PV and 10 metallic cookstoves. Improved cooking solutions and solar home systems were also installed, benefitting more than2,250 households.

2022 Narrative: The project has completed a series of multi stakeholders dialogue (MSD) that brings together government agencies (national and provincial level), universities and non government organizations. The MSD is the approach to develop urban food system governance in Indonesia. BAPPENAS highlighted the MSD is a framework of a prototype of an urban food system that needs to be realized by local champion which involve local government agencies, non-government organizations, and enterprises. In the implementation of demonstration of  projects on sustainable urban and peri-urban agriculture in Semarang, the rooftop of the Soegijapranata Catholic University (SCU) campus is planned to be utilized as a location for the development of urban farming from the Agriculture Service. It is consistent with the vision that Semarang City will become a city that produces healthy food through the application of inclusive agricultural technology by supporting a circular economy. The City of Semarang has started towards the concept of Regenerative Agriculture. Two demo sites of sustainable urban and peri urban agriculture (SUPA) already selected. These two demo sites are expected to be developed to follow the design and practices of SUPA based on regenerative agriculture principles, as showcasing how circularity could be enhanced; kitchen activity in processing of harvested local products; and access to market for the local and sustainable food product in place.

2022 Narrative: The supporting partner, Bogor Agricultural University, submitted the study report on economic valuation of cocoa in North Luwu, Sulawesi. The study aims to support agro-forestry mainstreaming agenda of the Ministry of National Planning. The study finds cocoa agroforestry system provide provisioning services such as food supply (cocoa, other food crops and fruits), regulation services such as erosion prevention, soil biodiversity, nutrient retention, climate, and regulation of water flows, and habitat services. With regard to economic valuation, the study has found the market prices of cocoa produced from monoculture systems are cheaper than that in agroforestry systems. The different prices can be affected by trading system, the length of value chain and any other causes.

2024 Narrative: FOLUR Project Indonesia is in the second year of implementation since the project was officially launched in August 2022. Up to now, FOLUR Project Indonesia has taken initial yet critical set step in progressing with implementing the Integrated Landscape Management (ILM) approach. Whilst the definitive baseline will be determined in year 3 after the ILM plans are endorsed, in the meantime, through an inclusive and participative multi stakeholder dialogue process, project has made initial assessment with regard to the potential area for intervention at district level, which will inform the more comprehensive baseline assessment for area of land restored. This also reflects the progress of CPD Indicator related to Output Indicator 3.4.1: Number of adaptive landscape management strategies that build social, economic and ecological resilience tested/adopted at the district level.  Component 1: ILM FOLUR Project Indonesia has taken initial yet critical set in progressing with implementing the Integrated Landscape Management (ILM) approach.  Whilst the definitive baseline will be determined in year 3 after the ILM plans are endorsed, in the meantime, through an inclusive and participative multi stakeholder dialogue process, project has made initial assessment with regard to the potential area for intervention at district level, which will inform the more comprehensive baseline assessment for area of land restored.  TSA and HCV studies currently have been done in three project locations to provide a more robust baseline, namely in: Central Aceh, Aceh; Mandailing Natal, North Sumatera; and Luwu, South Sulawesi. TSA and HCV studies currently underway in two project locations to provide a more robust baseline, namely in: Sanggau District, Kalimantan Barat Province and Sorong District, Papua Barat Daya Province. Decisions Support Tool system: under development of initial term of reference.  CPD Indicator related to Output Indicator 3.4.1: Number of adaptive landscape management strategies that build social, economic and ecological resilience tested/adopted at the district level. Project has been identified 65 indicative villages then 25 villages have been verified as priority intervention sites in five district of FOLUR site locations. Facilitation on establishing multistakeholher forum (task force) for Papua Barat Daya and Kalimantan Barat Provinces. Formulation of Sustainable Palm Oil Regional Action Plan (RAD-KSB) in Mandailing Natal and Sanggau Districts have been facilitated for supporting sustainable commodity action plan.  Component 2: Sustainable Commodity Production The preparatory work to identify potential targeted sites and beneficiaries in the 5 targeted districts was completed.  This included a series of more than 30 participative multistakeholder dialogues ILM related activities both at national and sub-national level through which consultations were undertaken with more than 5000 potential beneficiaries, of which around 2000 were women, creating ownership in the process with them.  As a result, a clearer indication and picture of initial beneficiaries was obtained in Sorong, Central Aceh, Mandailing Natal, Sanggau and Luwu and is estimated at 52,838 (22,644 women).  In terms of CPD Indicator, this refers to the progress of CPD Indicator related to Output Indicator 3.1.3: Number of men and women who have benefitted from improved governance of commodities productions at land and sea.  Component 3: Conservation and Restoration In the meantime, the project has not restored any degraded areas yet, but to progress towards defining the baseline of restoring the area of land including forest land, the project has determined the possible area that can be restored in each of the 5 districts.  58,894 hectares in total were identified including 5,380 hectares in Central Aceh, 3,651 hectares in Mandailing Natal, 5,222 in Sanggau, 34,172 in Sorong and 10,469 hectares in Luwu.  The project also made an initial determination that restoration could be targeted on forest land equaling 37,910. The project is on track to have more specific estimates by year 3 and is expected to meet the 20,000 hectares end target.

Description:
The Global Environment Facility (GEF8) approved the Expression of Interest (EOI) of the project entitled ‚ÄúSustainable, regenerative and resilient rice-based food systems to strengthen community and
ecosystem health in three river basins of Sri Lanka ‚Äù under the Food Systems Integrated Program (FS-IP). The project aims to imporve the ecosystem health and transform food systems to deliver multiple
environmental and social benefits through the following components: (i) Implementing institutional, policy and regulatory frameworks that support sustainable, regenerative and resilient food systems; (ii)
Improved and increased financing deployed in support of food system transformation; (iii) Developing/using innovative technologies and good practices of agri-food production systems in the landscape ; (iv) Developing sustainable agri-food value chains for value-addition and healthy and diverse food consumption through a circular economic approach ; and (v) Knowledge for regenerative and resilient agri-food systems is enhanced.

Implementation partners: Sri Lanka Ministry of Agriculture; Sri Lanka Ministry of Environment

Description: As part of the United Nations joint programme on ‚ÄòMonitoring the Food, Energy, and Finance Crisis towards informed Policy and Response Options in the Philippines‚Äô, the Wold Food Programme (WFP) conducted mobile Vulnerability Analysis and Mapping (mVAM) surveys from October 2022 to March 2023 to understand the food security situation of households.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Labour Organisation; United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Labour Organisation; United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: World Food Programme Multi-donor

Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 4 Output 4: Social protection systems effectively shored.
Human rights marker narrative: Focus on data collection
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: The Joint Programme provided the UN and the Government of the Philippines with clear and up-to-date information on the impacts of the cost-of-living crisis at both the macroeconomic and household levels. Although it was common knowledge that inflation was hitting decade-high levels in the past year, there was insufficient information on how exactly the country‚Äôs food systems had been affected, how households were coping with the crisis, and how equipped the government was to respond to the economic shock. The Joint Programme aimed to fill the information gap by conducting three studies: (1) an assessment of the Philippine agri-food systems, (2) a nationwide survey on the household-level impacts of the crisis, and (3) an assessment of the shock-responsiveness of the country‚Äôs social protection systems.

Implementation partners: Local and international NGOs

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: ACTIVITY 5 : fundling level of 29% achieved.
2022 Narrative: ACTIVITY 5 : funding level of 29% achieved.
2023 Narrative: In 2022 and 2023, WFP continued to strengthen agricultural value chains across Afghanistan to promote the local production and accessibility of fortified nutritious foods. This was done through continued (i) support to wheat and soy farmers to increase production quantity and quality; (ii) livelihoods and market-linkage support to women in rural areas (iii) support to 44 flour mills for the fortification of wheat flour with essential vitamins (B12 and folic acid) and minerals (iron and zinc), and four soy processing factories to combat micronutrient deficiencies among the general population (iv) support to seven soya processors. In 2022, more than 11,532 farmers, including 2,695 women, were supported through large-scale wheat value chain strengthening projects. A total of 10,576 farmers received training on product marketing and post-harvest handling solutions, while 4,840 also benefitted from complementary training on nutrition and gender mainstreaming. 23,639 farmers from 67 farmer organizations have been trained in 2023.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Resilient and Green Recovery and Growth for Shared Prosperity and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Natural Resource Management, Climate Resilience and Environmental Sustainability
Output: The private sector, other non-state actors and the people in Sri Lanka have improved knowledge and capacities to demand for, adopt and use environmentally friendly, gender-responsive and climate-smart environmental protection, natural resource management, and sustainable consumption and production practices.
Sub-Output: Enhancing the contribution from Non-Timber Forest Products to livelihoods and food security (TCP/SRL/4003)
Description:
Presently the capacity of DFC for assessment and designing measures for sustainable
management and value addition of NTFP to benefit local livelihoods and their food security remains
limited. In the above context, the project aims to support the DFC to build the national capacity to ensure
sustainable management, value addition and use of NTFP, that in turn will enhance the contribution of
NTFP to the livelihoods and food security of the rural people. Specific objectives are to: (i) improve
knowledge and skills of NWFP users on sustainable extraction and resource assessments (ii) prepare
assessment reports focusing on selected NTFP that will include both economically and nutritionally
viable species (iii) design and pilot a selected NTFP resource improvement program and (iv) design and apply conservation measures for selected threatened NTFP species. A proposal for resource mobilization
will also be prepared to conserve and sustainably use NTFP.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Sri Lanka Ministry of Environment
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2024 Narrative: This project significantly contributed to building anticipatory action (AA) capacity, enhancing early warning systems, and fostering regional collaboration to address climate-induced crises in South Asia, with a focus on Sri Lanka.1. Capacity Building:National-Level Training for Humanitarian Agencies: Trained 44 representatives from humanitarian agencies on anticipatory action (AA), with 50% female participation.Government Officer Training: FAO and ADPC jointly trained 34 government officers at the national level on AA (18 males, 16 females), equipping them with critical skills for proactive disaster management.Regional Training in Batticaloa:Conducted AA training for 43 government officers, including the validation of historical flood and crisis timelines (40 males, 3 females).Delivered specialized training for 34 officers in agriculture and irrigation sectors on localized agro-met advisory development (27 males, 7 females).2.Regional and National Platforms for Anticipatory Action:South Asia Dialogue Platform (SADP): Held on 10‚Äì11 September in Sri Lanka, with participation from seven countries (Pakistan, Bhutan, Nepal, Bangladesh, Maldives, Afghanistan, and Sri Lanka). This platform addressed challenges and opportunities in developing national frameworks for AA, with FAO playing a key organizing role as part of Sri Lanka‚Äôs AA technical working group (83 males, 25 females).Sri Lanka Dialogue Platform on Anticipatory Action: Conducted on 12‚Äì13 September under the theme ‚ÄúMeaningful Partnerships for Sustainable Anticipatory Action.‚Äù The event promoted a shared understanding of AA among national actors and strengthened collaboration for its institutionalization (74 males, 39 females).3.Technological Advancements in Early Warning Systems:Initiated the installation of automated rain gauges and river gauges (10 each) across Maduru Oya, Andella Oya, and Magilavatuwan River Basins.

Description: In response to the November 2023 Jajarkot earthquake, provide immediate multipurpose cash assistance and conditional cash assistance through Food Assistance for Assets (FFA) and Food Assistance for Training (FFT) for 10,783 households. Provide unconditional cash assistance to 6072 vulnerable households unable to contribute labour for FFA and FFT activities and nutrition-focused cash top-ups were to 4548 households with pregnant and breastfeeding women and girls (PBWGs), and children aged 6‚Äì23 months, to address specific nutritional needs and prevent malnutrition.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office
Implementation partners: United Nations World Food Programme

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: Unconditional Support: Emergency Cash Support: WFP, under the UN‚Äôs Joint Recovery Action Plan, provided unconditional cash assistance to 30,170 vulnerable people in Jajarkot and Rukum West, with each of 6,000 households receiving USD 260 (NPR 36,000).Nutritional Top-Ups: 1,580 pregnant and breastfeeding women and 2,590 children (6‚Äì23 months) received monthly cash top-ups of USD 18 (NPR 2,500) for four months to address their nutritional needs.Integrated Support Services: Beneficiaries received funds directly in bank accounts, with spending focused on food, debt, and healthcare. The assistance was reinforced with nutrition education, protection messaging, and financial literacy training.Conditional Support:In response to the November 2023 earthquake efforts to recover and reconstruct, through the food assistance forassets (FFA) scheme, WFP supported 9,300 households contributing to rebuilding efforts, such as the repair of 126kilometers of roads, adopting a build back better approach. Through the food assistance for training scheme, 945households received short-term skill training in areas such as plumbing, electrical wiring, and masonry.
2025 Narrative: Comprehensive Humanitarian Response: The project effectively addressed both immediate and longer-term needs of earthquake-affected communities through a combination of unconditional cash assistance and conditional support focused on asset creation and skills development. This integrated approach ensured that vulnerable households not only received timely relief but were also empowered to contribute to recovery and resilience-building efforts.Enhanced Community Resilience: By combining emergency aid with training, infrastructure repair, and behavior change communication, the intervention laid the groundwork for sustained community recovery. The focus on skill-building and community infrastructure has strengthened local capacities, supporting a more resilient and self-reliant recovery process.

2024 Narrative: FAO supported a water scarcity study in Mongolia, which led to the construction of two energy-efficient greenhouses (2000 ha) in Tuv and Darkhan-Uul, using Venlo technology and hydroponics. These greenhouses strengthened local value chains by connecting growers with buyers and promoting sustainable practices.FAO also facilitated the establishment of a 1,000-liter/day milk processing unit, which has served 1,200 students with local dairy products since 2022. Livestock health was improved through parasite prevention for 51,000 sheep and goats, artificial insemination for 350 sheep, and supplemental feed for cows, resulting in a 2.8-fold increase in milk production.The Sustainable Fibre Alliance certified 120 herders and 8 cooperatives, enabling premium cashmere sales. Additionally, a Nature Reserve Bee Honey cluster produced 500 kg of honey, supported by technical training, shelters, and packaging, adding value to local agriculture.

2023 Narrative: UN Women:Through COP in my City Initiative UN Women with the support of MOCC and other partners successfully managed youth led events across Pakistan. A total of 1,550 young people, with 50% being young women, gained knowledge and skills on gender-responsive climate action and a human rights approach to climate resilience and adaptation through the COP in My City training series organized by the Ministry of Climate Change (MoCC) in partnership with UN Women, UNICEF, and UNDP. Specifically, X number of young people, half of them young women, participated in an online training session conducted by UN Women that focused on human security and social cohesion in the context of climate change and climate crises. Additionally, 450 young women and men, with a 50/50 gender balance, engaged in in-person workshops that provided them with valuable experience and capacities in climate action, new solutions, and leadership. Four young women were also given the opportunity (funded by UN Women) to join the Pakistan Official Delegation to COP 28, gaining firsthand experience in the world of climate negotiations. This comprehensive training program has equipped a significant number of young people with the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute to climate action and resilience efforts in Pakistan.PCO in partnership with MOCC arranged an effective dialogue during COP28 at Pakistan Pavilion Titled: Price for Peace ‚Äì Importance of Gender Equality and Finance in climate change . Main objective of the dialogue was to present the case of Pakistan, real-life women stories of navigating in the terrain of climate crises and security risks and highlight and develop an understanding of how gender and climate change offer a potential for sustainable climate finance. Representatives from global level participated and gave insights around the topic. The discussion led to conclusion of more emphasis on involving local community in climate change and the importance of climate change and finance sector. UN Women also supported youth engagement at COP28 . The event "Youth taking a stand - Gender Responsive and inclusive climate action for sustainable climate adaptation," attracted participant across globe. This event was live broadcast and provided crucial platforms for engaging youth amplifying the call for gender-responsive and human rights-based climate policies and their implementation.
2024 Narrative: FAO Pakistan supported 8 721 farming households through the farmer field school, farmer climate school, and farmer business school approaches, enabling them to effectively manage food and commodity production systems within river basins and districts. This initiative focuses on improving water availability, efficiency, and usage to enhance agricultural and livestock practices and contribute to sustainable resource management. FAO supported and developed ten (10) business plans for agriculture and livestock value chains, covering grapes, olives, dates, fruit and vegetable drying, and tunnel farming. Initiatives within the livestock value chains included modernising dairy farming, establishing wool collection centres, improving sheep and goat fattening practices, upgrading butcher shops, and introducing a semen production unit. These efforts aimed to enhance productivity, while promoting low water use, and improving market access across the agricultural and livestock sectors.UN Women:During the reporting period, 729 women farmers enhanced their knowledge and skills in maximizing profits through marketing, value addition and post-harvest handling of agricultural produce. This initiative aims to empower women farmers by equipping them to seize profitable opportunities at local and regional levels, thereby contributing to increased household incomes.As part of UN Women's initiative to promote inclusive economic opportunities through sustainable agricultural practices, 634 women farmers haveenhanced their skills in financial literacy and savings during the reporting period in the districts of Khyber, Mohmand. These women farmers are equipped with essential financial management skills, empowering them to make informed decisions on savings and investments. The training module fosters active engagement from both women and men, creating an inclusive and supportive environment for skill development. Women selected for this training are strategically identified for their potential to maximize program impact and sustainability, enabling them to serve as future mentors for similar interventions.

2023 Narrative: Translated and tailored the Guide to develop and enhance national pesticide residue monitoring programs to align with the specific requirements and contexts of Mongolia. In cooperation with the Agro-ecology School, MULS, conducted a comprehensive soil fertility study in the central and eastern cropland region to support the MOFALI in estimating and importing the annual fertilizer quantities.
2024 Narrative: FAO, in collaboration with the Mongolian Greenhouse Farmers‚Äô Association, is developing standards for greenhouse construction and postharvest management to ensure a consistent supply of healthy, nutritious vegetables.A greenhouse vegetable module is being developed for integration into the plant.mofa.gov.mn portal to improve crop registration, enhance traceability, and boost market access.FAO translated and handed over three Codex Standards to the Mongolian Agency for Standardization and Metrology (MASM), which have since been adopted as national standards. These include: Guidelines on food safety risk analysis; Codex contact points; and Hygienic practices for fresh fruits and vegetables

2023 Narrative: 1) To support Vanuatu across various aspects of agricultural data processing and analysis, disaster assessment, and recovery efforts. This included assistance with processing and presenting the Vanuatu National Agricultural Census (VNAC 2022) data; designing and implementing the country Post-Disaster Needs Assessment (PDNA 2023) for the Productive Sector after the dual cyclone Judy and Kevin that hit the country in March 2023; and capacity development for the Vanuatu Bureau of Statistics (VBoS) staff. 2) The collaboration resulted in the utilization of census data for policy studies, feasibility assessments, updated production data, and the design of initiatives aimed at enhancing agricultural productivity in Vanuatu, ultimately contributing to evidence-based decision-making and strengthening the country's capacities. The PDNA has contributed to ascertaining damages and losses as well as supporting the development of a recovery plan.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, monitoring activities across the seven Area Councils (ACs) demonstrated that 86% of the 63 large agricultural machines procured through PIRAS funding (including 28 rotavators and 35 augers) were in use. AC users were trained to operate and maintain the machinery, and all ACs have an established committee to secure their operations and maintenance. In collaboration with the Napil Agricultural Training Center, agricultural technical trainings were extended to 5 lead farmers, on topics such as vegetable nursery techniques, tool and soil management, transplanting of crops from nurseries to farms, and crop management. The lead farmers trained were responsible to share knowledge to the other community members. This separate approach was taken because post-cyclone, it was difficult to align the community members‚Äô priorities and encourage them to attend the sessions. An additional 221 participants (63% women and 35% youth) attended a community-based tool and soil management training. In July 2023, the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) facilitated the ‚ÄòAgriculture Open Day‚Äô, where World Vision provided training to 257 beneficiaries (20% women) on the operation of machines provided by PIRAS to maximize capacities to increase productivity and reduce manual labour. Inter-island supply chains were strengthened through partnership with the Nasuaman Farmers‚Äô Association. PIRAS in Vanuatu operates in 7 communities on the Tanna Island in the Tafea province. With an initial country target of 3,600 beneficiaries (of whom 1,800 women and 1,320 youth were expected), the intervention has reached 4,974 beneficiaries (17% women and 19% youth). During Q1 2023, dual Tropical Cyclones Kevin and Judy (both Category 4) made landfall within 48 hours from one another. Participatory identification of needs and priorities in the agricultural sector

2023 Narrative: Overall MERMAID project level: A total of 3,169 beneficiaries were reached (88% of target set at design), of whom 53% women and 51% youth. The grant recipient has addressed implementation issues, by proactively demanding a grant extension and budget reallocation following implementation delays caused by tropical cyclones in March 2023. Regular Project Steering Committees were organized between Grant recipients‚Äô representatives and IFAD‚Äôs Grant Manager, to present progress and discuss challenges. A learning event was jointly attended in September 2023 in Solomon Islands, bringing together the Alliance Bioversity International ‚Äì CIAT as well as the World Vision Vanuatu and Solomon Islands implementation teams. This served to identify key milestones during the program‚Äôs last year of implementation, and identify priority for expert knowledge transfer between the Alliance and World Visions staff on the ground. Physical targets were attained and in some cases exceeded, for instance through the establishment and support to 29 saving groups (161% targets met), or facilitating the participation of 1,282 to market linkage events and exposure visits (237% targets met). In 2023, updated logframe shows 69% women involved in the nutritional behavioural change strategy design, hence including their voice in the decision-making and prioritization process. All targets under Component 2 (Innovations for investing in women) were met or exceeded in 2023. For instance, Agribusiness opportunities were identified (12 compared to 9 set at design); the agribusiness skills training material was developed and the target was exceeded through inclusion of the Basic Numeracy programme to tailor and enhance effectiveness in reaching and empowering women, given the baseline findings and in line with the programme's adaptative management. Targets were also exceeded by 237% with regards to attendees to capacity building sessions, market linkage events, competitions, and exposure visits with 64% women reached. Small grants to women (and youth) are being delivered, and so far 89% of progress has been reached; for instance these include fish cold storage, demonstration farms, poultry, piggeries, coconut processing, duck farming support have been supported through MERMAID, as identified through feasibility assessments and community consultations giving voice to women and youth.

Description: Project activities contributing to improve alignment with international best practices of quality management and control systems for exported food products will comprise a range of activities, grouped under two main clusters. The first will focus on technical training for export-oriented operators along the value chain on food safety best practices and international standards and the second on training for the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Department of Agriculture (DA) and attached agencies/bureaus to act as competent authorities for food exports to the EU. A series of webinar-based interactive sessions, training and coaching are planned under all activities, to the extent possible. ToT work will be carried out with remote supervision, targeting selected staff of export-oriented economic operators and public sector institutions. COVID-19 response will involve awareness-raising on standards and measures that can build resilience of enterprises and help recovery from the crisis. Gender equality will be given due consideration in selection of training participants and in consultative mechanisms.
Agencies: International Trade Centre
Implementation partners: Philippines Department of Trade and Industry

2021 Narrative:
"As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 157 459 (78 308 men and 79 151 women) vulnerable food insecure people in rural areas of Afghanistan with emergency agriculture assistance packages and cash based interventions under HRP 2022. A total of 28 767 (14 556 men, 14 211 women) vulnerable people were supported with summer crop seeds and trained on related technical trainings. Similarly, 121 411 (60 185 men and 61 226 women) vulnerable people benefited from home gardening packages and related technical trainings. A total of 7 281 (3567 men and 3714 women) vulnerable people benefited from cash for work activities. Overall, a total of 7 919 people belonging to 849 households headed by people with disability benefitted from FAO implemented activities. 

As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 943 152 vulnerable food insecure people under HRP 2021 projects carried forward to 2022 with (i) certified seed of improved and locally adapted wheat varieties for the spring planting season and related technical training; (ii) animal feed and technical trainings on livestock best management practices; (iii) home gardening packages and related technical trainings; (iv) summer crop seeds and related technical trainings; (v) cash for work activities and unconditional cash transfers; (vi) COVID-19 awareness raising sessions.  

FAO financial delivery  under TEF Outcome 1 under HRP 2022 between January - June 2022 is USD 12,103,796. 
FAO carry-forward from HRP 2021 financial delivery between January -June 2022 is USD 22,958,955."
2022 Narrative: In 2022, FAO supported 3,853,801 vulnerable people with critical wheat seed assistance packages to protect food and nutrition security and sustain agriculture based livelihoods. Emergency assistance package comprised of 50 Kg certified wheat seed, 50 Kg of DAP fertilizer and 50 Kg of urea fertilizer per household, combined with technical training conducted in rural areas of 31 provinces of Afghanistan. In order to achieve this number of households reached, FAO procured 27,527 MT (wheat seed), 35,004 MT (urea as some carry forwarded amount of urea from 2021 also distributed in 2022) and 23,899.65 MT (DAP) and timely distributed to vulnerable households for the reporting period. This is expected to increase wheat production in the country and contribute to safeguarding food and nutrition security of vulnerable people from the impact of recent natural and economic shocks.
2023 Narrative: During the reporting period, FAO supported 201,166 people with wheat cultivation packages to protect food and nutrition security and sustain agriculture-based livelihoods. Each assistance package comprised 50 kg of high-quality locally-adapted certified wheat seeds, 50 kg of Diammonium Phosphate (DAP), 50 kg of Urea fertilizers, and technical training on wheat cultivation methods. The package produces sufficient food for a household for one year and continues to provide direct benefits for 3-4 years.

Sub-Output: Assessing the impact of the global crisis on the agriculture and food security situation in Nepal
Description: The major objective of this joint programme is to assess the impact of the global crisis on Nepal?s food system, food security, household level agriculture and income, livestock production, food and essential commodity prices and market functionality, and to explore the impact of the crisis on Nepal's progress towards achieving SDG targets (mainly SDG 2). The differential impact the crisis has on urban and rural households and chronically vulnerable groups will also be assessed and analyzed. WFP and FAO will build on existing tools and systems for food security monitoring and emergency impact assessments (a combination of household surveys, market assessments and desk reviews as well as consultations with relevant stakeholders), with the evidence generated shared with the Government, development and humanitarian partners and other stakeholders to inform the design of potential response plans and strategic interventions by humanitarian and development agencies, as well as to inform Government policies, plans and programmes.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: National Planning Commission Nepal

2021 Narrative: In 2021, WFP worked with national and state governments to develop and roll out information campaigns to increase awareness of new components of the TPDS, and a web-based learning management system for government staff. WFP also provided technical support for analysis of supply chain networks and their optimization and introduced a GPS-based tracking system for grain transportation. WFP also introduced innovations such as mobile storage units and internet of things (IoT), SMART warehouses for reducing post-harvest losses in government procurement systems. The automated grain dispensing machine (Annapurti) which WFP developed in 2020 was approved by the Government and piloted in two states.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, WFP continued to strengthen the efficiency and effectiveness of the government‚Äôs food-based safety nets under the National Food Security Act by providing capacity strengthening and technical support to the government and its staff. WFP rolled out the e-learning system for government staff, expanded the pilot of Annapurti, the automated grain dispensing machine, supply chain optimization and GPS-based tracking systems to reduce transportation costs and carbon emissions, piloted internet-of-things (IoT)-enabled smart warehouses and continued to pilot the use of mobile storage units to reduce storage losses for government stocks. In addition, WFP provided technical support and innovation to increase social and financial mobility of women in self-help groups in Odisha.

2021 Narrative: In collaboration with Government of Rajasthan, WFP is developing the report to monitor and assess the status of food and nutrition security in the Rajasthan. Besides, WFP is piloting a real time remote food and nutrition security monitoring and assessment system in a small vulnerable geography of Rajasthan to support evidence-based decision-making. WFP in partnership with DMEO of NITI Aayog is contributing to the joint review of the National Food Security Act in the country
2022 Narrative: At the Central government, WFP in partnership with DMEO, NITI Aayog, is contributing to the joint multi-ministerial review of the flagship National Food Security Act in the country. WFP is also supporting DMEO to build the national curriculum and competencies on monitoring and evaluation to strengthen the capacities of in-service government officers. WFP has also supported DMEO in implementing the national ME curriculum and facilitating sessions as part of the One-Week Residential Training of Senior In-Service Government Officers in July 2022 at NILERD. At the State level, WFP is engaged in strengthening the capacities of two State governments. WFP is collaborating with the Government of Rajasthan (GoR) to develop a dashboard for monitoring SDG-2; prepare a comprehensive food and nutrition security (FNS) report and dashboard as a tool to support decision-makers; and piloting a remote FNS monitoring tool in a focussed geography to support effective tracking of critical indicators. WFP has also undertaken multiple workshops to strengthen the capacities of state evaluation office in Rajasthan. In Odisha, WFP is engaged in generating and disseminating evidence on thematic areas of SDG-2 and jointly assessing several state-led FNS initiatives.

WHO in collaboration with the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India and FAO, undertook an action-oriented social media campaign to promote food safety awareness in the country as part of celebrations for the second World Food Safety Day (WFSD) 2020. WHO implemented a multi-country Codex project for advocacy and training on institutionalizing codex standards and procedures in India, Nepal and Bhutan.

2021 Narrative: Provided technical support to the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI) for assessment of Data Systems for Food and Agriculture related SDG Indicators in select States of India. An LoA was also signed between the FAO India and the Society for Social and Economic Research (SSER) for providing technical support for estimating SDG indicators using recently released data from ‚Äò‚ÄôNational Surveys on Land and Livestock Holdings of Households and Situation Assessment of Agricultural Households‚Äù. A virtual workshop on FIES organized in February 2021 through virtual mode, and outcome of the workshop was circulated to the relevant stakeholders. Based on FAO recommendations, a technical group on FIES was constituted by the MoSPI in July 2021 but it is still not functional due to some interdepartmental concerns in the MoSPI.  Subsequently, a workshop on Food Balance Sheet was also organized jointly by the FAO and MoSPI in October 2021.
2022 Narrative: The project ‚ÄúAssessment of Data Systems for Food and Agriculture related SDG Indicators in select States of India‚Äù continued to build national and state capacities to monitor SDGs related to food and agriculture, and align national and state indicator frameworks with the global indicator framework for the SDGs. Under this project, FAO (1) produced a "Methodological Note for Pilot Surveys on the Food Insecurity Experience Scale"; (2) Analyzed the survey methodology and the data of the NSS 77th round of LLH-SAAH and produced a "Report on the assessment of suitability of the NSS 77th round for reporting farm-survey-based SDG indicators and proposals for modifications in the future rounds of the LLH-SAAH Surveys"; (3) Conducted a training for Government officials on preparation of Supply Utilization Accounts and Food Balance Sheets; (4) With the help of a "Report on the Estimation of Indicators 2.3.1 and 2.3.2 using data from the ‚ÄúLand and Livestock Holdings of Households and Situation Assessment of Agricultural Households‚Äù (LLH SAAH)" generated state-level estimates of SDG indicators 2.3.1 and 2.3.2; (5) In response to the Government‚Äôs request, examined the SDG Global Indicator 5.a.2 in select states of India and produced a report to explore the scope of its possible inclusion in the India‚Äôs National Indicator Framework.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Nutrition and Food Security
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - Nutrition and Food Security
Output: Output 4.1.3 - By 2022, in UN supported states, government and partners have enhanced capacity to increase agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers
Sub-Output: 4.1.3.5 - Facilitate National Dialogue: Indian Agriculture Towards 2030: Pathways for Enhancing Farmers‚Äô Income, Improving Nutritional Security and Achieving Sustainable Food Systems in the context
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Ministry of Agriculture and Farmer's Welfare; Niti Aayog
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
2021 Narrative: FAO India is closely collaborating with the NITI Aayog and the MoA&FW to coorganised a high-level policy dialogue through 2019-2022. For this a Steering Committee was set up with the Member (Agriculture) of NITI Aayog chairing the committee and several agricultural and food experts as members. Under the guidance of the Committee, eight priority themes were identified and authors were commissioned to write thematic papers for the dialogue. The papers were opened for public comment at a virtual conference held through 19-22 January 2021. The papers were revised based on the feedback from discussants and participants. Two outputs from this dialogue process are being finalised: a set of policy briefs and an open access book to be published by Springer
2022 Narrative: The book titled: Indian Agriculture Towards 2030: Pathways for Enhancing Farmers‚Äô Income, Nutritional Security and Sustainable Food and Farm Systems,   was published through Springer in early 2022. The book carries a foreword by the Honourable Vice President of India, Shri M Venkaiah Naidu. The book was released at a public event of the National Dialogue: Indian Agriculture Towards 2030: co-organised by the NITI Aayog and the FAO on   28 March 2022 at the India International Centre, New Delhi. The Honourable Union Minister of Agriculture and Farmers‚Äô Welfare, Shri Narendra Singh Tomar, released the book. As an open-access publication, the book is available for free download on the SpringerLink website: https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-981-19-0763-0    Additionally, FAO collated the recommendations emerging from the thematic discussion papers prepared of the National Dialogue into a set of nine policy briefs with key messages for the transformative shift in agri-food systems to achieve the SDGs. The policy briefs are addressed to the central and state governments, as well as relevant public institutions and suggest possible pathways for transforming agriculture in India.

Implementation partners: Iranian Red Crescent Society

Geography: West Azerbaijan; Iran, Islamic Republic of; Khoy
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: After the earthquake of Khoy on 28 January 2024, a UN Inter-agency team comprising 12 UN personnel from UNICEF, UNFPA, UNHCR, IOM, UNDP, WFP, WHO, UNESCO, UNIC, and UNDSS conducted a comprehensive assessment in the affected areas on February 6th, 2023, in response to a request from the National Disaster Management Organization via the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The UN assessment mission to Khoy identified that there is a need for disaster relief and transitional assistance for the affected population.WFP Iran Country Office mobilized USD 200k immediately and procured 2,445 Family Food packages and delivered to the Iranian Red Crescent Society (IRCS) under a bilateral Letter of Intent on March 1st-2nd , 2023. These packages included essential items such as rice, canned pinto beans, canned Tuna fish, green lentils, pinto beans, cube sugar, veg. oil, sugar, tea, and purified salt and were designed to meet the one-month food requirements of a family of four.

Description: Vulnerable people in disaster-affected or at-risk areas have enhanced food and nutrition security all year round and increased capacity to mitigate and manage risks associated with climate and other shocks by 2026. This will be achieved by improving community capacities in managing climate shocks and risks through i) access to climate /weather information; ii) use of climate resilient livelihoods practices; iii) climate resilient assets protecting the community against climate related shocks; iv) access to risk transfer transfer mechanisms and contingency funding. v) strengthening the capacity of local authorities and communities to prepare for, respond to and recover from disasters.

Gender marker narrative: WFP fully integrated gender into the implementation of activities, as evidenced by the GAM score of 3. Resilience-building activities ensured that assistance was tailored to the needs and interests of beneficiaries and reflected gender-inclusive participation, as well as consideration of the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities. Plan name: UN Socioeconomic and Peacebuilding Framework for COVID-19 Recovery in the Philippines 2020-2023
Strategic priority: Prosperity and Planet
Outcome: Urbanization, economic growth, and climate change actions are converging for a resilient, equitable, and sustainable development path for communities.
Output: Output 6: Resilience strengthened in all sectors and all levels of government
Sub-Output: Conducted Climate Change and Food Security Analysis and developed livelihood zone and climate suitability maps.
Description:
As part of the Climate Change and Food Security Analysis, WFP together with CIAT developed livelihood zone and climate suitability maps that can provide national agencies and provincial governments with important data-driven insights to inform the design of tailored climate change adaptation and mitigation measures. Key outputs of the CCFSA include:
i) the first-ever Livelihood Zones Map available at the city and municipal level for the whole country;
ii) a database of 71 indicators including crop suitability data based on medium- and long-term climate projections for key types of crops, a climate risk index for selected natural hazards, socio-economic indicators and rural-urban dynamics.
iii) 4 regional livelihood zone maps (MIMAROPA, BARRM and SOCCSKSARGEN, Zamboanga Peninsula) validated by the Gov‚Äôt and analysed in regional-level reports.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: World Food Programme Multi-donor
SDG Targets: 17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.

2023 Narrative: Achievements:The National Framework for Weather, Climate, and Ocean Services (NFWCOS) was finalized for Tuvalu and Niue. The National Strategic Plan for Weather, Water, and Climate Services (NSPWWCS) Implementation Plan was finalized for Palau, with a draft for RMI. Engagement with stakeholders during NFWCOS consultations involved 188 participants across three countries (101 males, 87 females) Niue - 49 participants (22 male, 27 female, Palau - 35 participants (18 males, 17 females, RMI -20 participants (16 males, 4 females and Tuvalu 61 participants (28 males, 33 females).  Additionally, 141 stakeholders (74 males, 67 females) participated in the National Climate Outlook Forum (NCOF) across Palau, Cook Islands, and Tuvalu in Palau on 17 ‚Äì 18, April 2023  The onboarding of fixed-term local consultants for Palau and RMI completed, contributing to the establishment of National Programme Implementation Managers and Finance Officers. International consultant was also engaged for a Climate Services Market Assessment across the five countries.Completed 8% of the Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) installation with four (4) AWS installed: 2 in Niue,2 in Tuvalu.Nine (9) AWS shipped and awaiting installation in Cook Islands (2),Tuvalu (20 and Palau (5). Seven (7) AWS assembled and to be shipped for Tuvalu (4) and Cook Islands (2-3). . Ongoing work on designing and planning for the Automated Weather Observation Systems (AWOS) to be installed under the programme. Completed maintenance and returned to service 9 existing AWS across 8 different islands in Cook Islands. Progress ongoing for 10 wave buoys to be installed through the programme with the deployment of 1 wave buoy in Niue,, 9 buoys awaiting deployment to Cook Islands (4), Tuvalu (4), and Niue (1), with ongoing procurement for Palau (1). Preparatory meetings and arrangements conducted between Tuvalu Met Service, Public Works Department and Climate Change Department on the design and process for the construction of the Met Offices in the 5 outer islands, with the construction of 2 Met Offices scheduled for 2024. Eight regional technical trainings and attachments conducted to enhance the technical capacity of the NMHS staff from the 5 countries.Coordination meetings, virtual data harmonization efforts, and alignment with regional strategies were part of ongoing activities.Challenges:Delayed implementation due to challenges in recruitment of key staffLogistic challenges due to limited transportation options available to the outer islands. Budget constraints given costs increased since programme developed

Plan name: Transitional Engagement Framework (TEF)
Strategic priority: Priority 1
Outcome: TEF Outcome 1:  More people in Afghanistan will have benefitted from life-saving humanitarian assistance that enable them to live in safety and dignity  [Saving lives]
Output: 1.3  Provide and protect inclusive critical/lifesaving livelihood interventions of families and communities, particularly in rural areas.
Sub-Output: 1.3.5 Vulnerable food insecure farmers and herders (women and men) in rural areas benefit from critical livestock assistance packages to protect food and nutrition security and sustain agro/livestock based livelihoods
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Asian Development Bank; European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; Government of Italy; Government of Japan; Government of Norway; Government of Sweden; Japan International Cooperation Agency; The World Bank; United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: Local and international NGOs
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
"As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 157 459 (78 308 men and 79 151 women) vulnerable food insecure people in rural areas of Afghanistan with emergency agriculture assistance packages and cash based interventions under HRP 2022. A total of 28 767 (14 556 men, 14 211 women) vulnerable people were supported with summer crop seeds and trained on related technical trainings. Similarly, 121 411 (60 185 men and 61 226 women) vulnerable people benefited from home gardening packages and related technical trainings. A total of 7 281 (3567 men and 3714 women) vulnerable people benefited from cash for work activities. Overall, a total of 7 919 people belonging to 849 households headed by people with disability benefitted from FAO implemented activities. 

As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 943 152 vulnerable food insecure people under HRP 2021 projects carried forward to 2022 with (i) certified seed of improved and locally adapted wheat varieties for the spring planting season and related technical training; (ii) animal feed and technical trainings on livestock best management practices; (iii) home gardening packages and related technical trainings; (iv) summer crop seeds and related technical trainings; (v) cash for work activities and unconditional cash transfers; (vi) COVID-19 awareness raising sessions.  

FAO financial delivery  under TEF Outcome 1 under HRP 2022 between January - June 2022 is USD 12,103,796. 
FAO carry-forward from HRP 2021 financial delivery between January -June 2022 is USD 22,958,955."
2022 Narrative: In 2022, FAO supported 1,186,577 vulnerable food insecure people with critical livestock assistance packages in rural areas of 25 provinces of the country to protect food and nutrition security and sustain agriculture/livestock based livelihoods. The livestock protection package consists of 200 Kg of concentrate animal feed, 3 kg of high quality fast growing fodder crop seed along with deworming medicine support for up to 30 animals and linkage to local veterinary extension services per household. In 2022, FAO distributed 33,902 MT of animal feed, as well as 377 MT of fodder crop seed to sustainably cultivate and feed their livestock. This livestock package contributes to the protection of food and nutrition security and sustain agriculture/livestock based livelihoods.
2023 Narrative: During the reporting period, FAO assisted 1,811,040 small-scale herders with livestock protection support. Each assistance package comprised 200 kg of animal feed, fodder crop seeds to produce livestock feed, de-wormer medicine, and technical training on livestock management. The livestock package contributes to the protection of food and nutrition security and sustains agriculture/livestock-based livelihoods.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 5 - Natural resource management, community resilience, and energy efficiency
Outcome: Outcome 5.1 - Natural resource management, community resilience, and energy efficiency
Output: Output 5.1.2 - Effective solutions and capacities built at national, subnational and sectoral levels for sustainable management of natural resources and ecosystems, chemicals and wastes and effluents
Sub-Output: 5.1.2.12 - Support implementation of gender sensitive and poverty focused climate resilient agriculture practices and market interventions to support food production and livelihoods in the north eastern states of Nagaland and Mizoram
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Fund for Agricultural Development
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Fund for Agricultural Development; Non-core funds
Implementation partners: Government of Mizoram; Government of Nagaland
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In the IFAD-funded FOCUS project, FAO provided technical assistance to the state governments of Mizoram and Nagaland in 2021. The project's goals include promoting sustainable jhum cultivation, assisting with livestock development, and developing value chains. FAO collaborated with the North Eastern Space Application Centre (NESAC) in 2021 to create an agroclimatic atlas for the project districts of Nagaland and Mizoram. The agroclimatic maps will be used to plan effective land use. FAO has also assisted in the development of curricula and training materials for Master Trainers and Trainers on supporting sustainable farming and introducing innovative production technology. FAO has also aided in the delivery of training content to farmers via a cascaded capacity development approach. Additionally in 2020, FAO completed the household survey covering over 3,200 households in Nagaland and over 1,600 household in Mizoram to inform the baseline of the project. The MIS for project effective monitoring and reporting has been developed and deployed. In May 2021, a virtual awareness training programme on ‚ÄúFall Army Worm management in Maize in Nagaland‚Äù was organized jointly by FAO, Department of Plan protection, quarantine and storage and Indian Institute of maize research.
FAO also directly supported the FOCUS project through its technical assistance programme. In 2021, studies on Sustainable Jhum in Nagaland and Mizoram, Livestock Development in Mizoram, and Millet Analysis in Nagaland were conducted under this programme. The Sustainable Jhum study reports are being finalised, while other reports have been submitted to the project States. A guidebook on Nagaland's Community Seed Bank has also been created and shared with the state for feedback. The Nagaland FOCUS Project team was taken on an exposure visit to Karnal, Haryana. The purpose of the visit was to demonstrate and provide exposure to the new and improved potato seed production technologies.
2022 Narrative: In the IFAD-funded FOCUS project, FAO provided technical assistance to the state governments of Mizoram and Nagaland for promoting sustainable jhum cultivation, assisting with livestock development, and developing value chains. Under this project, FAO trained 78 Master Trainers in Mizoram and 91 in Nagaland. The Master Trainers (MTs), who were the State and district level officials from different departments of Mizoram and Nagaland state, used the same training process and resources to train the Block/ Circle Officers and village-level workers in their respective districts with technical backstopping of FAO experts. The block, circle, and village level staff, in turn, trained the lead farmers (CRPs and CAHWs). Gender parity amongst trainees at all levels was emphasized.               	The project also documented the importance of the jhum system of farming, its impacts on people‚Äôs livelihoods and ecosystems, and the options to make this unique system sustainable and profitable. The various Sloping Agriculture Land Technology (SALT) and Soil and Water Conservation (SWC) technologies have great potential to address the issues of erosion and declining soil fertility in sloping areas. Likewise, improved agronomic practices (e.g. crop rotation, intercropping, integrated pest management, and integrated nutrient management), terrace cultivation, and better livestock practices can contribute to increased income.

2021 Narrative:
Food Systems Summit
FAO supported the Ministry of National Food Security and Research in conducting National Food Systems Summit Dialogues, identifying game changing solutions for the transformation of food systems and preparation of the final report. The ideas, solutions, partnerships and action plans generated in the National Level Dialogues were critical to the Summit‚Äôs success and Pakistan was represented by the Minister of National Food Security and Research in the Global Food Systems Summit. FAO in collaboration with Pakistan Institute of Development Economics (PIDE) and Ministry of National Food Security and Research (MNFSR), organized a private food system summit dialogue and presented findings of 5 research studies on Sustainable Food System in Pakistan.

Food Control Act
FAO prepared Draft Assessment of National Food Control System report and validation workshop due in December 2021. The work comprised of capacity assessment of stakeholders and gap analysis of the legislations currently in use by provincial and federal governments. Assessment of National Codex System was also conducted and draft report is available. Advocacy meetings/ workshops for harmonization of food standards, establishing national Codex programme and strengthening the national food control system conducted. The draft Food Control Act on Federal level is being formulated.
