Plan name: UNDAF/OP III (2018-2022)
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 5 - Food Security
Outcome: Outcome 5.1 - By 22, children, adolescent girls and pregnant and lactating women have improved availability of, access to, and consumption of safe, nutritious and sufficient food, while promoting sustainable management of cultural and natural resources.
Output: Output 5.1.5 - Livelihoods rebuilt through the rehabilitation of agriculture, natural resource management and food assistance for assets (FFA) including offering of food and cash assistance, coupled with agriculture and livestock inputs, in response to shocks, disasters, or displacement.
Sub-Output: 5.1.5.1 - Provide humanitarian assistance to meet the basic food and nutrition needs of the most vulnerable populations affected by disaster - WFP
Description: During and after a major disaster where WFP assistance is required and requested, WFP will provide relief support through unconditional transfers  and early recovery support through conditional transfers. Assistance modalities will primarily be cash and/or food transfers, using cash when feasible; especially where markets are stable and have sufficient supply and security and implementation arrangements permit.  WFP will maintain its emergency response capacity and support clusters and working groups related to humanitarian coordination. When appropriate, WFP will support the government to operationalize its safety nets and other response mechanisms for relief. WFP will apply lessons from past experiences and assessment analysis to ensure accountability to affected populations and consider the specific needs and concerns of women, men, girls, boys and any specific vulnerable groups that may arise as a result of a crisis situation and intervention.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Adaptation Fund; Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development; CERD; CRDO; NRSP; TF Pakistam
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
2021 Narrative:
WFP continues its unwavering commitment to ensure that all conflict and hazard-affected people across the country have adequate food and nutrition. In 2021, WFP was able to retain its position as a key partner of choice for the host Government, for providing lifesaving relief food assistance along with recovery support to disaster-affected people across the country.  
In 2021, WFP continued its cash-based relief response for the families that were affected by heavy monsoon rainfall in the Sindh province in 2020, and those affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and other shocks in the most vulnerable districts of Balochistan, Sindh, and  Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP). The provision of relief food assistance to families that remained displaced in KP province also continued in 2021. All three interventions were concluded in the first half of the year. In the latter half of the year, upon request from the host Government, WFP provided life-saving food assistance to families that were affected by heavy rainfall and flash flooding in three districts of KP. All these interventions were implemented at the behest of and in close collaboration with all relevant government departments at the federal and provincial levels.  
 
Nearly all beneficiaries targeted under these cash-based responses were successfully supported in 2021. With regards to the interventions implemented using the food-based modality, WFP successfully phased out all families that remained displaced in KP upon their return to their areas of origin. In the latter half of the year, WFP was compelled to provide reduced rations to the people affected by the flooding in the northern districts of KP province, due to funding shortfalls.

Overall WFP provided assistance to 422,949 beneficiaries by distributing 4,750 MT food and US$ 4.42 million cash. The WFP assistance helped assisted population to main its acceptable food consumption levels and avoid negative coping strategies to meet their needs.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, WFP was in the final year of its five-year Country Strategic Plan (CSP 2018-2022) and remained committed to its core mandate of ensuring that all conflict- and hazard-affected populations in Pakistan have adequate food and nutrition. This encompassed the provision of lifesaving relief food/cash assistance to flood affected families. In the last quarter of 2022, WFP responded to a flood emergency under emergency response and livelihoods support across 04 provinces of Pakistan. Upon request of the host government, WFP immediately mobilized available resources and in-country food stocks to ensure the timely provision of food assistance to the calamity-stricken people across Pakistan. WFP prioritized 2.7 million IPC 3  4 classified people for the provision of assistance, using both food and cash-based modalities. By the end of the year, WFP provided unconditional assistance to 3.1 million flood affected people including Pregnant and Lactating Women and Children from 6-23 months through provision of Ready to Use Supplementary food. It provided 62,645 MT food US$ 7,612,600 cash assistance. Out of the total targeted households, 31 percent were provided assistance through registration of females‚Äô family members.

Plan name: UNDAF/OP III (2018-2022)
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 5 - Food Security
Outcome: Outcome 5.1 - By 22, children, adolescent girls and pregnant and lactating women have improved availability of, access to, and consumption of safe, nutritious and sufficient food, while promoting sustainable management of cultural and natural resources.
Output: Output 5.1.5 - Livelihoods rebuilt through the rehabilitation of agriculture, natural resource management and food assistance for assets (FFA) including offering of food and cash assistance, coupled with agriculture and livestock inputs, in response to shocks, disasters, or displacement.
Sub-Output: 5.1.5.2 - Support affected populations during the early recovery phase to address food insecurity and rebuild livelihoods - WFP
Description:
WFP will support the construction and repair of community assets through Food Assistance for Asset activities to increase access to food and support early recovery and rehabilitation of livelihoods of the most food-insecure in disaster-affected areas, particularly temporarily dislocated households returning to FATA. Such projects will follow WFP‚Äôs Food Assistance for Assets guidance manual, including application of the three-pronged approach and fostering participation by a wide-range of community representatives. An environmental screening will ensure that activities are designed to factor in environmental concerns. In mobilizing beneficiaries, WFP will work with its cooperating partners to engage women in the projects, including fostering gender balance on project management committees; actively supporting women to participate in activity design; community-based operation and management of the assets; and promoting shared decision-making on the use of cash/food and responsibility for household food security and nutrition._x000D_
60.	Both activities 1 and 2 will be implemented, under the overall supervision of the relevant government authority (e.g., the FATA Disaster Management Authority and the FATA Secretariat), through NGOs with the requisite technical capacity, while building the capacity of local responders. WFP will collaborate with relevant line departments and UN partners, particularly FAO, UNDP, UNICEF and UNHCR, wherever feasible.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Central Emergency Response Fund; Regular Resources
Implementation partners: Adaptation Fund; Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development; BRSP; FRD; SIF; SRSP; TF Pakistam; WEO
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
2021 Narrative:
WFP food assistance for assets/livelihood interventions focused on facilitating the recovery of families affected by multiple hazards and shocks including the COVID-19 pandemic, floods, droughts, and locust outbreaks. The families in the KP province that had recently returned to their areas of origin after a prolonged period of displacement were provided with recovery support. These activities provide direct conditional cash-based transfers to meet the consumption gap; and simultaneously build household and community assets that reduce the risk of disasters, strengthen livelihoods, and build resilience. All activities followed nature-based approaches adapted specifically to the local context. These programmes supported the improvement of anticipatory, absorptive, and longer-term adaptive capacities of the targeted households. Overall WFP supported 21,944 households or 142,636 through its cash assistance programme by distributing US$2.8 million cash assistance. Out of these households, 35 percent were supported through women participation.
 
These interventions were implemented in close coordination with relevant Government line departments at the federal, provincial and district level. In addition, the targeted communities were heavily engaged at all levels of programme implementation. All partners, relevant Government staff and members of community-level bodies formed to facilitate the implementation of these programmes were engaged in training and orientation sessions relating to the implementation modalities, selection criteria and programmatic outcomes of these interventions.
2022 Narrative: WFP continued recovery interventions through food assistance for assets (FFA) in order to support and help disaster-stricken communities rehabilitate their lives and livelihoods and build resilience. This response was implemented in two contexts. The first prioritized food-insecure districts in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan provinces adjacent to the Pak-Afghan border. The other was implemented in Sindh and AJK province, targeting food-insecure households that were impacted by multiple hazards. WFP‚Äôs livelihood support complemented the Government‚Äôs efforts to stabilize the Afghan border host communities‚Äô areas and contribute to economic growth and peace in the region. Under this component, WFP provided assistance to 902,000 individuals by providing 20,428 MT food and US$ 3,078,800 cash assistance. Out of the total assisted households, 33 percent were targeted through women participation.FFA interventions were implemented in close coordination with relevant government entities, with the targeted communities actively engaged in decision-making processes, not least concerning the identification of assistance recipients. Village profiles were developed for all targeted villages. Female staff interviewed women specifically while generating these profiles to ensure that their needs are appropriately reflected and translated into context-specific activities or training sessions that benefit them. The selection of beneficiaries within the selected villages is conducted in due consultation with the communities, using a community-based participatory approach, and in accordance with the pre-defined eligibility criteria. Engaging the community in the selection of beneficiary households helps in the identification and engagement of the most vulnerable households in the targeted villages, while simultaneously increasing awareness and acceptance of the eligibility criteria. The schemes supported the harnessing and management of natural resources, increased agricultural production, improved access to markets, and the development of income-boosting skills.The schemes supported the harnessing and management of natural resources, increased agricultural production, improved access to markets, and the development of income-boosting skills.

2021 Narrative: FAO conducted two IPC Acute Food Insecurity trainings/analysis workshops: in March 2021 for 19 districts of Sindh and Balochistan, and in October 2021 for 25 districts of Sindh, Balochistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa; and one IPC Acute Malnutrition training/analysis workshop in August 2021 for 9 districts of Sindh. Three workshops were attended by 93 government and non-government stakeholders. Based on the IPC Acute Food Insecurity and IPC Acute Malnutrition analysis, FAO prepared five province specific acute food insecurity and one acute malnutrition analysis reports. FAO also conducted one round of household assessment and two rounds of key informants interviews of food traders, agriculture inputs dealers, agriculture and livestock officials in 25 vulnerable districts across 3 provinces (Sindh, Balochistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa) in April/May and July/August 2021.

2021 Narrative:
FAO
Web-based Food Security and Nutrition Information System functional at the national level
FAO continued to support the Government of Pakistan (Ministry of National Food Security and Research) to opertionalise web-based Food Security and Nutrition Information System (FSNIS). FSNIS is a web based platform for food security and other relevant data including a Food Price Dashboard which will enable Government to track anomalies in supply chain and prices across Pakistan. Under analytical products of FSNIS developed in 2021, are the Pakistan Food Forecast (Kharif 2021 and Rabi season 2021-22) report which provides situation analysis and forecasts for 5 major Rabi crops (Wheat, Potato, Gram pulse, Lentil (Masoor pulse) and Rapeseed &Mustard) and 6 major Kharif crops (Rice, Maize, Mung pulse, Mash pulse, Sugarcane and Cotton). As support to the Government of Pakistan in the wake of Covid-19 pandemic, FAO continued producing Weekly Price Bulletins on evolution of food prices of major food items since the outbreak in February 2020, keeping anset of Covid-19 and subsequent lockdown as benchmark. 
FAO organized two stakeholders consultation workshop on the findings of Pakistan Food Forecast (Kharif 2021); and data validation and training-cum- consultation on Findings of Pakistan Food Forecast report (Rabi 2021-22). 47 officials (6 women) from different national and provincial government departments participated. FAO in collaboration with WFP, UNICEF and WHO published Pakistan Overview of Food Security and Nutrition (POFI) 2020 report in October 2021 which is in line with the global and regional reports on State of Food Security and Nutrition and useful to monitor the food insecurity and malnutrition situation in the country.

Gender marker narrative: Women play a vital role in agriculture but often face gender-based constraints, limiting their opportunities and benefits. This initiative ensures gender mainstreaming across all activities, with a 40% target for gender inclusivity in areas such as sustainable food systems, value chains, and landscape management, promoting equity at all levels from officers to farmers.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Youth; Women & Girls; Peasants & Rural Workers; Indigenous Peoples
2023 Narrative: As a part of the UNEP global project titled ‚ÄúThe Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity: Promoting a Sustainable Agriculture and Food Sector‚Äù funded by the European Union and implemented in seven countries from 2019-2023, UNEP supported the Indian government in generating evidence for scaling sustainable agriculture practices in India through economic valuation. As per the need identified by the Project Steering Committee (PSC), co-led by the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare (MoAFW) and Ministry of Environment Forests and Climate Change (MoEFCC), the TEEB AgriFood framework has been applied towards assessing and valuing the environmental and socioeconomic implications of scaling organic farming and agroforestry in Uttarakhand, Uttar Pradesh and Assam. The results of the project were shared periodically with a range of stakeholders, including the NITI Aayog and the Ministry of Jal Shakti (Water Resources) and State Agriculture and Forest Departments to assess their usability for evidence-based decision-making on sustainable food and agriculture systems in India. The assessment included modeling and economic valuation exercises for various scenarios from 2020 till 2050.

Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Asian Development Bank; European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; Government of Denmark; Government of Japan; Government of New Zealand; Government of the Republic of Korea; Japan International Cooperation Agency; The World Bank; United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
Implementation partners: Local and international NGOs
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2021 Narrative:
"As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 157 459 (78 308 men and 79 151 women) vulnerable food insecure people in rural areas of Afghanistan with emergency agriculture assistance packages and cash based interventions under HRP 2022. A total of 28 767 (14 556 men, 14 211 women) vulnerable people were supported with summer crop seeds and trained on related technical trainings. Similarly, 121 411 (60 185 men and 61 226 women) vulnerable people benefited from home gardening packages and related technical trainings. A total of 7 281 (3567 men and 3714 women) vulnerable people benefited from cash for work activities. Overall, a total of 7 919 people belonging to 849 households headed by people with disability benefitted from FAO implemented activities. 

As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 943 152 vulnerable food insecure people under HRP 2021 projects carried forward to 2022 with (i) certified seed of improved and locally adapted wheat varieties for the spring planting season and related technical training; (ii) animal feed and technical trainings on livestock best management practices; (iii) home gardening packages and related technical trainings; (iv) summer crop seeds and related technical trainings; (v) cash for work activities and unconditional cash transfers; (vi) COVID-19 awareness raising sessions.  

FAO financial delivery  under TEF Outcome 1 under HRP 2022 between January - June 2022 is USD 12,103,796. 
FAO carry-forward from HRP 2021 financial delivery between January -June 2022 is USD 22,958,955."
2022 Narrative: In the reporting period, FAO supported 238,840 vulnerable food insecure particularly female people with home gardening packages, 71,750 people with summer crops packages and 104,923 people with poultry packages. These varied interventions are to protect food and nutrition security and sustain agro/livestock based livelihoods.
2023 Narrative: During the reporting period, FAO supported 923,643 landless and highly food-insecure people (particularly female-headed households) with home gardening vegetable production packages, 47,103 people with summer crop production packages, and 96,341 people with backyard poultry production packages.In the meantime, in order to protect food and nutrition security and sustain agro/livestock-based livelihoods, FAO assisted 293,139 people with small farm equipment packages, 41,671 people with soybean cultivation packages, 525 people with micro-greenhouses, 315 people with backyard mushroom production packages, and 329 people with solar dryers.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Planet
Outcome: By 2025, environmental sustainability and resilience are mainstreamed as priorities within the national development agenda, across all sectors and levels of society.
Output: Transitioning national development towards a decarbonised pathway and a resource efficient economy through the adoption of green growth strategies and practices across all sectors.
Sub-Output: TEEB for Agriculture and Food ('TEEBAgriFood') Promoting biodiversity and sustainability in the agriculture and food sector through economic valuation
Description:
The TEEBAgriFood initiative in Malaysia is steered by the Government of Malaysia, Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security (MAFS).  UNEP signed a Small Scale Funding Agreement (SSFA) with the Malaysia Agriculture and Research Development Institute (MARDI) in August 2022.  

TEEB for Agriculture and Food ('TEEBAgriFood') Promoting biodiversity and sustainability in the agriculture and food sector through economic valuation.The assessment will reveal the economic benefits of adopting myGAP in the vegetable production sector, for instance in terms of enhanced water quality, reduced climate emissions, and improvements to human health.  Once these benefits have been estimated through a scenario analysis, a case could be made for interventions to promote farmer adoption of the myGAP Standard. Implementing partners are : the Ministry for Agriculture and Food Security (KPKM), Malaysia Agricultural Research and Development Institute (MARDI)
Agencies: United Nations Environment Programme
Implementation partners: Malaysian Agricultural Research and Development Institute
SDG Targets: 15.9 By 2020, integrate ecosystem and biodiversity values into national and local planning, development processes, poverty reduction strategies and accounts.
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: The inception workshop (in Dec 2020) discussed a longlist of topic and location options for the focus of the TEEBAgriFood analysis focus. These were presented to the Steering Committee in 2021 which selected the topic of improving agrofood certification systems through MyGAP or MyOrganic in the Cameron Highlands District.
2022 Narrative: MARDI initiated TEEBAgriFood analysis through the collaboration of researchers from three areas of expertise (socio-economics, soil, fertiliser and water, and biodiversity and environment), along with local stakeholders. The scope and methods of the analysis were reviewed by peers and key project focal points, and endorsed by the project steering committee.  Site visits were organised to identify myGAP farms and key local stakeholders. Biophysical and geospatial data was collected from primary and secondary sources.
2023 Narrative: MARDI's detailed results have been reviewed by the project Technical committee, UNEP, and key project focal points. A policy makers synthesis will be presented at the Steering Committee and a national workshop with wide stakeholders within December. Key findings: The study provides guidance on specific enhancement strategies, including setting up farmgate price premiums, incentive payments, and IPM initiatives. Trust in government shows high impacts for policy effectiveness. A shift in appreciation for highland resources and promotion of community-based conservation can increase local benefits through economic multipliers, and societal benefits of preventing long-term environmental harm.

Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; Government of Denmark; Government of Japan; Government of New Zealand; Government of Sweden; Japan International Cooperation Agency; The World Bank; United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
"As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 157 459 (78 308 men and 79 151 women) vulnerable food insecure people in rural areas of Afghanistan with emergency agriculture assistance packages and cash based interventions under HRP 2022. A total of 28 767 (14 556 men, 14 211 women) vulnerable people were supported with summer crop seeds and trained on related technical trainings. Similarly, 121 411 (60 185 men and 61 226 women) vulnerable people benefited from home gardening packages and related technical trainings. A total of 7 281 (3567 men and 3714 women) vulnerable people benefited from cash for work activities. Overall, a total of 7 919 people belonging to 849 households headed by people with disability benefitted from FAO implemented activities. 

As of 30 June 2022, FAO supported 943 152 vulnerable food insecure people under HRP 2021 projects carried forward to 2022 with (i) certified seed of improved and locally adapted wheat varieties for the spring planting season and related technical training; (ii) animal feed and technical trainings on livestock best management practices; (iii) home gardening packages and related technical trainings; (iv) summer crop seeds and related technical trainings; (v) cash for work activities and unconditional cash transfers; (vi) COVID-19 awareness raising sessions.  

FAO financial delivery  under TEF Outcome 1 under HRP 2022 between January - June 2022 is USD 12,103,796. 
FAO carry-forward from HRP 2021 financial delivery between January -June 2022 is USD 22,958,955."
2022 Narrative: In 2022, to safeguard households' daily food and nutrition security and meet essential non-food related daily expenses, FAO engaged 168,756 people in cash for work interventions aimed to restore critical irrigation structures and 128,373 people in unconditional cash transfers.
2023 Narrative: During the reporting period, FAO supported 923,643 landless and highly food-insecure people (particularly female-headed households) with home gardening vegetable production packages, 47,103 people with summer crop production packages, and 96,341 people with backyard poultry production packages.In the meantime, in order to protect food and nutrition security and sustain agro/livestock-based livelihoods, FAO assisted 293,139 people with small farm equipment packages, 41,671 people with soybean cultivation packages, 525 people with micro-greenhouses, 315 people with backyard mushroom production packages, and 329 people with solar dryers.

2023 Narrative: WFP distributed specialized nutritious foods for malnutrition prevention as part of monthly food and cash assistance to households with children, or pregnant and breastfeeding women in priority Districts experiencing exceptionally high levels of hunger and malnutrition. 2.6 million children and 1.2 million pregnant women were served with specialized nutritious foods for the prevention of malnutrition in 2022. In 2023, preventive distributions followed the scaling down of general food assistance throughout the year, 1.8 million children and 999,523 women have been served. Note that all WFP final figures are cumulative, and preventive support takes place over several months, so the monthly figures cannot be aggregated.

2022 Narrative: During the second biannual of 2022 (July to December 2022) FAO carried out two assessments. These were 1) Data in Emergencies (DIEM-Monitoring) Round 5; and 2) DIEM Impact of the earthquake.1) The fifth-round data collection started on 24 July and completed on 27 August 2022. Overall, 6,019 households were surveyed in 25 provinces out of 34. The DIEM round findings contributed to the Integrated Phase Classification (IPC) analysis workshop from 24 September to 02 October 2022 as direct evidence. Analytical product produced is Afghanistan: DIEM-Data in Emergencies Monitoring Brief ‚ÄìRound 5. The brief presents key findings and recommendations for humanitarian actors to utilize in planning and implementing data-driven programming to sustain farmers‚Äô livelihoods and build their resilience to future shocks ‚Äì protecting the food security of rural people in Afghanistan.‚ÄØ2) DIEM-Impact conducted an assessment to understand the impact of the earthquake in Khost and Paktika on agricultural livelihoods and food security. Field data were collected between 23 July and 27 August 2022 in the three most affected districts ‚Äì Barmal, Giyan and Spera ‚Äì and have been integrated with remote sensing data. The DIEM-Impact assessment focused on damage and losses. Overall, 549 household were surveyed in the three districts. The analytical product developed is StoryMap: The impact of the earthquake on agricultural livelihoods and food security.In addition, in 2022 FAO supported Food Security and Agriculture Cluster activities to provide an action-oriented forum for bringing together national and international humanitarian partners to improve the timeliness and effectiveness of humanitarian assistance on the lives of crisis-affected population in Afghanistan.
2023 Narrative: During the first biannual of 2023 (January to June 2023) FAO carried out two assessments. These were 1) Data in Emergencies (DIEM-Monitoring) Round 6; and 2) Impact of the cold-wave.1) The sixth-round data collection started on 19 January and completed on 15 February 2022. Overall, 26 provinces, 6 032 rural households and 313 agriculture input vendors were interviewed to monitoring data on the dynamic impacts of shocks to agricultural livelihoods, food security and value chain. The DIEM round findings contributed to the Integrated Phase Classification (IPC) analysis workshop from 24 September to 02 October 2022 as direct evidence. Analytical product produced is Afghanistan: DIEM-Data in Emergencies Monitoring Brief ‚ÄìRound 6. The brief presents key findings and recommendations for humanitarian actors to utilize in planning and implementing data-driven programming to sustain farmers‚Äô livelihoods and build their resilience to future shocks ‚Äì protecting the food security of rural people in Afghanistan.‚ÄØ2) DIEM-Impact conducted an assessment to understand the impact of the January 2023 cold wave in Afghanistan on livestock. Cold wave impact assessment on livestock covered both urban and rural areas of all 34 provinces and 16 700 households face-to-face surveyed from 26 February to 23 March 2023. The DIEM-Impact assessment focused on damage and losses. Dissemination materials such as presentation, analysis report and tabular data were made available to partners.In addition, in 2023 FAO supported Food Security and Agriculture Cluster activities to provide a monthly brief on Early Warning and climate analysis to help humanitarian partners to have an overview on medium- and long-term weather impact on agriculture and livelihoods, along with relevant information of hazards such as drought, flood, animal and plant diseases, pests (i.e. April 2023 locust infestation).

Strategic priority: Driver 3: Human security and socio-economic resilience
Outcome: By 2022, people in Sri Lanka, especially the vulnerable and marginalised groups of children, youth, women, migrants, elderly and disabled, benefit equitably from dynamic and responsive social protection systems.
Output: Nutrition and Food Security

FAO - Activities not started yet

Description: The project aimed to facilitate access to inputs so that farmers are able to cultivate green grams in the upcoming interim cultivation season, successfully.  A total of 8750 smallholder farmers received a direct cash transfer of $60/HH.  The key targeting criteria for receiving the cash transfer was a landholding of ‚â§ 2 acres and green gram (mung bean) cultivation of ‚â§ 1 acre.  Originally, the project scope included seven of the main green gram growing districts of the country
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Sri Lanka Department of Agriculture
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Data Collection and Analysis; Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Priority given to women headed hoseholds when selecting beneficiaries
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2022 Narrative: A direct one time cash transfer of 60 USD was transferred small holder farmers engaged in growing green gram (mung bean) as an end Yala / mid season crop. This transfer was made in anticipation to enhance production of green gram to help farmers and other poorer sections of the society to meet their protein requirement, especially in view of the rising cost of animal-based protein sources. Furthermore, its nitrogen fixing qualities would help in reducing N fertilizer need for the subsequent crop, and crop residue can increase organic matter on paddy land, benefitting the farmer transitioning into Maha season after green gram cultivation. Out of 9194 farmers 9150 received an amount of USD 60 as per selected beneficiary farmer household, via Standard Chartered Bank transfer (FAOs financial service provider). Which was following the verification of the beneficiary details in order to minimize the inclusion errors and avoid unnecessary delays while eliminating the possible corruptions.  In parallel to the cash transfer, a series of refresher training on soil nutrient management and mung bean crop management were provided. The training and knowhow to cope up with the cultivation under low soil moisture status. Women farmers were given priority in every activity to ensure and empower their financial status. All the activities were closely monitored with the key performance indicators to ensure they were happening in the ground as expected in relation to output, outcome and impact.  Arrangements were made to organize and conduct farmer training to enable Agriculture Extension personals in the respective administrative units. (Agriculture instructors, Agriculture technical assistants, Agricultural officers). In the training sessions, special emphasis was given to address the utilization of minimum external inputs such as fertilizer, agro-chemicals and irrigation water in mung bean cultivation. The training contents included were soil water and nutrients conservation and sustainable utilization, raw seeding and weed management, cultural practices, harvesting and post-harvest practices, storage and marketing. Necessary handouts were distributed among participants for further reference.

2022 Narrative: The main objective of this project is to increase food security, by enabling paddy farmers to cultivate in the 2022 cropping season and to supplement the food and nutritional needs of small-scale fishers' households. This FAO project provides 15,619 farmers with agricultural inputs and $US 867,636 in multi-purpose cash to 6,886 people among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 22,034 people, including 5,921 women, 16,113 men, including 1,101 people with disabilities.
